    <div class="published" id="main">
     <div class="ajax-delay-load" id="storyWrapper">
      <div class="article collapsable-panel" data-story_id="949492" id="article-1">
       <div class="meta share-expanded">
        <div class="clearfix" id="group_info">

          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="heading">
          <span class="name">
           Sustainable Food and Agriculture
          </span>
          <span class="follow">

        <p class="date">
         Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 06:43 PM PST
        </p>
        <h2>
         <a href="/story/2011/02/25/949492/-A-Scientific-Bombshell-Dropped-This-Week" id="titleHref">
          A Scientific Bombshell Dropped This Week
         </a>
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
         </span>
        </h2>
        <p class="author">
         <span>
          by
         </span>
         <a href="/user/Jill Richardson">
          Jill Richardson
         </a>
         <a alt="Follow this author" class="ajax type-user do-hotlist do-updateContent size-tiny off altTooltip" href="#?friend_id=172753&amp;is_stream=1">
          Follow
         </a>
         <span class="for">
          for
         </span>
         <a href="/blog/Sustainable Food and Agriculture">
          Sustainable Food and Agriculture
         </a>
        </p>
        <ul class="front-page-share clearfix">
         <li style="margin-left: 0px">
          <div class="fb-share-button" data-href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/02/25/949492/-A-Scientific-Bombshell-Dropped-This-Week" data-layout="button_count">
          </div>
         </li>
         <li>
          <a class="twitter-share-button" data-count="horizontal" data-related="markos" data-text="A Scientific Bombshell Dropped This Week" data-url="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/02/25/949492/-A-Scientific-Bombshell-Dropped-This-Week" data-via="dailykos" href="https://twitter.com/share">
           Tweet
          </a>
         </li>
         <li>
          <a class="comments comment_count_with_new" data-comment_count="733" data-story_id="949492" href="/story/2011/02/25/949492/-A-Scientific-Bombshell-Dropped-This-Week#comments">
           733 Comments
          </a>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </div>
       <div class="article-body">
        <div id="intro">
         <p>
          This week, something big happened. The Farm and Ranch Freedom Alliance (FARFA) published a
          <a href="http://farmandranchfreedom.org/gmo-miscarriages">
           letter
          </a>
          on their website, written by Dr. Don Huber to Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack. The letter detailed preliminary findings that link the herbicide Roundup and/or genetically modified Roundup Ready crops to miscarriages in animals.
         </p>
         <p>
          Stories pop up ALL THE TIME about GMOs causing this disease or that, and usually I don't believe them. This time, Judith McGeary of FARFA (a good friend of mine) was certain that this is a big story. The findings are preliminary. But Dr. Huber found them concerning enough that he wrote to Tom Vilsack asking that a major expansion of the use of genetically modified crops (the deregulation of GE alfalfa) be postponed until more research can be done.
         </p>
         <p>
          The letter's below, along with my own analysis of how seriously we take this. Normally, I don't put much stock in stuff like this, but I've been astounded at the reaction people who are far wiser than me have had to this. Yesterday I was talking about something else entirely to a farmer with a PhD in soil fertility and he called this letter a "game changer." If he thinks that, then this is probably something to pay attention to - and then complete the study and have it peer reviewed. But Huber's calling for caution in the meantime.
         </p>
        </div>
        <p class="divider-doodle">
        </p>
        <div class="article-body" id="body">
         <blockquote>
          Dear Secretary Vilsack:
          <p>
           A team of senior plant and animal scientists have recently brought to my attention the discovery of an electron microscopic pathogen that appears to significantly impact the health of plants, animals, and probably human beings. Based on a review of the data, it is widespread, very serious, and is in much higher concentrations in Roundup Ready (RR) soybeans and cornsuggesting a link with the RR gene or more likely the presence of Roundup. This organism appears NEW to science!
          </p>
          <p>
           This is highly sensitive information that could result in a collapse of US soy and corn export markets and significant disruption of domestic food and feed supplies. On the other hand, this new organism may already be responsible for significant harm (see below). My colleagues and I are therefore moving our investigation forward with speed and discretion, and seek assistance from the USDA and other entities to identify the pathogens source, prevalence, implications, and remedies.
          </p>
          <p>
           We are informing the USDA of our findings at this early stage, specifically due to your pending decision regarding approval of RR alfalfa. Naturally, if either the RR gene or Roundup itself is a promoter or co-factor of this pathogen, then such approval could be a calamity. Based on the current evidence, the only reasonable action at this time would be to delay deregulation at least until sufficient data has exonerated the RR system, if it does.
          </p>
          <p>
           For the past 40 years, I have been a scientist in the professional and military agencies that evaluate and prepare for natural and manmade biological threats, including germ warfare and disease outbreaks. Based on this experience, I believe the threat we are facing from this pathogen is unique and of a high risk status. In laymans terms, it should be treated as an emergency.
          </p>
          <p>
           A diverse set of researchers working on this problem have contributed various pieces of the puzzle, which together presents the following disturbing scenario:
          </p>
          <p>
           <b>
            Unique Physical Properties
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           This previously unknown organism is only visible under an electron microscope (36,000X), with an approximate size range equal to a medium size virus. It is able to reproduce and appears to be a micro-fungal-like organism. If so, it would be the first such micro-fungus ever identified. There is strong evidence that this infectious agent promotes diseases of both plants and mammals, which is very rare.
          </p>
          <p>
           <b>
            Pathogen Location and Concentration
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           It is found in high concentrations in Roundup Ready soybean meal and corn, distillers meal, fermentation feed products, pig stomach contents, and pig and cattle placentas.
          </p>
          <p>
           <b>
            Linked with Outbreaks of Plant Disease
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           The organism is prolific in plants infected with two pervasive diseases that are driving down yields and farmer incomesudden death syndrome (SDS) in soy, and Goss wilt in corn. The pathogen is also found in the fungal causative agent of SDS (Fusarium solani fsp glycines).
          </p>
          <p>
           <b>
            Implicated in Animal Reproductive Failure
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           Laboratory tests have confirmed the presence of this organism in a wide variety of livestock that have experienced spontaneous abortions and infertility. Preliminary results from ongoing research have also been able to reproduce abortions in a clinical setting.
          </p>
          <p>
           The pathogen may explain the escalating frequency of infertility and spontaneous abortions over the past few years in US cattle, dairy, swine, and horse operations. These include recent reports of infertility rates in dairy heifers of over 20%, and spontaneous abortions in cattle as high as 45%.
          </p>
          <p>
           For example, 450 of 1,000 pregnant heifers fed wheatlege experienced spontaneous abortions. Over the same period, another 1,000 heifers from the same herd that were raised on hay had no abortions. High concentrations of the pathogen were confirmed on the wheatlege, which likely had been under weed management using glyphosate.
          </p>
          <p>
           <b>
            Recommendations
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           In summary, because of the high titer of this new animal pathogen in Roundup Ready crops, and its association with plant and animal diseases that are reaching epidemic proportions, we request USDAs participation in a multi-agency investigation, and an immediate moratorium on the deregulation of RR crops until the causal/predisposing relationship with glyphosate and/or RR plants can be ruled out as a threat to crop and animal production and human health.
          </p>
          <p>
           It is urgent to examine whether the side-effects of glyphosate use may have facilitated the growth of this pathogen, or allowed it to cause greater harm to weakened plant and animal hosts. It is well-documented that glyphosate promotes soil pathogens and is already implicated with the increase of more than 40 plant diseases; it dismantles plant defenses by chelating vital nutrients; and it reduces the bioavailability of nutrients in feed, which in turn can cause animal disorders. To properly evaluate these factors, we request access to the relevant USDA data.
          </p>
          <p>
           I have studied plant pathogens for more than 50 years. We are now seeing an unprecedented trend of increasing plant and animal diseases and disorders. This pathogen may be instrumental to understanding and solving this problem. It deserves immediate attention with significant resources to avoid a general collapse of our critical agricultural infrastructure.
          </p>
          <p>
           Sincerely,
          </p>
          <p>
           COL (Ret.) Don M. Huber
           <br/>
           Emeritus Professor, Purdue University
           <br/>
           APS Coordinator, USDA National Plant Disease Recovery System (NPDRS)
           <br/>
          </p>
         </blockquote>
         <p>
          The letter makes some pretty serious claims about problems with Roundup and/or Roundup Ready crops. As I made clear above, this is preliminary research, so it's certainly not solid enough to believe as fact. The letter was sent to Tom Vilsack prior to the deregulation of GE alfalfa because the preliminary data was disturbing enough that the letter's author, Dr. Don Huber, felt the evidence we have in hand is enough to justify delaying the deregulation of GE alfalfa until we have more information.
         </p>
         <p>
          Now there are some questions arising about the letter. A few people even suggested it is a hoax. So I will share what I know, along with my own perspective and knowledge on GMO safety, which will hopefully give you a barometer to determine whether or not you find me a credible source on this.
         </p>
         <p>
          First of all, my close friend Judith McGeary, the person who first posted the letter online, personally confirmed with Dr. Huber that he did write the letter and send it to Tom Vilsack. So that much is not a hoax. However, many people are asking who is doing the study and where is the data they have thus far? And that information is not available publicly at the moment. Huber has not yet spoken to the media about his letter, although I believe he will in the near future.
         </p>
         <p>
          The safe thing to do is to wait until the study is done and published in a journal, the data is public for review, and the researchers behind the study are known. For all we know, as the study continues, this preliminary conclusion will be disproved. Or perhaps the study will be completed, and then a peer reviewer will notice a major flaw in the study. That said, Huber's reputation is pretty solid and it seems that he felt there was enough credibility in the evidence he saw and enough urgency that he wrote this letter and made the issue public.
         </p>
         <p>
          Personally, I usually disregard studies or claims that GMOs cause this disease or that. I am not a scientist, but I have common sense. I'll believe a claim about GMOs when a credible scientist - or, preferably, several - believes it. Internet rumors are just that.
         </p>
         <p>
          I also don't believe that there is anything inherently dangerous about GMOs. Simply because something is genetically modified does not make it dangerous or harmful. But it DOES mean that we need to study the heck out of each GM variety of seed before we commercialize it and put it into the food supply. And we should do that because we know quite well by now that containment of a GMO is impossible. Once a GMO is out there, it's out there. If you screw up once, it's game over.
         </p>
         <p>
          What's more, we need independent science on GMOs - and we do not have that. Not right now. And when scientists DO come forward with anything negative about GMOs, they are attacked. That needs to stop. Why would I believe Monsanto's word that its money-making product is safe anymore than I believe BP's word that its drilling won't cause an oil spill? Monsanto stands to gain a ton of money on each GMO they commercialize, and I have anecdotal evidence of intimidation of scientists by Monsanto from a trusted source. (I would need to get his permission to repeat what he said publicly to really make an accusation, so take my "anecdotal evidence" for what it's worth.)
         </p>
         <p>
          Right now, I have no interest in eating something that has not had independent science performed by scientists who felt safe and secure to publish their findings without being attacked. Nor do I want to eat something that the biotech companies refuse to even label. If you're so proud of it, label it so I know I'm eating it.
         </p>
         <p>
          What I do tend to believe are the very logical stories that come out about GMOs - if they come from a credible source. That is, it's easy to understand why Roundup Ready crops increase Roundup use. It's not terribly hard to imagine that Bt crops, which produce a insecticide in every cell, might kill insects (beyond just the targeted pest species). Nor is it a stretch to believe that Roundup resistant weeds are emerging and that farmers will need to spray a stronger, more toxic herbicide in addition to Roundup to get rid of them. Based on all of that, and given what I've read from scientists like
          <a href="http://www.biol.canterbury.ac.nz/people/heinemann.shtml">
           Jack Heinemann
          </a>
          , I think there is an awful lot of evidence that agroecology can accomplish what we are trying to accomplish with genetic engineering more successfully, with better impacts on the environment, and without as much risk.
         </p>
         <p>
          So, given all that, do we believe the Huber letter? First of all, I do not think anyone should take it as more than it is: evidence of an alarming preliminary finding that merits more research. Nothing more. But Huber himself seems rock solid and very credible. If he thinks this is a big deal - as he put it, an "emergency" - then there's reason to believe it is. I'll be interested to hear what he has to say once he speaks out about this. And I'll keep an eye out for the finished study, once it's published.
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
       <h4>
        Originally posted to
        <a href="/blog/Sustainable Food and Agriculture/">
         Sustainable Food and Agriculture
        </a>
        on Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 06:43 PM PST.
       </h4>
       <h4>
        Also republished by
        <a href="/blog/DK GreenRoots/">
         DK GreenRoots
        </a>
        .
       </h4>
       <div class="tags">

        <div>
         <p>
          Add keywords that describe this diary.
		Separate multiple keywords with commas.
          <br/>
          <a href="/special/tag_tips" target="_blank">
           Tagging tips
          </a>
          -
          <a href="/search?search_tags=1" target="_blank">
           Search For Tags
          </a>
          -
          <a href="http://www.dkosopedia.com/wiki/Tag:Tagfinder" target="_blank">
           Browse For Tags
          </a>
         </p>
         <div class="pageTip hasTooltip" style="margin-top:3px">
          ?
         </div>
         <div class="tooltipContents qtip-style-dk4_large qtip-pos-br">
          <p>
           <b>
            More Tagging tips:
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           A tag is a way to search for this diary. If someone is searching for "Barack Obama," is this a diary they'd be trying to find?
          </p>
          <p>
           Use a person's full name, without any title. Senator Obama may become President Obama, and Michelle Obama might run for office.
          </p>
          <p>
           If your diary covers an election or elected official, use election tags, which are generally the state abbreviation followed by the office. 
		CA-01 is the first district House seat. CA-Sen covers both senate races. NY-GOV covers the New York governor's race.
          </p>
          <p>
           Tags do not compound: that is, "education reform" is a completely different tag from "education". A tag like "reform" alone is probably not meaningful.
          </p>
         </div>
         <!-- &lt;h4 id="p_tagErrorMessage"&gt;You must enter at least one Tag for this Diary Entry:&lt;/h4&gt; -->
         <p>
          <input id="p_tagInput" name="tag_draft" size="70" type="text" value=""/>
          <!-- &lt;input id="tagSubmit" type="submit" name="submit" value="Submit" /&gt; -->
         </p>
         <p style="font-style:italic">
          Consider if one or more of these tags fits your diary:
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Civil Rights');return false;">
           Civil Rights
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Community');return false;">
           Community
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Congress');return false;">
           Congress
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Culture');return false;">
           Culture
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Economy');return false;">
           Economy
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Education');return false;">
           Education
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Elections');return false;">
           Elections
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Energy');return false;">
           Energy
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Environment');return false;">
           Environment
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Health Care');return false;">
           Health Care
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('International');return false;">
           International
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Labor');return false;">
           Labor
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Law');return false;">
           Law
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Media');return false;">
           Media
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Meta');return false;">
           Meta
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('National Security');return false;">
           National Security
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Science');return false;">
           Science
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Transportation');return false;">
           Transportation
          </a>
          , or
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('White House');return false;">
           White House
          </a>
          .
	If your diary is specific to a state, consider adding the state 
	(
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('California');return false;">
           California
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Texas');return false;">
           Texas
          </a>
          , etc).
	Keep in mind, though, that there are many wonderful and important diaries
	that don't fit in any of these tags. Don't worry if yours doesn't.
         </p>

            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509532">
             <li id="c199">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40511793">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 dangerous denialism.
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40511793#c199?mode=alone;showrate=1#c199">
                  18+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:1228">
                   zzyzx
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:4498">
                   laurak
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:8078">
                   BigOkie
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:10342">
                   Pescadero Bill
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:24892">
                   samddobermann
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:27823">
                   Cedwyn
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:58452">
                   Sandino
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:64284">
                   debedb
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:67799">
                   417els
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:70434">
                   Catesby
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:72404">
                   AnnCetera
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:74087">
                   The Hindsight Times
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:79314">
                   suspiciousmind
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:110590">
                   gzodik
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                   Cassandra Waites
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:196939">
                   Inspector Javert
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:198784">
                   Faeya Wingmother
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:303096">
                   bigrivergal
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 Some people actually think we don't have a population problem, and that the failure to solve for starvation and endemic disease and resource wars throughout history is merely a management or engineering problem.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Some people think we don't have a population problem because even China has tons of habitable space, not to mention the surfaces of the oceans, regardless of factors such as land needed for food supply and waste disposal.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Some people are in such deep denial that they won't recognize we have a population problem even when mass dieoffs occur.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:44695">
                  G2geek
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40511793#c199">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:19:06 AM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c81">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40511793">
              <li id="c258">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40514413">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Population problem?
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40514413#c258?mode=alone;showrate=1#c258">
                   7+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:31985">
                    milton333
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:80807">
                    shaharazade
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                    Cassandra Waites
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:181518">
                    ban nock
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:209472">
                    Sonofasailor
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                    Joieau
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:289901">
                    Eugene Fitzherbert
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  The problem with calling it a "population problem" is that it conjures up an image of nameless hordes of subsistence-level humans in India and China breeding like rabbits. Like they're the problem.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Last I heard, the average "citizen" in the U.S. (which of course doesn't have nameless hordes) consumes some thirty times the amount of earth's resources than those nameless people do. We can achieve the same impact by nixing the birth of thirty rabbit-people, or by bringing one American back down to size.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I would prefer to see the issue phrased as an"unsustainability problem" -- which includes growth of the developing economies, but remains centered on the biggest problem, which is overconsumption in the developed world.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:81763">
                   Eikyu Saha
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40514413#c258">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 07:13:27 AM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c199">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40514413">

                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Children on the streets sniffing glue...
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40519017#c381?mode=alone;showrate=1#c381">
                     3+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">

                    are not a population problem. They are a function of poverty. If we see this as a "population" problem, we fail to address the root cause, which is the inequity of our system of distributing the world's resources.

                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       Particularly, half as many wherever it is that you yourself live, because that means more opportunity, more prosperity, etc., for those who are living there.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       I'll take half as many in California where I live. If I lived in New York I'd prefer half as many New Yorkers. Etc.
                      </p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="cf">
                      <p class="sig">
                      </p>
                      <p class="cb">
                       by
                       <a href="/user/uid:44695">
                        G2geek
                       </a>

                       <a href="/comments/949492/40542351#c723">

                  <li id="c607">
                   <div class="cx" id="cx40525439">
                    <h5>
                     <a class="de">
                     </a>
                     <span class="cu">
                      Resources would get cheaper
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">
                      (
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40525439#c607?mode=alone;showrate=1#c607">
                       0+ / 0-
                      </a>
                      )
                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      If we had 1/4 as many people, a lot of commodities would get a lot cheaper. So people would consume more. Think of the fossil fuels we'd burn! Also, with fewer people polluting, governments could let people pollute more.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      The great thing about a lower population is, it would pretty much absolve anybody from worrying about how they live. The problem is, how do we get all those excess Indians, Chinese and Africans to disappear so we can continue to live carelessly?
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      I don't believe lowering the earch's population would reduce human damage to the planet at all, in fact it might increase it.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      What strikes me most about your comment is your last statement, you liked it at least twice as much w 1/2 the people. You've given me the impression you don't care much about the environment, you just don't like people. Not a persuasive argument.  Personally I think most of this talk about overpopulation is just a "Lebensraum" sentiment on the part of people who think they have a right to overconsume.
                     </p>
                    </div>

                  <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525439">
                   <li id="c724">
                    <div class="cx" id="cx40542373">
                     <h5>
                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       Jevon's Paradox:
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/949492/40542373#c724?mode=alone;showrate=1#c724">
                        1+ / 0-
                       </a>
                       )
                      </span>
                     </h5>
                     <div class="crs">
                      <dl>
                       <dt>
                        Recommended by:
                       </dt>
                       <dd>
                        <a href="/user/uid:79314">
                         suspiciousmind
                        </a>
                       </dd>
                      </dl>
                     </div>
                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       Conservation increases consumption by driving down prices.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       And the cure for that is a culture change to where consumption is not an end in itself, and other means to the ends of personal happiness are more accessible.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Among other things, this also requires a zero-growth economy: steady state.  And that in turn requires distributional equity: social democracy.
                      </p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="cf">
                      <p class="sig">
                      </p>
                      <p class="cb">
                       by
                       <a href="/user/uid:44695">

                       <a href="#c607">

                       </a>

                      </p>

                  <li id="c725">
                   <div class="cx" id="cx40542410">
                    <h5>
                     <a class="de">
                     </a>
                     <span class="cu">
                      since average Americans have 10x the impact of...
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">
                      (
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40542410#c725?mode=alone;showrate=1#c725">
                       0+ / 0-
                      </a>
                      )
                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      .... average Indians or Chinese, that means the impact of America is equivalent to 3 billion more Indians or Chinese.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      That means America is overpopulated.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      And one very effective definition of overpopulation is, dependent on foreign sources for core necessities such as water, food, or energy.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Global trade in foodstuffs and energy should be limited by international treaty to the exchange of equivalent caloric or BTU value respectively. That would solve the population and consumption problems in one generation.
                     </p>
                    </div>

               <li id="c298">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40516372">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   I don't think you can separate the size of the
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40516372#c298?mode=alone;showrate=1#c298">
                    4+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>

                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>

                   </dt>

                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   population from the idea of sustainability.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Given the prediction that "
                   <a href="http:/http://climateprogress.org/2011/02/24/half-of-world%E2%80%99s-population-could-face-climate-driven-food-crisis-in-second-half-of-the-century/">
                    Half of worlds population could face climate-driven food crisis in second half of the century
                   </a>
                   ".
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Basically, we're looking at a planet that won't be able to produce enough food for half the world's population. No matter how you slice it up, we'll have too many mouths to feed in the coming decades.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   So the "biggest problem" is climate change. And growing the developing economies won't do anything but exacerbate that problem.
                  </p>

               <li id="c721">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40542318">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   don't use euphemisms:
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40542318#c721?mode=alone;showrate=1#c721">
                    0+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   Of course we have an "unsustainability problem."
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   And that's a euphemism for:
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    Overpopulation.
                   </strong>
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   and
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    Overconsumption.
                   </strong>
                   (You used that word yourself.)
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   BTW, factor for the US is 10: an average American has the impact of ten average Indians or Chinese. That means that the US has the impact of 3.5 billion Indians or Chinese.  And that means the US is overpopulated.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   50% of our impact is pure waste, as compared to Europe, so by cutting out the waste we're down to 1.75 billion Indian- or Chinese-equivalent.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   But regardless of all else, every human requires X calories, Y liters of water, Z amount of sewage disposal, and Q square feet in which to sleep, every single day, or things break and people die. So population is relevant regardless of consumption level.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">

               <li id="c629">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40526368">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Of weeds, yes.
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40526368#c629?mode=alone;showrate=1#c629">
                    2+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:19891">
                     justme
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:170476">
                     MsGrin
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   And the self-seeded remnants of last year's crop counts as "weed" when you're trying to grow something else. Plowing is what you do to turn the ground. Then you till 'fertilizer' (often composed of industrial waste and coal ash) into it. Then you spray the shit out of it again to get the leftover weeds that might want to come up. Then you plant your crop.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   I see you aren't much into farming. I am, but I use a no-plow, no-till methodology. Glyphosate? Never touch the stuff. Or GMOs designed to tolerate or express poisons.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">

                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:

                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  to the wheat when spraying a field to clear the field before planting the wheat.
                 </p>
                 <p>

           <li id="c242">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40514028">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Not confirmed yet?
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40514028#c242?mode=alone;showrate=1#c242">
                8+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:1113">
                 cdreid
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:33373">
                 johanus
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:56170">
                 EdlinUser
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:75635">
                 mcmom
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:80807">
                 shaharazade
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                 Cassandra Waites
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:143104">
                 radmul
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:146179">
                 dark daze
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               When something highly "artificial" (i.e., many steps removed from nature) appears on the market, the basic presumption should be that it is inherently toxic. The burden of proof should be for the producer to pay for independent studies that demonstrate lack of toxicity. If there is even the slightest doubt, the product should be withdrawn until that doubt is cleared up.
              </p>
              <p>
               If toxicity is even slightly demonstrated, even if it has yet to be confirmed, the default should be to halt production and remove it from the market, pending further study. Not the other way around.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:81763">
                Eikyu Saha
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40514028#c242">

              </p>

               <a href="#c21">

               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524936">
                <li id="c733">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40623114">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    If it's not peer reviewed, it's not science.
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40623114#c733?mode=alone;showrate=1#c733">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    And you're confusing the FDA approval process with the peer-review process, which is the foundation of modern science and the only way hokum is weeded out from legitimate science. It's peer-reviewed science that exposed the dangerous of the very products you're railing about.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    If it matters, it gets at least one peer-reviewed study on it. You seem to have no idea of the vast volume of research out there.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    To put the peer-review process which you seem to hate so much into plain terms: peer-review means, "We don't believe something just because some random person asserts it's true." Which is
                    <strong>
                     precisely
                    </strong>
                    what's happening in this article. Peer-review is not flawless, but it's a world better than just taking anything some random person or group asserts at face value. You have to have a group of (ideally independent) individuals who are experts in the field say, "We think this person is onto something." Random individuals on the net are simply not going to have the background necessary to tell if some claims made by some random person or group is legit or just them talking out their arse.
                    <br/>
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:137348">
                     Rei
                    </a>

                   <dl>

                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                      mem from somerville
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                      lostboyjim
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:137348">
                      Rei
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:175912">
                      cdkipp
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    It's sadly probably not a hoax, just misguided. Reuters has evidence that Huber's now working with or for a notoriously evidence-optional anti-GMO organization.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Knowing that, the goal here is not to actually complete a study. The goal is to delay deployment of GMO alfalfa and poison public opinion.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">

             <li id="c489">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40522134">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 and there is no GE Wheat
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40522134#c489?mode=alone;showrate=1#c489">
                  1+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                   Hopeful Skeptic
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/04/us-monsanto-wheat-gmo-idUSTRE6A34K220101104">
                  http://www.reuters.com/...
                 </a>
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                  Roger Fox
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40522134#c489">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:43:37 PM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c274">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522134">
              <li id="c537">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40523277">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Absolutely irrelevant.
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40523277#c537?mode=alone;showrate=1#c537">
                   2+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:170476">
                    MsGrin
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:198784">
                    Faeya Wingmother
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  This is suspicion of a 'new' pathogen, a virus-size fungus that looks to thrive in glyphosate-rich environments. Like agricultural fields sprayed with glyphosate, and fields of RR crops that are sprayed even more with glyphosate. The letter issues warning based on these preliminary findings. Because Vilsak was going to approve RR alfalfa (millions of acres, most of it pasture and fodder for diary) before the research could be finished.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Alfalfa grows fine without RoundUp. So there really wasn't any need for RR alfalfa. USDA acknowledges that RR alfalfa will contaminate organic alfalfa and wreak havoc on certification standards for milk and meat. Almost as if they did that on purpose...
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40523277#c537">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 02:45:03 PM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c489">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40523277">
               <li id="c541">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40523427">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   From the letter:
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40523427#c541?mode=alone;showrate=1#c541">
                    5+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:1276">
                     NorthCountryNY
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                     mem from somerville
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:20436">
                     Wee Mama
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:70434">
                     Catesby
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                     xgz
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <blockquote>
                   High concentrations of the pathogen were confirmed on the wheatlege, which likely had been under weed management using glyphosate.
                  </blockquote>
                  <p>
                   The whole point -- er, "point" -- the letter makes is that either glyphosate or glyphosate-resistant crops encourage the growth of this ... thing. Which does not and cannot exist. But moving on.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   In this cattle "study", which almost surely doesn't exist, the glyphosate-enriched population is the one fed wheat.
                   <strong>
                    That makes no sense.
                   </strong>
                   It is possible to apply glyphosate to a wheat field prior to planting. The chemical doesn't tend to persist in the environment very long (or you couldn't do this). It kills the weeds, and by the time you plant the what, it's gone.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Know how you know it's gone?
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Because there's no glyphosate-resistant wheat. Glyphosate kills wheat. Unless there were glyphosate-resistant wheat. Which there isn't.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Therefore the glyphosate-rich population in the nonexistent cattle study
                   <strong>
                    cannot
                   </strong>
                   be the one fed wheat. If you wanted a cattle population fed from a high-glyphosate-exposure environment, you'd feed it Roundup-ready
                   <em>
                    corn
                   </em>
                   silage that had been subject to repeated herbicide applications. But that's not what the letter says they did. It says something impossible.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Which makes sense, because the letter basically says they did 7 impossible things ... before breakfast.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                    Serpents Choice
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40523427#c541">
                    Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 02:53:56 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c537">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40523427">
                <li id="c551">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40523789">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Additionally Read the label
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40523789#c551?mode=alone;showrate=1#c551">
                     2+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                      mem from somerville
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                      xgz
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    The Round up label states to use drinking water to mix with the round up before spraying. Why? Because round up chemically binds with soil particles. THe label warns you not to use water from a stream or river because said water will have silt, which the round up bonds to, making the entire batch useless.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    So if you clear a field using roundup, before planting non GE Wheat, you need to explain how the round up is transferred to the wheat.......
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Or else someone might call bullshit on ya .....
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.

                      <p>
                       If he was working with Monsanto's GMO wheat, he would have ... well, needed Monsanto's permission. There are few universal truths. But something that comes close is that Monsanto
                       <strong>
                        will
                       </strong>
                       sue the shit out of you if you step on their intellectual property rights.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       This was pretty clearly not a Monsanto-sponsored study. For one thing, when they pay people, they expect it to get published. They don't pay for press releases. Well, okay, actually they do pay for press releases, but they pay
                       <em>
                        other people
                       </em>
                       for them, not the scientists.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       And they make damn sure that anyone working with their stuff publishes conclusions one step at a time, the way you are supposed to. As opposed to this balderdash, which would have been like 8-10 top-tier journal pubs if it were real, instead of one ranty memo to the government.

                  </p>

             <p>
              But, to expect Vilsack/the Obama Admin to do anything about this is utter folly.
              <em>
               That doesn't mean we shouldn't try
              </em>
              ; but, we are rapidly losing the last ground against the corporatocracy, and we can no longer count on any help at all from the elected (or appointed) Democrats at the national level. For whatever reasons--personal profit, longtime association, sudden stardom, or a completely discredited and baseless belief that what is good for Megabusiness is good for the American people, the vast majority of Democrats in D.C. now subscribe to some version of Hooverism/trickle-down economics.
             </p>
             <p>
              What we need, in part, is a whistleblower along the lines of what Jeffrey Wigand (or, maybe, Merrell Williams) was to the tobacco companies. But, no doubt, that person would suddenly be exposed as, say, a sex offender or something, to discredit them.
             </p>
             <p>
              Dark times. Dark, dark times. It is our duty to fight on even in the absence of hope.

          <li id="c33">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40508561">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              N=2000, effect size 450 to 0, is significant.
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40508561#c33?mode=alone;showrate=1#c33">
               32+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:1625">
                opendna
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:4138">

               </a>

               <a href="/user/uid:4498">
                laurak
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:10342">

               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:17036">

               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:25269">

               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:27823">
                Cedwyn
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:31383">
                mrkvica
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:31900">
                pat bunny
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                kalmoth
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:37157">
                lcrp
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:38076">
                walkshills
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:40685">
                TheOrchid
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:48901">
                Heiuan
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:50721">
                offred
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:51087">
                JohnB47
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:51603">
                Simplify
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:64371">
                RJDixon74135
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:65907">
                buddabelly
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:72100">
                greenearth
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:72404">
                AnnCetera
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:83832">
                OHdog
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:86112">
                pgm 01
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                Cassandra Waites
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:136604">
                207wickedgood
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:154707">
                Dragon5616
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:163690">
                wvmom
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:169483">
                rja
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:170476">
                MsGrin
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:184001">
                vahana
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:195130">
                dle2GA
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:209053">
                Anthony Page aka SecondComing
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              I don't have enough knowledge of the relevant fields of science (veterinary medicine, biology) to say which of a number of statistical significance tests is appropriate for looking at those data.  But there's no way in hell that an effect of size 450 on a sample of size 1000 compared to a control group of size 1000 is due to chance or coincidence.
             </p>
             <p>
              The only other viable hypothesis is that some other treatment given to the test group was responsible for the spontaneous abortions. So the very first thing to do is to compare all of the other circumstances of both samples. Or one could just swap the feed between two subsequent herds in the same facilities, and see if the spontaneous abortions track the feed.
             </p>
             <p>
              If this was about a pharmaceutical for human use, there's no way FDA would approve it unless for use as an abortifacient. And then the "every blastocyst is sacred" crowd would be screaming to have it banned.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:44695">
               G2geek
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40508561#c33">
               Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 07:45:29 PM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c8">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40508561">
           <li id="c184">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40511364">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               But that's the problem with this...
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40511364#c184?mode=alone;showrate=1#c184">
                13+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                 taylormattd
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:4138">
                 copymark
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:14467">
                 Duncan Idaho
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:20436">
                 Wee Mama
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:24892">
                 samddobermann
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                 murrayewv
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:44695">
                 G2geek
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:94098">
                 Van Buren
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                 Cassandra Waites
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                 lostboyjim
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                 KroneckerD
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:197542">
                 docmidwest
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                 cryonaut
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               We don't have any facts to compare. The difference could be all kind of things. But without publishing the methods or the data, just a pair of numbers and a conclusion, we have no means of even considering all the possibilities, but there are many plausible differences that could have effects--the two groups have been fed different foods, and thus must have been kept separately.
              </p>
              <p>
               This isn't the way quality scientists go about publicizing research. As I have said, this smells bad to me.
              </p>
              <p>
               I also find the 0 abortions in hay group nearly as improbable as the 450... A certain number of abortions are normal and to be expected, and I find it hard to believe that in 1000 pregnant cows, not one aborted. Seems way too convenient.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">

            <li id="c186">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40511471">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I find it impossible
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40511471#c186?mode=alone;showrate=1#c186">
                 15+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                  taylormattd
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:4138">
                  copymark
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                  mem from somerville
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:14467">
                  Duncan Idaho
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:20436">
                  Wee Mama
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:24892">
                  samddobermann
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:31900">
                  pat bunny
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                  murrayewv
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:44695">
                  G2geek
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                  whl
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:97977">
                  Geek of all trades
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                  Cassandra Waites
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                  lostboyjim
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:174871">
                  bicycle Hussein paladin
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:187444">
                  FarWestGirl
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                In the first three weeks of pregnancy, the miscarriage (spontaneous abortion) rate for beef cattle runs around 30%, and drops to somewhere in the range of 2 to 5% by about the sixth week. The high initial rate means that farmers really don't start keeping track of them until about 45 days in. Five percent and under is considered entirely normal.
               </p>
               <p>
                (Incidentally, those numbers date from long before genetic engineered crops were more than a glimmer in a science fiction writer's eye.)
               </p>
               <p>
                Even if the abortions allegedly being counted omitted those prior to the sixth week, there still should have been anywhere between 20 and 50 in a herd of 1000 cattle.
               </p>
              </div>

              <li id="c201">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40512026">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Among humans...
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40512026#c201?mode=alone;showrate=1#c201">
                   16+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                    taylormattd
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:4138">
                    copymark
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:5137">
                    glitterscale
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                    mem from somerville
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:20436">
                    Wee Mama
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:27823">
                    Cedwyn
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:31900">
                    pat bunny
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:37228">
                    riverlover
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                    murrayewv
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:44695">
                    G2geek
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:76550">
                    dirtfarmer
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                    whl
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                    Cassandra Waites
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                    lostboyjim
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                    KroneckerD
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                    cryonaut
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  The miscarriage rate is 15-20% (for women who
                  <em>
                   know
                  </em>
                  they are pregnant) is considered the standard, but when the most senstive tests to detect possible pregnancy are used, the rate has been found in some studies to be
                  <em>
                   60-70%
                  </em>
                  .
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  And that's in modern, healthy populations. In populations with endemic poor nutrition or other environmental stresses, which was common in most of human history, I wouldn't be surprised if it had actually been higher.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  That's why when I see "45% abortion rate, oh disaster for the cows!", I immediately get suspicious. The rates I gave for cattle is from what's observed (someone finds obvious aborted material, far enough along in the pregnancy that it's fairly easily seen). If, on the other hand, someone was specifically testing for pregnancy early using the same sort of hormonal testing used for humans, I wouldn't be in the least bit surprised if 45% was well on the low end.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  And that's why I
                  <em>
                   really
                  </em>
                  get suspicious when another population has 0%. That's just completely freaking unbelieveable.
                 </p>
                </div>
