          <li id="c217">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40513010">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Why does this happen?  Six-letter word--
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40513010#c217?mode=alone;showrate=1#c217">
               5+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:3590">
                hester
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:75635">
                mcmom
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:80807">
                shaharazade
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:146179">
                dark daze
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:160999">
                eXtina
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              P-R-O-F-I-T.
             </p>
             <p>
              Capitalism seeks to commoditize everything. It's especially great if you can get a monopoly on something people can't do without--like food. For years, Monsanto has essentially been trying to patent food, thereby obtaining a monopoly on what we eat. If you've seen "
              <a href="http://www.foodincmovie.com/">
               Food Inc
              </a>
              .," you've seen how Monsanto goes to great lengths to prevent anyone from growing crops from anybody else's seed, claiming that it violates their patents. They are doing this around the world.
             </p>
             <p>
              And writing a letter to Vilsack? Waste of time.
              <a href="http://www.organicconsumers.org/articles/article_15573.cfm">
               He's Monsanto's boy
              </a>
              .
             </p>
             <p>
              Organizing consumer strikes to break the hold this monopoly has on our farmers while growing your own in your back yard and (even better) community gardens you organize with your neighbors is the solution.
             </p>
             <p>
              And at some point, we may need to protect those community gardens from those Monsanto fuckers. They're that ruthless.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              <a href="http://libcom.org/history/articles/1896-1936-buenaventura-durruti" rel="nofollow">
               "We carry a new world in our hearts." - Durruti
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:79930">
               goinsouth
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40513010#c217">
               Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:04:37 AM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c8">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>

            <div class="ct">
             <blockquote>
              Unbelievable reporting!
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              Literally unbelievable. There are some pretty huge claims (virus-sized fungus) in that letter along with with a gigantic statistical red flag (45% to 0% abortion rates). I don't see how anyone could believe this without at least a look at the experimental setup and design - neither of which are discussed.
             </p>
             <p>
              When this "Scientific Bombshell" has been published in a respected peer-reviewed journal, I'll at least look at their research with an open mind. As it is currently "reported", I consider this to be at the same credibility level as the prophecies of Nostradamus.
             </p>
            </div>

          <li id="c249">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40514205">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Huber's first sentence is a mess...
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40514205#c249?mode=alone;showrate=1#c249">
               12+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                taylormattd
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:7638">
                Unstable Isotope
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:50893">
                DrFood
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                xgz
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                whl
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                Roger Fox
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:122357">
                Kathy S
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                KroneckerD
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                Hopeful Skeptic
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:209053">
                Anthony Page aka SecondComing
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                Margd
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                cryonaut
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              A team of senior plant and animal scientists have recently brought to my attention the discovery of
              <strong>
               an electron microscopic pathogen
              </strong>
              that appears to significantly impact the health of plants, animals, and probably human beings.
             </p>
             <p>
              An "electron microscope pathogen" would be a disease of the electron microscope. He should have written something like: "a recently discovered, previously unknown pathogen has been discovered by so and so."
             </p>
             <p>
              This blunder undermines Huber's scientific credibility; a boo-boo of this sort is unacceptable for a working, professional scientist.
              <br/>
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>

           <li id="c482">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40521986">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               I'm an electron microscopist
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40521986#c482?mode=alone;showrate=1#c482">
                8+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                 mem from somerville
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                 yuriwho
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:80060">
                 kurt
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                 xgz
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:120616">
                 Cassandra Waites
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                 KroneckerD
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                 Hopeful Skeptic
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                 cryonaut
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               and a plant pathologist. Kickbass is absolutely correct. That first sentence was not written by someone who works with plant pathologists. This is really unfortunate because there might be a real problem but this is so bogus, it screams out hoax.
              </p>
              <p>
               Koch's postulates isn't even mentioned.  You can't start talking about new life forms without performing Koch's postulates.
              </p>
              <p>
               It doesn't make sense that a run away gene or genes would take the form of a fungus. A viroid maybe, but a fungus is a complex life form with chitin in its cell walls.  Genes for chitin production just don't come out of thin air.
              </p>
              <p>
               Who did the electron microscopy? That information would be included in a real letter. The microscopy is a key part to the whole story.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                Margd
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40521986#c482">

               </a>
              </p>

               <a href="#c249">

               </a>

          <li id="c290">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40515940">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              The letter may be a hoax.
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40515940#c290?mode=alone;showrate=1#c290">
               6+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                taylormattd
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                mem from somerville
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                xgz
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                whl
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                Margd
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                cryonaut
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Plus, some letter without any documentation is not worth the paper it's printed on (since you can only use it for scratch paper if the other side is clean).
             </p>
             <p>
              That's what science is all about. Testing hypothesis not rushing out screaming because of a letter without even the names of the so-called "senior researchers". That was the first red flag.
             </p>
             <p>
              Science is not about believing what you want to believe, but what you have been convinced of, based on scientific evidence.
             </p>
             <p>
              This is just a crazy letter. When I read it, I see not the type of words used by scientists but the language of the layperson. What kind of pathogen? This just smells bogus to me.
             </p>
            </div>

               Hopeful Skeptic
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:197542">
               docmidwest
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:209053">
               Anthony Page aka SecondComing
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:215586">
               erush1345
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:289230">
               Margd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:298633">
               cryonaut
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             letter that scream "you've been punked!" The Kos community would do well to not buy into this until there are some peer-reviewed publications. I've never seen a scientist beyond college freshman status that would write in this manner and make these very odd phrasings. The biology doesn't seem credible either for a number of reasons.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:52737">
              ChemBob
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40509916#c103">
              Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 09:25:25 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c1">
              Parent
             </a>

            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509916">
          <li id="c126">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40510312">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              I agree there's lots to question
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40510312#c126?mode=alone;showrate=1#c126">
               9+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:4498">
                laurak
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:4598">
                Timaeus
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:25308">
                peraspera
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:36216">
                Calidrissp
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:56170">
                EdlinUser
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:73624">
                erratic
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:106731">
                trueblueliberal
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:170476">
                MsGrin
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:187444">
                FarWestGirl
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              But the letter does hang together relatively well for what it is - a note from a USDA scientist in the middle of preliminary research that has implications on a decision the non-technical Sec. Vilsack is about to make.
             </p>
             <p>
              The diarist is associated with the Organic Consumers Association and author of a book on food production issues. The person she notes as her source, from the FRFA, is indeed a member of that organization. And Dr. Huber's long research history into the effects of Roundup has brought him into close contact with the non-corporate factions of agriculture of which the FRFA is a major player. The chain of contact is quite plausible.
             </p>
             <p>
              The non-technical nature of the summary and lack of peer-review is likewise covered.
             </p>
             <p>
              Whether this letter is valid or not, well, someone here must know someone at USDA, or be able to file an FOIA, or something, or personally contact Dr. Huber to verify this info.
             </p>
             <p>
              And the validity of the claims (or whatever the actual discoveries turn out to be when published in a technical journal where people will actually understand the real designation of this organism) will have to wait until peer review is done.
             </p>
            </div>

              </span>

               <a href="/comments/949492/40516242#c292?mode=alone;showrate=1#c292">

                </a>

                <a href="/user/uid:160089">
                 patrickz
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:289230">

                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                 cryonaut
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               many suspicious things. Some of the things that hit me:
              </p>
              <p>
               This organism appears NEW to science!
              </p>
              <p>
               equal to a medium sized virus but yet ...
              </p>
              <p>
               micro-fungal like organism (seems like every hit was from this letter and I have never heard that phraseology)
              </p>
              <p>
               new animal pathogen in Round Ready crops, and its association with plant and animal diseases that are reaching epidemic proportions
              </p>
              <p>
               The simple fact is that given that they say that this is newly discovered, but yet associated with various long known plant diseases. If true, there would be a substantial paper trail indicating this association prior to any relationship to RR plants. And, there would be scientists that are named. Basically, this has to be totally bogus.
               <br/>
              </p>

            <blockquote>
             The safe thing to do is to wait until the study is done and published in a journal, the data is public for review, and the researchers behind the study are known. For all we know, as the study continues, this preliminary conclusion
             <strong>
              will be disproved
             </strong>
             . Or perhaps the study will be completed, and then a peer reviewer will notice a major flaw in the study. That said, Huber's reputation is pretty solid and it seems that he felt there was enough credibility in the evidence he saw and enough urgency that he wrote this letter and made the issue public.
            </blockquote>

            and waits to see how long it takes mem from somerville to pop up and claim that GM is all wonderfully safe and that DK users are all just hippie scaremongers who don't understand science....

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             1. failure to link to proof that there's not independent science being done on GMOs (Proof: Recent Mark Bittman piece in the NYT and a previous piece in the NYT as well... the former is in the opinion column but the latter is news)
             <br/>
             2. failure to link to proof that scientists are attacked if they come up with anything negative on GMOs (Proof: Google "Arpad Pusztai" and "Chapela and Quist" - there's also a great Nature piece about a scientist being attacked for her work on GMOs)
             <br/>
             3. Mentioning my anecdotal evidence w/o documentation and citing facts and names. I'm just not sure my friends want to be "outted" for being attacked by Monsanto. It's happened to 2 of them, one was a scientist, and the other an activist who is particularly effective. The scientist also told me another two incidences of Monsanto doing this to scientists.
            </p>

            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              - that I feel we need far longer longitudinal studies before GM goes into the food chain to be more certain as to the safety of our gene tweaking. To those who make a profit off of it, though, such patience and diligence is unfathomable and ludicrous.

                 <a href="/user/uid:154707">

                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:159657">

                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                  Hopeful Skeptic
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:215586">
                  erush1345
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                  Margd
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                  cryonaut
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                Personally I hate Monsanto as a company for their horrific business practices. However, when you support delusional statements not backed by solid data to undermine even Monsanto, you do yourself a and your cause a dis-service because people will look into the claim, find it to be untrue or unproven and then consider your group as quacks.
               </p>
               <p>
                It is impossible to prove something to be totally safe. You cannot prove a positive. You can only prove a hypothesis false. The last standing hypothesis that fits the data is considered true until it is dis-proven. That's how science works.
               </p>
              </div>

                 So the hypothesis is that Roundup
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40510084#c114?mode=alone;showrate=1#c114">
                  3+ / 0-

               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 causes spontaneous abortions in animals.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Therefore, until it is proven false, it is true.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Ban the shit - now!
                </p>
                <p>
                 Simply because beyond the damage it could be doing to crop and meat production, there's also the chance that it could very well be effecting women trying to have children as well.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Monsanto and other companies producing herbicides containing glyphosate could be in for a world of hurt if this turns out to be the case and they a) know about it, b) don't do the right thing ASAP.
                </p>
                <p>
                 There's been evidence of this from studies done in other countries that have been summarily dismissed by the corrupt USDA with the help of Monsanto funded studies -
                 <a href="http://www.theecologist.org/blogs_and_comments/commentators/other_comments/686959/revealed_the_glyphosate_research_the_gm_soy_lobby_doesnt_want_you_to_read.html">
                  http://www.theecologist.org/...
                 </a>
                 (This is an example of people suffering extreme exposure).
                </p>
                <p>
                 Roundup, the lifeblood of Monsanto, is a bane on humanity and animal alike.
                </p>

                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   to "dementia"?
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   That's about as provable given the information we have as is the claim of a virus sized fungus.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt

                <li id="c136">

                    who is now retired and emeritus is claiming to have discovered a new class of microorganisms without presenting any data.                       Sorry, no.

                       </a>
                      </dd>
                     </dl>
                    </div>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      A scientist who hadn't jumped on the conspiracy theory woo-train would never release a preliminary anything about something like this. There are at least three claims in this letter that, if true, would be instantaneous Nobel Prizes for whoever had them published. And then some.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      But they're not true. And even if you don't have the science background to understand why they are impossible (although it doesn't take much background for that), everyone should be automatically extra-suspicious because these claims aren't being published, they're being spewed out in yet another example of terribly bad science via press release.
                     </p>
                    </div>

              <li id="c257">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40514392">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Not exactly
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40514392#c257?mode=alone;showrate=1#c257">
                   6+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:7638">
                    Unstable Isotope
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                    murrayewv
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:78940">
                    zeke7237
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                    whl
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:122357">

                   </a>

                   <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                    Hopeful Skeptic
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  The hypothesis would be something like:
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The use of Roundup is linked to the emergence of a form of life never before observed in plants in locations where it is used, said form of life replicates in said plants, when said plants are consumed by ungulates, said ungulates suffer from spontaneous abortions.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The null hypothesis would be that Roundup does none of this.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  After one or two sentences I thought to myself, "This is someone
                  <em>
                   trying
                  </em>
                  to write like a scientist."
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I hate Roundup and would never use the crap, but I hate shitty science and the shitty science reporting just as much.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  This is either a hoax or the writing of a
                  <em>
                   Professor Emeritus, Gobbledygook
                  </em>
                  .
                 </p>
                </div>

                 <p class="sig">
                  One flower is made of the whole cosmos. - Thich Nhat Hahn

              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40514392">
               <li id="c329">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40517382">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   I'm reminded of Dr. James Hanson
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40517382#c329?mode=alone;showrate=1#c329">
                    1+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:170476">
                     MsGrin
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   and his original work. Met with a lot of scorn from industry and Bush government officials and instant suspicion by scientists that weren't privy to his findings.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   The difference being Hanson had a lot of eventual backup by means of so many other climate scientists doing their own studies. Hell, even today, people doubt his more drastic conclusions.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Huber on the other hand has very few colleagues in his field, specifically relating to Roundup and patented GMOs, do to the nefarious nature of the Monsanto threat. So few are doing his kind of in-depth research.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   And now, he's in the crosshairs of the Monsanto discredit machine. I think as senior lead of a team he put his name to this knowing he'd take the heat figuring he had a lot less to lose. I think perhaps, he's decided to become a scientist activist like Hanson.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   But, as I said before, time will tell IF the truth is allowed to get past the Monsanto tentacles.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">

               <h5>

                 that's not how reality works
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40525120#c597?mode=alone;showrate=1#c597">

                 </a>

               </h5>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 and you people have the nerve to go around yelling about superstitious dogmatic religious people. So nothing is true until some peer that works for Montsanto or is a scientist who meets your criteria of ? say's it is untrue? gimme a break.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:80807">
                  shaharazade
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40525120#c597">

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525120">
              <li id="c604">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40525309">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Um.
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40525309#c604?mode=alone;showrate=1#c604">

                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  I'm pretty sure that you're not interested in a real debate, but I'm waiting for my food to arrive, so I'll bite.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  You seem to think that the entire process of science -- testing and refinement of hypotheses -- is fatally flawed because Monsanto's a fairly unlikable company with a lot of money and it employs scientists. Or ... something.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  A lot of scientists don't work for Monsanto, you know, even in the agricultural science industry. A lot work in university research departments. Some even work for nonprofit organizations. Although I somehow doubt you consider that relevant because everyone with a job related to agribusiness has probably gotten money that can, eventually, be traced back to Monsanto
                  <em>
                   somehow
                  </em>
                  .
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  So what, exactly, do you suggest is a method of determining whether scientific statements -- statements about the physical, observable world -- are true?
                 </p>
                </div>

             <li id="c567">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40524308">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 please don't take offense at this question
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40524308#c567?mode=alone;showrate=1#c567">
                  2+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:80060">
                   kurt
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:170476">
                   MsGrin
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 Are you a bot?
                </p>
                <p>
                 I've skimmed through most of the comments here and you've posted these sentences a dozen or more times! I agree it's weird that Huber's letter refers to effects of consumption of wheat silage, but nowhere does he (or the diarist) state or even suggest that there is such a thing as Roundup-ready wheat, so why are you going on about this particular aspect of the letter?
                </p>
                <p>
                 I agree with you and other commenters who are suspicious of the non-scientific elements of this letter; there's
                 <a href="http://permaculturelist.blogspot.com/2011/02/permaculture-nanobes-re-pathogen-new-to.html">
                  a good critical discussion of the letter here
                 </a>
                 , and I'm skeptical too. But as other commenters here have noted, Huber's letter wasn't intended as a scientific publication, but as a privileged communication with the Sec'y of Agriculture. Scientists who have preliminary data that is not yet suitable for peer-review, nonetheless have a right and a responsibility to act based on their specialized knowledge.
                </p>
                <p>
                 It is very reasonable for us to ask to see the data that Huber is using. I hope we learn more soon. Meanwhile I think further study of this subject is worthwhile.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:14467">
                  Duncan Idaho
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40524308#c567">

          <li id="c495">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40522263">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              There is no GE Wheat
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40522263#c495?mode=alone;showrate=1#c495">
               2+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                xgz
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                Hopeful Skeptic
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/04/us-monsanto-wheat-gmo-idUSTRE6A34K220101104">
               http://www.reuters.com/...
              </a>
             </p>
             <p>
              I think you need to consider taking the diary down.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:111567">
               Roger Fox
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40522263#c495">
               Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:49:17 PM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c3">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522263">
           <li id="c547">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40523561">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               You keep saying that
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40523561#c547?mode=alone;showrate=1#c547">
                1+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:80060">
                 kurt
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               to divert attention from the information right there in paragraph 1 of the letter that the pathogen appears "more likely" to be associated with the presence of glyphosate than with the RR gene itself. Which exists in these GMOs simply to encourage the spraying of more glyphosate.
              </p>
              <p>
               Glyphosate is not used exclusively on RR cultivars. It's used on suburban lawns, regular croplands, for weed and invasive species control all over the country, etc. It's just used MORE on RR cultivars, because they can take it.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                Joieau
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40523561#c547">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 03:03:39 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c495">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40523561">
            <li id="c554">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40523885">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Roger points out a symptom
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40523885#c554?mode=alone;showrate=1#c554">
                 5+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                  mem from somerville
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                  yuriwho
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:70434">
                  Catesby
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                  KroneckerD
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                  cryonaut
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                ...not the whole problem.
               </p>
               <p>
                Let's set aside whether the letter's claims are believable (although they aren't). Let's just look at what the letter claims has been done. It says that there's been a lot of testing, a lot of lab time on an electron microscopy bench, a whole passel of comparative analysis, and at least two live animal studies.
               </p>
               <p>
                If that stuff didn't happen, then this letter is just a big sack of lies meant to poison the dialogue.
               </p>
               <p>
                If it did happen ... then where is any of it? Studies take money, and expect publication. Animal studies aren't instantaneous. Crops take seasons to grow. Where's the data?
               </p>
               <p>
                Roger's been hammering the wheat problem because it means that one of those animal studies -- the miscarriage population comparison -- is
                <em>
                 impossible
                </em>
                (note that this is not the only way you can reach this conclusion). Just from what is written in the letter, it says that the foodlot with high glyphosate exposure is wheat silage. But that doesn't make any sense. Glyphosate kills wheat. There's no glyphosate-resistant wheat. And that's ignoring the fact that the study, as described, isn't even close to adequately controlled; if it did exist, which it doesn't, it serves mostly to show that maybe you shouldn't feed wheat to cows (note: in the real world, cows do just fine eating wheat silage).
               </p>
               <p>
                The real way you'd do that study would be to have several cattle populations, all on the same base grain type, probably corn silage. You'd have one fed with non-GMO corn in a field with no history of glyphosate application. You'd have one with non-GMO corn in a field with pre-planting glyphosate field exposure. You'd have one with glyphosate-resistant corn, but without the actual herbicide. Your fourth group would be BMO corn with pre-planting field exposure (to match group 2). And your fifth group would be glyphosate-resistant corn that you spray the patooties out of during the season.
               </p>
               <p>
                That's not what the letter talks about. What the letter talks about is either "research" -- note the scare quotes -- that is utterly without merit, or total baldfaced fabrication.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                 Serpents Choice
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40523885#c554">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 03:23:30 PM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c547">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40523885">
             <li id="c635">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40526533">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Have you challenged
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40526533#c635?mode=alone;showrate=1#c635">
                  0+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 this researcher in any moderated/peer reviewed forum, or are you just engaged in the age old practice of character assassination?
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                  Joieau
                 </a>

              <li id="c641">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40526915">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Has this researcher
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40526915#c641?mode=alone;showrate=1#c641">
                   2+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">

                  </dt>

                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  challenged the people whose work he decries as being an immediate threat in any moderated/peer reviewed forum, or is he just engaged in the age old practice of character assassination?
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  That answer, for the record, is no.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  But, that said, the research team at Purdue released a response, objecting to many of the principle claims. You can
                  <a href="http://www.btny.purdue.edu/weedscience/2011/GlyphosatesImpact11.pdf.">
                   read it here
                  </a>
                  (pdf).
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  You may note some immediate differences between their work and his, starting with the fact that they know how to cite their sources.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                 </p>

          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509203">
           <li id="c200">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40511881">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               also as someone else pointed out...
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40511881#c200?mode=alone;showrate=1#c200">
                7+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                 mem from somerville
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                 chimpy
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                 murrayewv
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:70434">
                 Catesby
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                 xgz
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                 whl
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:187444">
                 FarWestGirl
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               .... the herd with the miscarriage rate of 0 is also a questionable report, since there is a consistent range of percentage of miscarriage that should be expected for a normal sample.
              </p>
              <p>
               I was also concerned about the author of the letter failing to identify the new organism by name or species, or if it's too new even to be named, providing any URLs, citations, or even a keyword-searchable way to look it up further.
              </p>
              <p>
               Yes, we all want to believe that a surprising new form of life has been discovered, just as we all want to believe that bacterial cells will be found on Mars or radio signals will be received from distant star systems. But something is needed to substantiate the claim.
              </p>
              <p>
               So at this point I'm inclined toward skepticism. Let's see the actual data to back up the claims, and if the data are any good, then we should halt distribution of the materials that are suspected of being causal while conducting further studies under controlled conditions.
              </p>
              <p>
               BTW, I'm intrigued by the use of rodent models for the miscarriage issue, but I don't think they'll be conclusive since there's a chance that the effects are specific to cattle for whatever reason. But in that case if the rodent studies turn up positive, then immediate policy action would be called for.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:44695">
                G2geek
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40511881#c200">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:36:34 AM PST
               </a>
              </p>

               <a href="#c58">

                 ekyprogressive
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                 Hopeful Skeptic
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               it woo-full, and she couches it with the Fox-newsy question mark strategy... Could it be???
              </p>
              <p>
               Clinging to crap like this is a dangerous strategy, and has a whiff of desperation. Sad really.

          <li id="c212">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40512824">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              totally agnostic re MEM
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40512824#c212?mode=alone;showrate=1#c212">
               10+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:3590">
                hester
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:38616">
                nswalls
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:80060">
                kurt
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:83832">
                OHdog
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:107938">
                TomP
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                lostboyjim
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                Hopeful Skeptic
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:202168">
                Crider
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                Ezekial 23 20
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                Joieau
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              i am not here to weigh in on MEM!! what is that all about anyways - talk about getting personal.
             </p>
             <p>
              I am a reproductive cell biologist tho.
             </p>
             <p>
              There are a variety of obvious and less than obvious confounding issues that can and do play a part in evaluating this personal communication from one scientist to another political appointee.
             </p>
             <p>
              I would like to interject that simplicity should be one's goal without out being excessively reductionist.
             </p>
             <p>
              There is no need to jump to assumptions that a novel organism is causing fetal lethality/teratogenicity - that has been seen associated with GMO animal fodder in the past.
             </p>
             <p>
              One must tease apart the impact of any particular unintentional GMO transgene gene products (poorly characterized in the first part) versus the impact of glyphosphate.
             </p>
             <p>
              Just as with the debacle with the NASA study on arsenic bacteria - if your going to say you have found a novel organism you absolutely have got to show me the genome. Dont talk to me about new organisms until then.
             </p>
             <p>
              I know the letter is meant to be private and is most certainly not peer-reviewed - the wording sounds quite odd.
             </p>
             <p>
              "electron microscopic organism" is not a term used in the art.
             </p>
             <p>
              So bottom line - there is AMPLE reason to put RR Alfalfa on hold/ban it, well outside of any claims of some novel terminator organism. I know that argument has had almost zero impact on Vilsac because he is doing as he is bid (and not what is right for the public good).
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              I blog, a lot: green -
              <a href="http://www.humblegarden.com" rel="nofollow">
               Humble Garden
              </a>
              and black -
              <a href="http://www.peaknix.com" rel="nofollow">
               peaknix - living the peak
              </a>
              .
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:35876">
               nika7k
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40512824#c212">
               Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:39:48 AM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">

              <a href="#c40">

             </p>
            </div>

             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Ok
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">

               </a>

               </a>

            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              where's the primary data? Let's have a look. And what are the controls?
             </p>
             <p>
              We'll start there.
             </p>
             <p>
              Now, tell me the components of the "wheatlege" please.
             </p>
             <p>
              And next, this new organism: let's see some sequence data. Nobody uses EM, which is an absurd way to claim to have found some new organism.
             </p>
             <p>
              This is patently ridiculous.
             </p>
             <p>
              But let's also note this: every single laboratory animal in the US has been fed GMOs since we started using them. Have you heard of giant problems in breeding biomedical research animals since the late 1990s?
             </p>
             <p>
              Nope.
             </p>
             <p>
              How many companion animals are eating organic food? Are pets having disastrous reproduction consequences?
             </p>
             <p>
              Nope.
             </p>
             <p>
              Use your brains people. Don't fall for stuff that you want to be true because it supports your point of view.
             </p>

           <div class="cx" id="cx40514567">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Really?
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40514567#c263?mode=alone;showrate=1#c263">
               5+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                chimpy
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:34482">
                churchylafemme
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:127703">

               </a>

               <a href="/user/uid:201617">

               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                Joieau
               </a>

            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Because I've studied the sciences for decades, been granted 'of science' degrees at the bachelors, masters, and doctoral levels for work produced in 'hard sciences' (not honorary, and not from a diploma mill), and from what I see, mem has always been a bit more dogmatic than open to additional studies.
             </p>
             <p>
              In the science departments I've been a part of, both regular and 'applied', most scientists have been open to continued studies that examine aspects and facets of systems that haven't been addressed. They haven't gone around declaring 'case closed'. That's been the attitude of people whose economic interests aligned with keeping things the way they are.
              <br/>
             </p>

           <li id="c426">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40520177">
             <h5>

               Huh.  That may be the strangest
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40520177#c426?mode=alone;showrate=1#c426">
                3+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:70434">
                 Catesby
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                 KroneckerD
                </a>

                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               and most circular statement of credentials I've seen on here.
              </p>
              <p>
               You may have specific examples in mind, but what I typically see mem doing is challenging 1. people who draw conclusions when there is little or no evidence, 2. people who weight their opinions on poor or debunked studies, and 3. people who persist in a belief despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary. If you have a problem with any of those three, then I'd question the value of your "'of science' degrees at the bachelors, masters, and doctoral levels for work produced in 'hard sciences'". I mean, this is just basic stuff.
              </p>
              <p>

              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               Saint, n. A dead sinner revised and edited. - Ambrose Bierce
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:65678">
                pico
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40520177#c426">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 12:05:16 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c263">

               </a>

              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <li id="c480">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40521958">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Many things could cause high miscarriage rate
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40521958#c480?mode=alone;showrate=1#c480">
                2+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:80060">
                 kurt
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                 Ezekial 23 20
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Some of them may even have plausible correlation with use of Roundup and/or Roundup-ready crops. First, I expect a high correlation between results from Roundup-ready GM crops, and other crops on which Roundup has been used. Why else would someone plant Roundup-ready soy, unless he planned to use Roundup at some point?
              </p>
              <p>
               Second, with the stress of weed competition removed, a plant can sustain higher levels of other stresses, such as virus &amp; fungus. This is partly because of the reduced selection pressure, with weaker stock surviving where naturally resistant strains would have otherwise been selected. And, also partly because of the individual results of infected plants continuing to thrive, along with their pathogens, up until harvest.
              </p>
              <p>
               Third, plants growing faster, without weed competition, produce tissue of different density and strength than those growing slowly. Plants without weed competition may experience drier, wetter or shadier emergence conditions, or may continue fast, Spring-like growth longer into the season. So, even plants of identical genetic makeup will be more or less supportive of viral and fungus populations, depending on the rate at which they grow.
              </p>
              <p>
               Finally, farms that adopted the heavy use of roundup first, may produce less suitable feed for a number of reasons not directly related to this year's application of Roundup. It may have more established viral and fungal infections, because they've had the selective pressure of weeds removed for more seasons. And, the heavy use of herbicide may correlate with other practices that degrade the quality of the final product.
              </p>
              <p>
               So, as valuable as the questions are, I wouldn't count anything in this letter as an answer.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               Why is there a
               <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                Confederate Flag
               </a>
               flying in Afghanistan?
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                chimpy
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40521958#c480">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:34:52 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>

               ]
              </p>
             </div>

           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40521958">
            <li id="c556">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40523938">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I did not see
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40523938#c556?mode=alone;showrate=1#c556">
                 2+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                  chimpy
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:34482">
                  churchylafemme
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                that the letter offered any answer or was intended to offer any answer. It informed Vilsack of an issue that showed up so strongly in preliminary research that the prudent thing is to delay release of more RR cultivars until further research provides some answers.
               </p>
               <p>
                The strong evidence that
                <i>
                 something
                </i>
                is causing miscarriage clusters deserves further investigation. And ANY apparent connection with glyphosate or RR cultivars is reason enough to shelve new cultivars until more is known.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                 Joieau
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40523938#c556">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 03:26:27 PM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c480">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40523938">
             <li id="c571">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40524390">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Yes, that's how I read the intent
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40524390#c571?mode=alone;showrate=1#c571">
                  1+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 The intent of the letter appears to be to justify further study. More in the vein of a feeler in preparation for a grant proposal, than a preview of results. It presents a factual situation: a positive correlation between an undesirable outcome and a commonly-used product. In most situations, this would by itself justify more study.
                </p>
                <p>
                 But, the sub-claims made to support the needed study seem unnecessarily broad. No new class of organism need be involved, and any introduction of new theories only opens the original intent to more criticism. It is a sad situation where such extraordinary efforts must be made to justify a study, when the only argument against study would be its risk to an industry's profits.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 Why is there a
                 <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                  Confederate Flag
                 </a>
                 flying in Afghanistan?
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                  chimpy
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40524390#c571">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 03:55:42 PM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c556">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524390">
              <li id="c637">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40526636">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  I am fairly confident
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40526636#c637?mode=alone;showrate=1#c637">
                   2+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                    chimpy
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:34482">
                    churchylafemme
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  that this eminent researcher didn't propose a new class of pathogen lightly. He has evidence something very serious is going on (450 miscarriages out of 1000 pregnant cows is very significant - to the tune of roughly half). He has some odd close-up test results (micro and sub-micro) that look suspicious. He's asking for more time, before yet another crop - this one ubiquitous and valuable in animal husbandry as alfalfa - is approved for general release.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I see that as entirely reasonable.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40526636#c637">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:21:46 PM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c571">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40526636">
               <li id="c712">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40536792">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Again, I agree with the letter's intent
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40536792#c712?mode=alone;showrate=1#c712">
                    0+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   Which is to investigate the causes of various correlations. There may be flawed experiments, parallel causes, or (in the case of those 450 miscarriages) a serious illnesses that was coincidentally uncovered by a feed study. All things worthy of review and probably individual investigations into those individual experiments. And, if several of those correlations point, even tentatively, to a commonly used product, then a broader investigation is probably also warranted.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   But, I see no need to jump to the conclusion of a new class of life form to push the issue. Maybe the politics are such that he can't get an issue noticed without such extraordinary claims, but then the problem is with the politics, not the science. Leaking preliminary findings, or suggestions as to expected findings, is hardly ever helpful.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   Why is there a
                   <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                    Confederate Flag
                   </a>
                   flying in Afghanistan?
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                    chimpy
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40536792#c712">
                    Sat Feb 26, 2011 at 12:33:26 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c637">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
              </ul>
             </ul>
            </ul>
           </ul>
          </ul>
         </ul>
         <li id="c216">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40512979">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Well....
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40512979#c216?mode=alone;showrate=1#c216">
              6+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>

             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:3388">

              </a>

              <a href="/user/uid:36845">

              </a>

              <a href="/user/uid:183265">

              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             given how laughable many of the claims in the letter are, I might hold off bashing those of us who are scientists until you are on a little more solid footing.
            </p>
            <p>
             But that's just me.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             ....no longer in SF.... -9.00, -7.38
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:160276">
              TFinSF
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40512979#c216">

            </p>
            <p class="cl">
