           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40512979">
          <li id="c265">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40514603">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Those of us who are scientists?
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40514603#c265?mode=alone;showrate=1#c265">
               3+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:182596">
                afisher
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:201617">
                Tyto Alba
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                Joieau
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              I've got multiple undergrad and grad degrees in science. I don't bash 'scientists'. I 'bash' people who go around proclaiming that we don't need more studies because what we've got is 'good enough'.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
               Help Aji!
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:210303">
               Ezekial 23 20
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40514603#c265">
               Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 07:24:33 AM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c216">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40514603">
           <li id="c285">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40515695">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               100 % correct!
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40515695#c285?mode=alone;showrate=1#c285">
                0+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               People who don't want to recognize a potential problem / threat are the same folks who will ignore it, until it affects them. Then they will scream that the gov't failed to protect them.
              </p>
              <p>
               I don't know anything about the new microbe or how long it will take to move up the food chain, but I don't doubt that it will move up.
              </p>
              <p>
               I can hear speaker Orange: just not now!
              </p>
              <p>
               But hey, I'm old, so it really won't affect me, so let me bury my head in the sand and to hell with future generations, as THIS will be their problem.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:182596">
                afisher
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40515695#c285">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 08:19:25 AM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c265">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40515695">
            <li id="c293">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40516273">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I don't know that there even is a new microbe.
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40516273#c293?mode=alone;showrate=1#c293">
                 3+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:4498">
                  laurak
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                  chimpy
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:34482">
                  churchylafemme
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                But the scientific response to the suggestion is to A) ask for the data that suggests it to review, and B) try and design other independent studies to prove or disprove the allegations.
               </p>
               <p>
                Ag isn't my field - I spent my time doing geology and later human biology. But I also have a masters in systems analysis, which gives me a more wider view of dealing with any field. People who train to high levels in one specific field will often focus in their very specific knowledge fields and dismiss the possibilities that they could be missing something important 'off to the side'.
               </p>
               <p>
                Is this bogus? Could be, could be. But another study or two should very quickly either give added credence to the idea that there is a connection or show the supposed connection to be merely an artifact of the methods used in whatever the first study was. And maybe there is a connection, but it has nothing to do with the claims being put forward. Again, attacking the notion from a different angle will give a better notion of whether or not there is anything useful here.
               </p>
               <p>
                Before plate tectonics started having multiple studies pile up to support it, the eminent geologists of their day were equally certain that it was all a bunch of nonsense. Those with more arrogance than scientific curiosity merely pooh-poohed the notion, while those who actually wanted to find out whether or not such an outlandish notion could possibly be realistic, merely went out and ... did science.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
                 Help Aji!
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                 Ezekial 23 20
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40516273#c293">

                </a>
               </p>

                <a href="#c285">

             <a href="/user/uid:106504">

           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            testing. The burden of proof should also be in the hands of the people producing these materials for profit. They should have to conduct long term tests to prove they are healthy. Instead, the burden of proof is on underfunded scientists and non profit groups to establish a direct link to the harm they may be causing. How backwards is that?
           </p>
          </div>

              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:127703">
               Karl Rover
              </a>

              <a href="/user/uid:136604">
               207wickedgood
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:154707">
               Dragon5616
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:171802">
               Anne was here
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:184001">
               vahana
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:205862">
               JayinPortland
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:224245">
               Prairie D
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:233619">
               Miep
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:235212">
               Joieau
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Additionally, if our antitrust laws were enforced, the biotech companies would be busted pretty quickly. I've heard pretty disgusted farmers talking about their tactics in getting the farmers to all adopt GMOs. For example, they take the best yielding conventional seed, add a GM trait or two, and ONLY sell it as a GMO. That happened to a farmer I know who refuses to plant GMOs. So he lost access to the best yielding seeds - unless he was willing to plant GMOs.
            </p>
            <p>
             Because, aside from making sure GMOs are safe, there's also the question of: Are they the best way to solve our agricultural problems? And from what I've seen, it looks like the answer is no. But if you have fair competition, I wouldn't object to having the safety testing done (both for human and animal health AND environmental harm) and then putting them on the market and letting farmers choose. But the market is so distorted, not only by the lack of competition but also by all of the farm policies we have. I interviewed a woman in Iowa this week who wants to grow something other than corn and soy on her land and she's having FITS doing so because of ag laws as well as a total lack of infrastructure in Iowa for anything other than corn, soy, and factory farmed hogs.
            </p>
           </div>

            <li id="c28">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40508455">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Microfungi are what I consider normal fungi
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40508455#c28?mode=alone;showrate=1#c28">
                 11+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:3388">

                 </a>

                 </a>

                 </a>

                 <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                  cryonaut
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                as opposed to macrofungi such as mushrooms etc. Viruses are so small because they only have a protein shell and nucleic acids. They are not considered living because they cannot grow or reproduce on their own. That's because they thousands of times smaller than the smallest of cells.
               </p>
              </div>

                   mike101
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:52737">
                   ChemBob
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:80060">
                   kurt
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                   whl
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                   KroneckerD
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:215586">
                   erush1345
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                   Margd
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                   cryonaut
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 Fungi are usually a few microns in size, his letter implies the size around 100 nm which would be impossible for any 'normal' cell. It would indeed be a major discovery if real. But it's so vague that it could mean almost anything. It's highly unusual to announce a major discovery like that in a letter to USDA.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                </p>

              <li id="c569">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40524375">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Prions as pathogens
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40524375#c569?mode=alone;showrate=1#c569">
                   1+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:131391">
                    ekyprogressive

                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  was a rather revolutionary idea too. And yeah, it got a Nobel.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>

                  <a href="/comments/949492/40524375#c569">

                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524375">
               <li id="c584">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40524715">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Not AS revolutionary...
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40524715#c584?mode=alone;showrate=1#c584">
                    1+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:117053">
                     FG
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   ...as it tends to get played, but yeah. There was pretty good evidence that the causal agent of scrapie was smaller than a virus, all the way back to 1967. The problem was that no one could come up with a causal mechanism.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   It took a better understanding of protein folding to realize that catalyzed isoform conversion was the actual pathogenesis. That's what got the Nobel, although it's still a field with a lot of room for discovery. Protein folding is not ... exactly a complete field yet.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Not that the existence of prions changes the letter's "electron microscopic ... micro-fungal-like organism" into anything plausible. Those are still woo.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                    Serpents Choice
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40524715#c584">
                    Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:16:46 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c569">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524715">
                <li id="c602">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40525251">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Two Nobel prizes, in fact. 1976 one was for
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40525251#c602?mode=alone;showrate=1#c602">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    kuru which is another prion disease. And the final pieces of puzzle providing proof of the prion hypothesis have been discovered only in the last few years (last year, in fact).
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:117053">

                       FG

                   </div>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     Although Gajdusek wasn't able to identify the causal agent in kuru, he did conclude that it was of the same nature as whatever caused scrapie. So, ironically, prions earned a Nobel even before their description.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Gajdusek is also proof that even really, really good scientists can come up with ideas that are not acceptable.
                    </p>

              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Have you considered the Letter is fake?
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40528909#c684?mode=alone;showrate=1#c684">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                I emailed DR Huber at about 3pm Friday afternoon. He has not responded.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                 Roger Fox
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40528909#c684">

           </ul>
           <li id="c593">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40525004">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Speculation about new pathogen is irrelevant
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40525004#c593?mode=alone;showrate=1#c593">
                0+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               What is important is that a correlation has been found: animal feed that increases miscarriage rate would, even in the best case, be less valuable than more proven strains of feed. At worst, it's a danger to those working on the farm and to those who consume its produce.
              </p>
              <p>
               No speculation needs to be made as to new classes of organisms. I am dismayed by the fact that a scientist can't get an important correlation noticed without forwarding un-reviewed speculation (the scientific equivalent of taking his pants off and dancing lewdly in front of a cop).
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               Why is there a
               <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                Confederate Flag
               </a>
               flying in Afghanistan?
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                chimpy
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40525004#c593">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:35:22 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c16">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525004">
            <li id="c613">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40525570">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I don't think it has
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40525570#c613?mode=alone;showrate=1#c613">
                 2+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                  chimpy
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:76550">
                  dirtfarmer
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <blockquote>
                What is important is that a correlation has been found: animal feed that increases miscarriage rate would, even in the best case, be less valuable than more proven strains of feed.
               </blockquote>
               <p>
                No, this one guy in a really cranktastic letter says he's found that correlation. But GMO crop silage has been being used as cattle feed for several years now, and I've spent all day trying to find any evidence that there has been an increase in miscarriage rate.
               </p>
               <p>
                After all, that's the sort of thing that, if it was really happening, would be impossible to hide. It would make news in the zillion publications for the farming industry, on the huge array of farm-oriented TV and radio programs and in agribusiness journals. If nothing else, there would be a flurry of testing for brucellosis (aka "abortive fever").
               </p>
               <p>
                I found ... nothing to indicate that's been the case.
               </p>
               <p>
                So, no, no correlation has been found, because you cannot have a correlation to something that isn't happening. Really, I don't think any of the studies implied by that letter have been done at all. In particular, that bit about induced abortions in a laboratory setting would have the lab's ethics panel crapping itself, since there's no prior research to demonstrate the need for it.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                 Serpents Choice
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40525570#c613">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:11:08 PM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c593">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525570">
             <li id="c618">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40525957">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Hard to tell from letter
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40525957#c618?mode=alone;showrate=1#c618">
                  0+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 The letter's author's involvement appears to begin at the search for a cause. If I read it correctly (reading this thing does take some work), his lab was involved in finding the cause of such a high correlation. The study that produced it was done elsewhere, and before his organization's involvement.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Nobody would begin a trial that expected a 45% occurrence of miscarriage, so the context would appear to be that someone got this alarming result, and called everyone they knew to help find a cause. The fact that one of those people he called went off the deep end and pre-released claims of a new class of life doesn't make the original outcome less alarming.
                </p>
                <p>
                 If the author of this is still employed, I have to assume there were citations attached to this letter, which the leak did not forward. We will have to wait for any pre-publication citations to work their way through the system before we can take anything else from this.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 Why is there a
                 <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                  Confederate Flag
                 </a>
                 flying in Afghanistan?
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                  chimpy
                 </a>

          <li id="c39">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40508616">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              They should be testing more than just
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40508616#c39?mode=alone;showrate=1#c39">
               4+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:31383">
                mrkvica
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:34482">
                churchylafemme
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:48263">
                caul
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:76550">
                dirtfarmer
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              toxicity.
             </p>
             <p>
              When introducing new products sold in large quantities with very little known data, there should be something more to it than just toxicity.
             </p>
             <p>
              I am not even suggesting that they shouldn't go ahead and sell the products, but they should have to track them and collect long term data on their effect to people's health and the environment.
             </p>
             <p>
              Especially when we are talking about Monsanto, the company that told us that PCBs and Agent Orange (also their products) were not dangerous.
             </p>
            </div>

           <li id="c42">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40508730">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               This is usually done although more often for
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40508730#c42?mode=alone;showrate=1#c42">
                2+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>

             <div class="crs">

                <a href="/user/uid:48263">

               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               drugs. It's separate from product testing before its release. I have no idea how careful was Monsanto with testing this product but standards for drug trials are much stricter than those for pesticides.
              </p>
              <p>
               <a href="http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=epas-new-pesticide-testing-outdated">
                http://www.scientificamerican.com/...

         <li id="c485">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40522062">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I think this diary is a valuable illustration
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40522062#c485?mode=alone;showrate=1#c485">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:235212">
               Joieau
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             No, it doesn't prove anything. Nor does it really demonstrate anything convincing about the biology or chemistry involved.
            </p>
            <p>
             What it does is it demonstrates the asymmetry of the fight between commerce and safety. The letter, the diary, and the comments all show that our regulators cooperate easily with those who bring new chemicals and organisms into the marketplace, but react slowly when asked to investigate questions of safety.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Why is there a
             <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
              Confederate Flag
             </a>
             flying in Afghanistan?
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:24632">
              chimpy
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40522062#c485">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:40:02 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c5">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522062">
          <li id="c500">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40522358">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              It does not
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40522358#c500?mode=alone;showrate=1#c500">
               3+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                mem from somerville
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                Hopeful Skeptic
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                cryonaut
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              This is not a
              <em>
               credible
              </em>
              question of safety. I do not want my government regulatory agency to react quickly when it gets a badly-spelled, unprofessionally-worded paper warning of an upcoming disaster caused an organism no one else has seen, citing no published research papers or the opinions or input of any additional scientists (and, no, the mystery "team" in the first sentence doesn't count), no matter who sends it.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:87455">
               Serpents Choice
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40522358#c500">
               Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:53:54 PM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c485">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522358">
           <li id="c507">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40522639">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               The asymmetry is still there
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40522639#c507?mode=alone;showrate=1#c507">
                0+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               On one side, a convincing claim regarding safety needs to be made, just to cause an investigation. On the other, money and advertising pushes a product into use on the expectation of better yield.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               Why is there a
               <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                Confederate Flag
               </a>
               flying in Afghanistan?
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                chimpy
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40522639#c507">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 02:09:00 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c500">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522639">
            <li id="c518">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40522816">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Still no
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40522816#c518?mode=alone;showrate=1#c518">
                 3+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                  mem from somerville
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                  Hopeful Skeptic
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                  cryonaut
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                Legitimate investigations into safety have already been done. There are hundreds -- it might be thousands at this point -- of papers on GMO agriculture. It is absolutely true that a convincing claim would need to be raised before any sort of massive investigation into safety would be a defensible use of money.
               </p>
               <p>
                And lest you think I'm shilling, I'm not exactly what you'd consider a Monsanto supporter. I think much of their business model is reprehensible. And I think glyphosate-resistant GMO crops are not ideal because they lead to a sort of monoculture of herbicide use, which has and will select for glyphosate-resistant weeds. We'd be better off developing three or four viable control chemicals and encouraging their use in rotation to prevent resistance.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                 Serpents Choice
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40522816#c518">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 02:19:02 PM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c507">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522816">
             <li id="c583">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40524708">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 But, all the power is in Monsanto's hands
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40524708#c583?mode=alone;showrate=1#c583">
                  0+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 Yes, it would be interesting to try a collection of measures that could be rotated, but we a the public are not in a position to do that. It's in Monsanto's interest to play one chemical for as long as they can, and if they're lucky the patents will stay valid for as long as the chemical stays effective.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Only large chemical or other Ag companies would have the money to fund the research. And, in most cases, as the funder of safety &amp; efficacy studies, they have the power to suppress results that don't help their market prospects.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 Why is there a
                 <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                  Confederate Flag
                 </a>
                 flying in Afghanistan?
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                  chimpy
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40524708#c583">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:16:28 PM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c518">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524708">
              <li id="c589">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40524841">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Not exactly
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40524841#c589?mode=alone;showrate=1#c589">
                   1+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                    chimpy
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  I know it's fun to dig on Monsanto, and I really don't like them either. But facts are facts, and I have to play fair even to the side I don't like...
                 </p>
                 <blockquote>
                  ...if they're lucky the patents will stay valid...
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  The patent on glyphosate expired in 2000.
                 </p>
                 <blockquote>
                  And, in most cases, as the funder of safety &amp; efficacy studies, they have the power to suppress results that don't help their market prospects.
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  While throwing a lot of money at your side of the story works remarkably well, there's so much attention paid to Monsanto products, that I think you'd be surprised at how hard it would be for them to actually bury bad news at this point. After the scandals with IBT and Craven Labs (aside: who the hell names your company that?), their work goes through quite a few fine-toothed combs.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                   Serpents Choice
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40524841#c589">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:24:56 PM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c583">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524841">
               <li id="c614">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40525616">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   RR Soy is patented through 2014
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40525616#c614?mode=alone;showrate=1#c614">
                    0+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   Others longer. The original chemical is now off-patent, but the variety patents are still in force. Once RR soy goes off patent, RR2 soy will then be marketed in its place.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   And, for all the attention paid to policing Monsanto in particular, and the labs who were friendly to it, this is attention and energy that doesn't get used for something positive.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   Why is there a
                   <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                    Confederate Flag
                   </a>
                   flying in Afghanistan?
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                    chimpy
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40525616#c614">
                    Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:14:02 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c589">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525616">
                <li id="c616">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40525783">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Something positive
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40525783#c616?mode=alone;showrate=1#c616">
                     1+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                      chimpy
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    I'm not going to be baited into an outright defense of Monsanto's business practices, because I don't consider them defensible. Likewise, I don't think the patent system ought to apply to genomics developments, although I understand that we need
                    <em>
                     some
                    </em>
                    sort of system to protect the development rights of the corporations who invest in the initial research; as with just about everything intellectual property related, our law is way, way,
                    <strong>
                     way
                    </strong>
                    behind where it needs to be.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    But the goal of all of this is to improve the size and consistency of crop yields. I'm hard pressed to argue that, end of the day, that's not a positive goal to strive for.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                     Serpents Choice
                    </a>
                    on
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40525783#c616">
                     Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:24:02 PM PST
                    </a>
                   </p>
                   <p class="cl">
                    [
                    <a href="#c614">
                     Parent
                    </a>
                    ]
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525783">
                 <li id="c626">
                  <div class="cx" id="cx40526276">
                   <h5>
                    <a class="de">
                    </a>
                    <span class="cu">
                     "Something positive"
                    </span>
                    <span class="crd ntb">
                     (
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40526276#c626?mode=alone;showrate=1#c626">
                      0+ / 0-
                     </a>
                     )
                    </span>
                   </h5>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     ... as in developing new methods or products, instead of having to police Monsanto's dubious business practices.
                    </p>
                   </div>
                   <div class="cf">
                    <p class="sig">
                     Why is there a
                     <a href="http://www.axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/article_17829.shtml" rel="nofollow">
                      Confederate Flag
                     </a>
                     flying in Afghanistan?
                    </p>
                    <p class="cb">
                     by
                     <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                      chimpy
                     </a>
                     on
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40526276#c626">
                      Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:57:07 PM PST
                     </a>
                    </p>
                    <p class="cl">
                     [
                     <a href="#c616">
                      Parent
                     </a>
                     ]
                    </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </li>
                 <ul class="cm i1" id="k40526276">
                  <li id="c643">
                   <div class="cx" id="cx40527031">
                    <h5>
                     <a class="de">
                     </a>
                     <span class="cu">
                      Well, sure
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">
                      (
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40527031#c643?mode=alone;showrate=1#c643">
                       2+ / 0-
                      </a>
                      )
                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="crs">
                     <dl>
                      <dt>
                       Recommended by:
                      </dt>
                      <dd>
                       <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                        mem from somerville
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                        chimpy
                       </a>
                      </dd>
                     </dl>
                    </div>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      I'd love to see Congress do something about the mess than is gene patents. They're ridiculous, and Monsanto uses them as a bully stick.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      I'd love to see more competition in the GMO field, too. Genentech pioneered the industry, but they're mostly off in oncology research these days. If the SymBioSys insulin-producing safflower trial doesn't hit any bumps in PIII and gets approval, that's huge for them.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      It's so hard to encourage companies to look to the field, though, because public opinion is so polarized. I blame Monsanto for a lot of that, too, because they've just been such an intolerably crappy corporate neighbor, good intentions or otherwise.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      There's a lot of real, honest good that can come of this field. Or, if you feel this thread is too serious and would prefer some whimsy ... genetic engineering gets you
                      <a href="http://www.google.com/images?client=firefox-a&amp;rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&amp;channel=s&amp;hl=en&amp;q=GloFish&amp;um=1&amp;ie=UTF-8&amp;source=univ&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=BGpoTZjvKYb2swPq6MSmBA&amp;ved=0CFIQsAQ&amp;biw=1626&amp;bih=804">
                       glowing fish
                      </a>
                      , too!
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Fair disclosure: I am a former owner of a GloFish.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                    <div class="cf">
                     <p class="sig">
                      "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                     </p>
                     <p class="cb">
                      by
                      <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                       Serpents Choice
                      </a>
                      on
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40527031#c643">
                       Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:51:02 PM PST
                      </a>
                     </p>
                     <p class="cl">

                      <a href="#c626">

               </ul>

        <li id="c9">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40508021">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            When Monsanto was first
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40508021#c9?mode=alone;showrate=1#c9">
             21+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:4498">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:79924">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:80000">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:92246">
              Margfh
             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:100012">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:114668">
              OleHippieChick
             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:135160">
              forgore
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:136604">
              207wickedgood
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:157580">
              Amber6541
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:201617">
              Tyto Alba
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:205862">
              JayinPortland
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:235212">
              Joieau
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:239271">
              drnononono
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            marketing RoundUp, in the late '90s, one of their PR flaks was on NPR and being asked about what it would do. The response (and I wrote it down at the time so I wouldn't ever forget it:
           </p>
           <blockquote>
            RoundUp will kill anything green and growing.
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            Scientific studies can do lots of things, and prove or disprove lots of things depending on how they are structured and what the desired end results are.
           </p>
           <p>
            The idea that you can tinker with the genetic makeup of seeds -- whether with RoundUp or GMOs -- and not cause unlooked-for changes down the line is simply stupid. Or agribusiness.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            It is only by not paying one's bills that one can hope to live in the memory of the commercial classes. -- Oscar Wilde
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:13718">
             Mnemosyne
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40508021#c9">
             Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 07:11:50 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40508021">
         <li id="c358">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40518231">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Glyphosate was developed in the 1970s
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40518231#c358?mode=alone;showrate=1#c358">
              3+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:48175">
               yuriwho
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:80060">
               kurt
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:111567">
               Roger Fox
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Marketed as Roundup since 1973, the product has been used at levels of application which are astounding. Farmers, gardeners &amp; governments use Roundup to kill vegetation, especially weeds
            </p>
            <p>
             The patents have expired but the trademark name is still registered.
            </p>
            <p>
             In the opinions of countless farmers, Roundup has been so extensively used in the USA for so long that somebody would have noticed if it was killing, maiming, or harming large numbers of people, ag critters, or wild animals.
            </p>
            <p>
             There are some studies showing that it may harm fish in shallow water. But it's not supposed to be used in those applications. There are some studies showing that it may persist in some soils in some places, although it generally goes away in a few days to a few weeks, depending on the location.
            </p>
            <p>
             Some weeds have developed resistance to glyphosate.
            </p>
            <p>
             Most toxicology studies on the product are neutral or seem related to other compounds in the actual brand formulation of the glyphosate----i.e., a surfactant in the mix causes liver damage or an aromatic ingredient caused damage to human placenta. There was no explanation as to how the perfume could get into a human placenta.
            </p>
            <p>
             In one experiment, rats suffered major endocrine damage to the reproductive system during puberty. One wag commented that farmers &amp; gardeners will cease injecting Roundup into teen-aged rats.
            </p>
            <p>
             Ta-da.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             snafu = 3 fubar &amp; 1 wtf
            </p>

             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:199857">
               enhydra lutris

          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40508786">
           <li id="c261">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40514536">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               In what way?
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40514536#c261?mode=alone;showrate=1#c261">
                2+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                 xgz
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                 Margd
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Extraordinary claims require extraordinary proof.
              </p>
              <p>
               The scientific method is the antidote to the human tendency to believe certain things to be true on the basis of emotionally driven intuition.
              </p>
              <p>
               I don't trust Monsanto, and I think any genetically modified plant or animal that could even remotely affect the ecosystem or the human food chain should have its ass tested off.
              </p>
              <p>
               I also believe that this testing should be also conducted by third parties who have no stake in the results.
              </p>
              <p>
               But I also believe that we should not jump to conclusions like this, simply because they confirm our suspicions of a certain group of people. Down that road lies the insanity of politically determined opinions about the natural world.
              </p>
              <p>
               We need to observe checks on our own ideas and ideology, not just insist on them for others.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               The Republicans: Let's kill jobs and cut deficits until the economy recovers. The Democrats: Let's create jobs and boost the economy until it can help us resolve the deficit. Who needs to win the next election?
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:139599">
                Stephen Daugherty
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40514536#c261">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 07:21:00 AM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c44">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40514536">
            <li id="c325">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40517336">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Every time somebody says that some statement
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40517336#c325?mode=alone;showrate=1#c325">
                 3+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:4498">
                  laurak
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:201617">
                  Tyto Alba
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                  Joieau
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                makes it clear that the author knows nothing about science makes me think that the utterer of that statement knows nothing of science. Science is not a body of dogma, but but a methodology for continuou8sly refining our models of "reality".
               </p>
               <p>
                As I told somebody else:
                <br/>
               </p>
               <blockquote>
                When I hear scientifically impossible, I always
                <br/>
                think of Xenon Tetraflouride (scientifically impossible, like all similar coumpounds until the sixties), the sun (scientifically impossible until maybe the seventies), hovering and retrograde flight for certain insects and humingbirds (scientifically impossible for the longest time), etc. etc
               </blockquote>
               .
               <blockquote>
                But I also believe that we should not jump to conclusions like this, simply because they confirm our suspicions of a certain group of people. Down that road lies the insanity of politically determined opinions about the natural world.
               </blockquote>
               <p>
                Which is exactly what those claiming that this should be dismissed outright without consideration were doing. The author of the letter was suggesting that permitting be held in abeyance while further research was performed. Nobody was suggesting that the work done to date was conclusive. Rejecting further research on something that is not really at all settled is seldom a good idea.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                That, in its essence, is fascism--ownership of government by an individual, by a group, or by any other controlling private power.
  -- Franklin D. Roosevelt --
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:199857">
                 enhydra lutris
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40517336#c325">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:42:15 AM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c261">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40517336">
             <li id="c645">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40527055">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 The potential of Paradigm shift...
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40527055#c645?mode=alone;showrate=1#c645">
                  4+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                   mem from somerville
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                   yuriwho
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                   Serpents Choice
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                   KroneckerD
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 does not magically give any unproven hypothesis credibility, much less provide it the substance necessary to justify making policy from it.
                </p>
                <p>
                 This is the same argument that the Global Warming "Skeptics" use: this theory doesn't explain everything, so we can claim that our theory would supersede it given half a chance.
                </p>
                <p>
                 No, it doesn't work that way, not with good science. You have to prove something's there.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Let's take astrophysics for example. The Sun wasn't scientifically impossible. If you can observe something, it isn't impossible. There is this bright ball of whatever the hell it is up in the sky. The trick is in explaining it.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Well, what is it made of? Well, folks figured out it was made of hydrogen and helium by analyzing its spectrum. Then the question was, what allowed it to shine. It was getting energy, where was it getting it from? Like volcanoes on Io, the phenomena was self-evident, not the explanation for it.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Einstein's equations, which equated energy and matter, probably indicated a certain path. The question then became just what was happening on an atomic, then subatomic level.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Each improvement in the theory built on another, and each had to be proven correct, or reasonably correct, in order to proceed.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Let's look at that Xenon Tetraflouride. Why was that supposed to be scientifically impossible?
                 <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenon">
                  Let's ask wikipedia:
                 </a>
                </p>
                <blockquote>
                 Xenon is a member of the zero-valence elements that are called noble or inert gases. It is inert to most common chemical reactions (such as combustion, for example) because the outer valence shell contains eight electrons. This produces a stable, minimum energy configuration in which the outer electrons are tightly bound.[44]
                </blockquote>
                <p>
                 The article talks about the requirement for very powerful oxidizers in order to carry out the reactions necessary. Folks just got used to thinking that those chemicals didn't react. It wasn't Xenon Tetraflouride that proved them wrong, though, it was
                 <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenon_hexafluoroplatinate">
                  Xenon Hexaflouroplatinate.
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p>
                 The issue in creating such compounds is that closed up electron shell. If you remember your basic chemistry, Noble Gases like Xenon have full electron orbitals. The reason that Xenon and other heavier Noble Gases seem to be able to do this, according to the articles, probably relates to their larger size, and the vulnerability of some of their electron shells to ionization.
                </p>
                <p>
                 And really, though somebody predicted it could happen, it had to happen in order to be taken seriously.
                </p>
                <p>
                 In the case of your other examples, well, the theories of aerodynamics might say it was impossible, but duh, sure enough, there were the films and videos of it. So, they had to rethink aerodynamics, reconsider it in that light.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Notice a pattern? People changed their mind about what was impossible based on what was observed.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Now until this organism is actually observed, until somebody can, in a reproduceable way, actually isolate this organism, there is absolutely no freaking point at all to changing the status of this genetic strain, much less policy overall. When you chase fears you can't or won't prove around, instead of relying on the hard evidence, you set yourself up to fail in many ways.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Sure, let's see whether this critter actually exists. In the meantime, policy should assume it doesn't. We shouldn't chase ghosts in the machine of debate, like too many did on the vaccine controversy.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 The Republicans: Let's kill jobs and cut deficits until the economy recovers. The Democrats: Let's create jobs and boost the economy until it can help us resolve the deficit. Who needs to win the next election?
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:139599">
                  Stephen Daugherty
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40527055#c645">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:52:46 PM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c325">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </ul>

           <div class="cf">

            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:168506">
              ban48
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40508602#c37">
              Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 07:47:50 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c10">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40508602">
          <li id="c159">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40510837">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">

         <li id="c483">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40522000">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             new organism unknown to science
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40522000#c483?mode=alone;showrate=1#c483">
              8+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:7787">
               mem from somerville
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:87455">
               Serpents Choice
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:88255">
               xgz
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:131391">
               ekyprogressive
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:159657">
               KroneckerD
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:183265">
               Hopeful Skeptic
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:197542">
               docmidwest
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:298633">
               cryonaut
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I'll weigh in as an molecular evolutionary biologist:
            </p>
            <p>
             That's a huge extraordinary claim!
             <br/>
             ""a new organism unknown to science that is the size of a virus, but a micro-fungal organism never before seen that infects both animals and plants!"
            </p>
            <p>
             That's not a new species, nor even a new order, it's a whole new group of organisms separate from animals, plants, bacteria, viruses, fungus. Or it's a fungus so different it's not a fungus.
            </p>
            <p>
             THAT alone should send off huge huge warning bells. If he indeed discover this (by EM? really?), it would be earth-shattering scientific news whether it had anything to do with GMO's or not.
            </p>
            <p>
             Yet no preliminary report in Nature or other journal?
            </p>
            <p>
             This is an extraordinary claim of several magnitudes that needs some quite extraordinary evidence.
            </p>
            <p>
             A badly written letter isn't it. It does no one any favor to hang a hat on this.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             <a href="http://www.lathefamily.org/" rel="nofollow">
              Daddy, Papa &amp; Me
             </a>
             : Two dads, a daughter &amp; the politics of it all.
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:1236">
              wclathe
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40522000#c483">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:37:10 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c10">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
        </ul>
        <li id="c11">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40508109">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            IF these findings are confirmed
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40508109#c11?mode=alone;showrate=1#c11">
             9+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:31383">
              mrkvica
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:44075">
              nailbender
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:48263">
              caul
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:51755">
              truong son traveler
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:106504">
              keikekaze
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:113776">
              wayoutinthestix
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:157580">
              Amber6541
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:233619">
              Miep
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:235212">
              Joieau
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            what's Monsanto legal liability with respect to resulting plant diseases and animal infertility?
           </p>
           <p>
            Are the Feds on the hook for not requiring adequate testing as well?
           </p>
           <p>
            And of course, what happens to the human consumers of plant and animal products containing this pathogen?
           </p>
           <p>
            Is the pathogen killed through cooking or typical commercial food processing?
           </p>
           <p>
            Does Monsanto have internal records which bear on this?
           </p>
           <p>
            It's going to take research to verify or falsify this matter, these are merely the issues that occur to me.
           </p>
          </div>

           </span>
