              </span>

                3+ / 0-

            <li id="c79">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40509512">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                In this case
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40509512#c79?mode=alone;showrate=1#c79">

                is you assume it is an organism made from proteins and nucleic acids etc. I would be perfectly happy using the word impossible. It's a matter of scale. Atoms are too big to have enough of them in a package that small to re-produce. That's my opinion as a biochemist.

              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">

               </p>

            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509512">
             <li id="c304">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40516736">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 When I hear scientifically impossible, I always
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40516736#c304?mode=alone;showrate=1#c304">
                  1+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 think of Xenon Tetraflouride (scientifically impossible, like all similar coumpounds until the sixties), the sun (scientifically impossible until maybe the seventies), hovering and retrograde flight for certain insects and humingbirds (scientifically impossible for the longest time), etc. etc.
                </p>
                <p>
                 What we know is that reproduction using standard cell reproduction processes involving DNA, etc are probably not possible for entities below a certain size, but that is not, as far as we know, the entire universe of replication possibilities. We don't know how life arose, how it was catalyzed, whether it was originally replicating using DNA or RNA or other devices, etc. We can't simply say that the universe of possibility is limited to the everyday, we should have learned better by now.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 That, in its essence, is fascism--ownership of government by an individual, by a group, or by any other controlling private power.
  -- Franklin D. Roosevelt --
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:199857">
                  enhydra lutris
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40516736#c304">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:13:05 AM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c79">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40516736">
              <li id="c414">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40519773">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  That's a load of nonsense.
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40519773#c414?mode=alone;showrate=1#c414">
                   5+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:14467">
                    Duncan Idaho
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                    murrayewv
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                    yuriwho
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                    Serpents Choice
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                    cryonaut
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <blockquote>
                  the sun (scientifically impossible until maybe the seventies)
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  That's not even wrong. In 1920 Eddington proposed that that hydrogen fusion created the energy in the sun, and in 1928 Cecelia Payne demonstrated the sun was mostly hydrogen, which lent credence to the theory because of the proof that all the fuel was present. By 1928 von Weizscker had worked out the basic Carbon-Nitrogen-Oxygen cycle of solar fusion (although he didn't go far enough), and in 1938 Hans Bethe published "Energy Production in Stars", in which he described hydrogen fusion in stars, estimated the core temperatures, and showed how his results coming from a physics standpoint agreed with the results on mass and luminosity of stars coming completely separately from astronomy. At the same time Chandrasekhar was doing similar work, and of course out of his research came the theory of black holes.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  As for the hovering insects and birds, of course it wasn't "scientifically impossible": you could see it happen, no one disputed that it was. That whole story came from some calculations by a French scientist who demonstrated that if you treat a bee's wing like a static airplane wing, there was no way to produce enough lift, so the question was figuring out how it acted
                  <em>
                   unlike
                  </em>
                  an airplane wing, and that required further research into the sophisticated aerodynamics.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  That is
                  <em>
                   not
                  </em>
                  comparable to some of the statements in this letter. They are equivalent to saying that something isn't flying due to aerodynamics at all, but because the animal is using antigravity to toddle along.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:1463">
                   Northwatch
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40519773#c414">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 11:44:44 AM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c304">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
             </ul>
             <li id="c306">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40516878">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Prions?
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40516878#c306?mode=alone;showrate=1#c306">
                  1+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:127703">
                   Karl Rover
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 Not a bioscientist, but as I read this blog I thought "carbohydrate-consuming prion".
                </p>
                <p>
                 I understand them to be able to reproduce, and to be very, very small.
                </p>
                <p>
                 And creepy as all walking death.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 <em>
                  Groups:
                  <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/user/Toolbox" rel="nofollow">
                   Toolbox
                  </a>
                  and
                  <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/user/Trolls" rel="nofollow">
                   Trolls
                  </a>
                  ... to preserve the best &amp; the worst of DailyKos.
                 </em>
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:1625">
                  opendna
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40516878#c306">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:19:21 AM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c79">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40516878">
              <li id="c312">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40517043">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Prions are proteins that induce aggregation
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40517043#c312?mode=alone;showrate=1#c312">
                   3+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                    taylormattd
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                    murrayewv
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                    Hopeful Skeptic
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  of similar proteins. They make your brain pseudo-crystalline. One the mechanism of action was discovered, they were almost instantly accepted in the scientific community because they did not require any change in our working theories about how molecules interact.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  we are but temporary visitors on this planet. The microbes own this place &lt;- Me
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                   yuriwho
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40517043#c312">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:27:20 AM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c306">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40517043">
               <li id="c582">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40524698">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Actually, prions are able to
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40524698#c582?mode=alone;showrate=1#c582">
                    0+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   proliferate by somehow causing similar endogenous proteins to 'flip' from alpha to beta configurations. Notice the "somehow" in that sentence. It is not yet known (that we know of) how foreign prions cause endogenous proteins to flip configuration. It is simply known that they do.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                    Joieau
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40524698#c582">
                    Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:15:22 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c312">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
              </ul>
             </ul>
            </ul>
            <li id="c269">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40514706">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Well nothing's impossible.
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40514706#c269?mode=alone;showrate=1#c269">
                 2+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                  mem from somerville
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                  yuriwho
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                But something are extremely, extremely unlikely.
               </p>
               <p>
                I mean, all your atoms could spontaneously leap in a quantum event ten feet to the left, but the likelihood is so staggeringly small that a person claiming it to be impossible, might only be a hairs worth of off base to use such terms.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                The Republicans: Let's kill jobs and cut deficits until the economy recovers. The Democrats: Let's create jobs and boost the economy until it can help us resolve the deficit. Who needs to win the next election?
               </p>
               <p class="cb">

                <a href="/user/uid:139599">

           <li id="c578">

               Yeah. Proteins
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">

               <a href="/comments/949492/40524613#c578?mode=alone;showrate=1#c578">
                0+ / 0-

             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               that can reproduce independently, live outside of cells/bodies, and act as a [fatal] disease vector were also poo-poo'ed a few years ago.
              </p>
              <p>
               Then Prions earned Prusinger the Nobel Prize.

               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509339">
                <li id="c74">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40509464">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    If?
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40509464#c74?mode=alone;showrate=1#c74">
                     4+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:4498">
                      laurak
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:10342">
                      Pescadero Bill
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:31383">
                      mrkvica
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                      Joieau
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    <a href="http://www.thepeoplesvoice.org/TPV3/Voices.php/2011/02/20/scientists-warn-of-link-between-dangerou">
                     It's easy
                    </a>
                    to verify who is behind the letter, if you wanted to check for yourself:
                   </p>
                   <blockquote>
                    . . .
                    <p>
                     Dr. Don M. Huber, who coordinates the Emergent Diseases and Pathogens committee of the American Phytopathological Society, as part of the USDA National Plant Disease Recovery System, warned Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack that this pathogen threatens the US food and feed supply and can lead to the collapse of the US corn and soy export markets. . .
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     On January 27, Vilsack gave blanket approval to all genetically modified alfalfa. Following orders from President Obama, he also removed buffer zone requirements. This is seen as a deliberate move to contaminate natural crops and destroy the organic meat and dairy industry which relies on GM-free alfalfa. Such genetic contamination will give the biotech industry complete control over the nation's fourth largest crop. It will also ease the transition to using GE-alfalfa as a biofuel.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     . . .
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Tukey also conveyed that while Huber admits that much further study is needed to definitively confirm the link between Round-Up and the pathogen, In the meantime, he said, its grossly irresponsible of the government to allow Roundup Ready alfalfa, which would bring the widespread spraying of Roundup to millions of more acres and introduce far more Roundup into the food supply.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Huber, who has been studying plant pathogens for over 50 years and glyphosate for over 20 years, has noticed an increase in pathogens associated with the herbicide. In an interview with the Organic and Non-GMO Report last May, he discussed his team's conclusions that glyphosate can, significantly increase the severity of various plant diseases, impair plant defense to pathogens and diseases, and immobilize soil and plant nutrients rendering them unavailable for plant use.
                    </p>
                   </blockquote>
                   <p>
                    I'm not convinced this pathogen exists as described, but if nobody follows up on the eventual findings of this study, then I'd hope other tacks on the issues related to the issues seen come to light for review.
                   </p>
                  </div>

                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509308">
               <li id="c82">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40509559">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Peer reviewed?
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40509559#c82?mode=alone;showrate=1#c82">
                    12+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                     taylormattd
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                     mem from somerville
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:17717">
                     Paulie200
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:30517">
                     Eric Blair
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                     murrayewv
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                     yuriwho
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                     whl
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                     lostboyjim
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                     KroneckerD
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                     Hopeful Skeptic
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:215586">
                     erush1345
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                     cryonaut
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   None of the letter is based on peer-reviewed science. It's just wild speculation. Such unsupported and outlandish statements are surprising if it they are coming from a member of a USDA panel, but being on a panel like that is not in itself a big fucking deal.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:11236">
                    tomcat
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40509559#c82">

                <li id="c94">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40509753">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Last peer-reviewed publication appears to be 2009
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40509753#c94?mode=alone;showrate=1#c94">
                     3+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:14467">
                      Duncan Idaho
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:99900">
                      Seneca Doane
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:215586">
                      erush1345
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    Again, just a Google search - your mileage may vary.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I don't think this finding - if that's what it is - is ready to go out the door to the public just yet. I think it needs exactly what the original diarist says it needs: publication in a peer-reviewed journal. And given the claims, I think it needs a whole lot of review.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt

                <li id="c206">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40512351">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Yes, but....
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40512351#c206?mode=alone;showrate=1#c206">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    Sometimes respected individuals are just holding a seat on a committee. However, peer-reviewed science takes time, and maybe it is not a bad idea to consider a slowdown on approvals if a respected committee member and scientist thinks there may be a danger worth investigating.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    As a doctor, not a research scientist, I think about risk-benefit considerations. Maybe there could be widespread risk not worth the benefit of putting something out without more safety checks.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">

                    <a href="/user/uid:96115">

                     <blockquote>
                      On October 18 the Board of Trustees at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory suspended Watson's administrative responsibilities. On October 19, Watson issued an apology, stating that he was mortified and then on October 25 he opted to resign from his position as chancellor.[74][75][76][77][78][79][80] In 2008, Watson was appointed chancellor emeritus of CSHL[81] and, as of 2009, continues his daily activities advising and guiding project work at the laboratory.[82] In a 2008 BBC documentary, Watson said about the incident: "I have never thought of myself as a racist. I don't see myself as a racist. I am mortified by it. It was the worst thing in my life."[83]
                     </blockquote>

                 <ul class="cm i1" id="k40514572">
                  <li id="c491">
                   <div class="cx" id="cx40522180">
                    <h5>
                     <a class="de">
                     </a>
                     <span class="cu">
                      I think the date is interesting....
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">
                      (
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40522180#c491?mode=alone;showrate=1#c491">
                       2+ / 0-
                      </a>
                      )
                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="crs">
                     <dl>
                      <dt>
                       Recommended by:
                      </dt>
                      <dd>
                       <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                        mem from somerville
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                        Hopeful Skeptic
                       </a>
                      </dd>
                     </dl>
                    </div>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      Feb 24, 2011. There must be a lot of stuff out there behind the actual letter from this guy. Purdue is concerned in the weed science department to put out a statement like this.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      That said, they are point by point addressing the issues whith data. Plants are not helped by herbicides, but herbicide resistance isn't the issue they see. They discuss fungal infections of plants and toxins and point out the possibility of a problem isn't the same thing as an actual fungus making a toxin. They also point out the long period of glyphosate use without the effects alluded to in the letter. Nice find mem, but I predict the controversy will not disappear. We are all still talking about lectins in potatoes as proof GMOs are dangerous and the plants failed to be launched, which should prove regulation and testing can work.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                    <div class="cf">
                     <p class="sig">
                      You shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you mad. 
Aldous Huxley

        </li>
        <li id="c32">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40508549">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            The safety of transgenic crops aside...
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40508549#c32?mode=alone;showrate=1#c32">
             22+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:1276">
              NorthCountryNY
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:2101">
              northsylvania
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:3388">
              taylormattd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:6841">
              badger
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:28795">
              wader
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:33206">
              TiaRachel
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:38760">
              Noisy Democrat
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:48175">
              yuriwho
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:52737">
              ChemBob
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:62088">
              the fan man
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:70434">
              Catesby
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:88255">
              xgz
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90176">
              whl
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:110896">
              Devsd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:135733">
              lostboyjim
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:159657">
              KroneckerD
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:174871">
              bicycle Hussein paladin
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:178286">
              kerflooey
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:183265">
              Hopeful Skeptic
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:215586">
              erush1345
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:289230">
              Margd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:298633">
              cryonaut
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            This smells bad to me.
           </p>
           <p>
            There are a few things which seem suspicious:
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             Pitching scientific results to the media, rather than publishing them in peer reviewed journals.
            </strong>
            <a href="http://www.quackwatch.com/01QuackeryRelatedTopics/signs.html">
             This is one of the 7 warning signs of bogus science
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             The claim of a new pathogen which affects plants, animals, and humans.
            </strong>
            Such a pathogen would be a very, very rare thing. I could be wrong, but I can't think of any existing examples.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             The claim that it is well-documented that Round-up promotes soil pathogens and plant disease.
            </strong>
            This is not, in fact, well-documented at all. Though this claim has been made in the past (and there are a few lines of reason that make this a possibility worth looking at), the evidence as far as I know is thin to none.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             No mention of who his colleagues are.
            </strong>
            Dr. Huber is retired (his USDA role appears to be simply serving on a committee, not as a researcher). One doesn't do this sort of research in the backyard. At very least his claim would require an electron microscope. So presumably if this research is going on, it's happening in collaboration with some one at an established institution or corporation. Wouldn't he want to cite where this research is happening, and the credentials of his collaborators to reinforce the authority of his claims? He's very quick to cite his own qualifications...but that's as far as it goes.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             There are a lot of pretty nutty emeritus professors out there.
            </strong>
            I don't know Dr. Huber, but I've been around the plant sciences long enough to know that there are a lot of emeritus professors out there, many of whom were brilliant in their day, who now hold some very odd ideas and have become detached from the scientific reality. People tolerate them out of respect for the past contributions and the fact that most of them are pleasant, harmless, old guys, but every time I see extraordinary claims coming from emeritus professors, there's one or two nutty old guys I've encountered in the past who immediately spring to mind...
           </p>
           <p>
            Hopefully we'll know more soon, but I'm pretty skeptical at this point.
            <br/>
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:21292">
             elakazal
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40508549#c32">
             Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 07:45:00 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40508549">
         <li id="c57">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40509202">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             A quick Google...
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40509202#c57?mode=alone;showrate=1#c57">
              9+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:10342">
               Pescadero Bill
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:14467">
               Duncan Idaho
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:28795">
               wader
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:31383">
               mrkvica
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:65907">
               buddabelly
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:77225">
               Turbonerd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:99900">
               Seneca Doane
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:127703">
               Karl Rover
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:235212">
               Joieau
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             on Dr. Huber shows that he appears to still be publishing and speaking in this field of study. He appears to be focused on research into the interaction of agricultural chemicals and food production.
            </p>
            <p>
             A search on Glyphosate causing increased pathogen presence returns within scholar.google.com returns 10,800 results dating at least back to 1988. Your skepticism on these claims matches a response supposedly from a query to Purdue, but I find it hard to believe that Purdue knows nothing about a subject Dr. Huber has been studying for 20 years now, including while he was working at Purdue.
            </p>
            <p>
             I do have a lot of skepticism over this, though - there needs to be solid proof of an organism like this letter describes, since it goes against our current understanding of the size of self-reproducing organisms.
            </p>
            <p>
             But Dr. Huber is not just "on a committee", he heads up a USDA panel on emerging diseases and threats.
            </p>
            <p>
             Moreover, apparently this letter was sent prior to Sec. Vilsak's decision to release GMO alfalfa to the broad market. If that is true, then I think serious consideration needs to be made on whether Vilsak should be ousted from his position.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:6251">
              Phoenix Rising
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40509202#c57">

         <li id="c577">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40524493">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Emeritus professors
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40524493#c577?mode=alone;showrate=1#c577">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:7787">
               mem from somerville
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             In grad school I once had an elderly emeritus professor tell me about his "friend" who had not consumed anything but water for six months, and instead was surviving by "absorbing energy from the universe". He couldn't understand why the NIH wasn't studying people like that.
            </p>
            <p>
             In his day, this professor was top of his field, but old age comes to us all...
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:142474">
              liberal chemist
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40524493#c577">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:02:29 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">

          <div class="ct">

        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509067">
         <li id="c65">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40509310">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Why is it inconceivable that a
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40509310#c65?mode=alone;showrate=1#c65">
              3+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:6251">
               Phoenix Rising
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:31383">
               mrkvica
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:206053">
               lincoln deschain
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             virus might have some fungus like property? Why not a microorganism with fungal characteristics?
            </p>
            <p>
             Simply because it has never been seen before does not preclude it's possible existence. Just how long ago was it that it was believed an atom was the smallest unit of matter? Inconceivable that a proton, neutron or electron could be made up of even smaller particles?
            </p>
            <p>
             While I'm willing to wait for further evidence about the claim, dismissing it outright is as harmful to science as those who dismiss science in favor of religion.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             I am much too liberal to be a Democrat.
            </p>

               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Dark matter and dark energy
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40517883#c346?mode=alone;showrate=1#c346">
                  4+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">

               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 do not defy the laws of physics.  They are unknown variables we have based on astronomical observations.  They don't defy physics, we just don't understand exactly what they are yet.

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40517883">
              <li id="c617">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40525888">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Phlogiston! n/t
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40525888#c617?mode=alone;showrate=1#c617">
                   0+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="ct">
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40525888#c617">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:30:15 PM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c346">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525888">
               <li id="c622">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40526116">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Phlogiston
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40526116#c622?mode=alone;showrate=1#c622">
                    1+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:99900">
                     Seneca Doane
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   It's easy to make fun of phlogiston theory as one of those "see how terribly misguided science can be!" things, but it's more or less just wrong by a sign change. Every time phlogiston theory talks about
                   <em>
                    absorbing
                   </em>
                   phlogiston, that's
                   <em>
                    consuming
                   </em>
                   oxygen, and so forth.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Given the equipment of the era, it wasn't actually unreasonable. It didn't take too long after air was fractioned and people got to play around with phlogisticated air (=nitrogen, air that used up all its phlogiston / was out of oxygen) and dephlogisticated air (=oxygen, air with an enhanced phlogiston capacity) that the problems became apparent and the phlogiston theory was sunk in favor of the long-running debate between caloric and kinetic heat.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                    Serpents Choice
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40526116#c622">
                    Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:46:04 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c617">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40526116">
                <li id="c638">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40526730">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    And novel infectious agents
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40526730#c638?mode=alone;showrate=1#c638">
                     1+ / 0-
                    </a>

                      Seneca Doane
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    as small or smaller than viruses - but not viruses - isn't actually unreasonable.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">

                     <a class="de">

                     <span class="cu">
                      What's the problematic term there:
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">

                      <a href="/comments/949492/40537282#c717?mode=alone;showrate=1#c717">
                       0+ / 0-
                      </a>

                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>

                     </p>
                    </div>
                    <div class="cf">
                     <p class="sig">
                      Unplug the Koch machine! It's
                      <strong>
                       swallowing people's money!
                      </strong>
                     </p>
                     <p class="cb">
                      by
                      <a href="/user/uid:99900">

                      </a>

                      <a href="/comments/949492/40537282#c717">

                 </ul>
                </ul>
               </ul>
              </ul>
              <li id="c716">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40537269">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  They kick the crap out of the laws of physics
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40537269#c716?mode=alone;showrate=1#c716">
                   0+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  as understood right now. That's why physicists are so happy -- it's a chance to make a great name for oneself and to advance the ball of our understanding of the universe by a great deal, more so than possible in times without "crisis."
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  By your understanding of "we just don't understand what they are yet," what possible phenomenon
                  <em>
                   does
                  </em>
                  defy physics? This is a "heads I win, tails you lose" standard. If something that defies physics gathers enough evidence behind it, even without a compelling model, then it goes from "defies physics" to "we just don't yet understand it," forgetting the earlier stage.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Had I asked you 20 years ago whether something with the characteristics of dark matter and dark energy "defied physics," I will bet that you'd have said "yes."
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  Unplug the Koch machine! It's
                  <strong>
                   swallowing people's money!
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:99900">
                   Seneca Doane
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40537269#c716">
                   Sat Feb 26, 2011 at 01:11:27 PM PST
                  </a>

            <li id="c283">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40515557">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                RNA world! directed by...
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">

               </span>

                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  This doesn't look like an end-run
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40510451#c135?mode=alone;showrate=1#c135">
                   3+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )

                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  It looks like someone who sees a decision being made that he thinks is a Really Bad Idea, who has his recommendation dismissed and sends his letter to someone that might get the word out to farmers that this stuff could be bad.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  All he has to go by for the letter, by his own admission, is preliminary data. But all he has time to do before that decision is made is send a letter to his boss, the Agriculture Secretary of the United States.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I hope that this is either proven a hoax letter (which will not do the diarist's or the FRFA's reputation a single bit of good), or that we eventually get to see either a solid peer-reviewed article on the discoveries of this research - or another note saying "nope, we were wrong - it's something else". Now that this letter is out on the Internet, it needs people to follow it through to some kind of resolution. Monsanto need not apply to help.
                 </p>

                 <div class="cf">

                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:167760">
                    rfall

                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40510568">
                <li id="c155">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40510697">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    The letter summarizes the data
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40510697#c155?mode=alone;showrate=1#c155">
                     4+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:10342">
                      Pescadero Bill
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:24632">
                      chimpy
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:135160">
                      forgore
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                      Joieau
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    Perhaps the procedure that could come up with this seemingly dismissable claim isn't clear:
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    1. Dr. Huber, serving as head of a USDA panel on emerging diseases, has a team involved in following up on a paper produced a couple of years ago on Roundup or RoundupReady crops causing increased spontaneous abortions.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    2. His team gathers some initial data from reports in the field. From the letter, they don't appear to be great data - lots of unknowns. But the numbers are too stark to ignore.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    3. Team starts investigating the cause of the spontaneous abortions, finds something abnormal in the blood of the cows that were affected.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    4. Team cross-checks with Dr. Huber's specialty subject, plant fungal infections and Roundup. Same organism.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    5. Deadline rapidly approaching for a decision on approving GMO alfalfa, which is sure to be much more widely used as cattle feed than previous GMO plants.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    6. Go to Secretary with this, even with the weak link in the causality chain? Your factors... In favor: if the GMO crop goes out, the gene will undoubtedly spread to non-GMO fields and then the cat is well and truly out of the bag - what do you feed the cattle when the GMO plant is so widespread? Also, the numbers are pretty stark, and you've got the organism correlating the Roundup relationship. Against: the study is barely beginning, really - need to do a much more controlled version to see what happens.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I'd go with the letter if I were Dr. Huber, personally. It's not like GMO alfalfa is necessary to stop some blight...
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:6251">
                     Phoenix Rising

                    on
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40510697#c155">

                   <p class="cl">

                    <a href="#c146">
                     Parent
                    </a>

                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <ul class="cm i1" id="k40510697">
                 <li id="c185">
                  <div class="cx" id="cx40511437">
                   <h5>
                    <a class="de">
                    </a>
                    <span class="cu">
                     Just so I'm clear...
                    </span>
                    <span class="crd ntb">
                     (
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40511437#c185?mode=alone;showrate=1#c185">
                      5+ / 0-
                     </a>
                     )
                    </span>
                   </h5>
                   <div class="crs">
                    <dl>
                     <dt>
                      Recommended by:
                     </dt>
                     <dd>
                      <a href="/user/uid:17717">
                       Paulie200
                      </a>

                      <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                       murrayewv
                      </a>

                      <a href="/user/uid:88255">

                      </a>

                      <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                       whl
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                       Roger Fox
                      </a>
                     </dd>
                    </dl>
                   </div>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     ...where are we getting the idea that Dr. Huber is the head of a USDA panel on emerging diseases?
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     The letter calls him: "APS Coordinator, USDA National Plant Disease Recovery System".
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     As far as I can tell, what he's coordinating is group that put together a response plan for Late Wilt in corn. Somehow I doubt this data came out of that work.
                    </p>
                   </div>

                  <li id="c277">
                   <div class="cx" id="cx40515110">
                    <h5>
                     <a class="de">
                     </a>
                     <span class="cu">
                      That would indicate some connection to USDA, yes?
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">
                      (
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40515110#c277?mode=alone;showrate=1#c277">
                       1+ / 0-
                      </a>
                      )
                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="crs">
                     <dl>
                      <dt>

                      </dt>
                      <dd>
                       <a href="/user/uid:10342">
                        Pescadero Bill
                       </a>
                      </dd>
                     </dl>
                    </div>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      The letter needs some backup, and I am suggesting that the diarist, who apparently has the contacts needed, follow up on our concerns and get a somewhat better idea of where the good doctor is coming from and going to...
                     </p>
                    </div>
                    <div class="cf">
                     <p class="sig">
                      Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt
                     </p>
                     <p class="cb">
                      by
                      <a href="/user/uid:6251">
                       Phoenix Rising
                      </a>
                      on
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40515110#c277">
                       Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 07:49:51 AM PST
                      </a>
                     </p>
                     <p class="cl">
                      [
                      <a href="#c185">
                       Parent
                      </a>
                      ]
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <ul class="cm i1" id="k40515110">
                   <li id="c291">
                    <div class="cx" id="cx40516069">
                     <h5>
                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       Connection
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/949492/40516069#c291?mode=alone;showrate=1#c291">
                        9+ / 0-
                       </a>
                       )
                      </span>
                     </h5>
                     <div class="crs">
                      <dl>
                       <dt>
                        Recommended by:
                       </dt>
                       <dd>
                        <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                         mem from somerville
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:11236">
                         tomcat
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                         murrayewv
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:70434">
                         Catesby
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:78940">
                         zeke7237
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                         whl
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                         lostboyjim
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                         KroneckerD
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                         Hopeful Skeptic
                        </a>
                       </dd>
                      </dl>
                     </div>
                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       First off, abbreviation time. APS is the American Phytopathological Society. It is a professional organization dedicated to research into plant disease. Every year, the APS participates in a conference with the USDA's National Plant Disease Recovery System (NPDRS) to identify potentially emerging disease threats to US agriculture and to develop detection and recovery plans.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       As for Don Huber, he
                       <a href="http://www.apsnet.org/members/directories/Pages/Council.aspx">
                        does not now
                       </a>
                       and
                       <a href="http://www.apsnet.org/members/directories/Pages/RecentOfficers.aspx">
                        has never
                       </a>
                       held a leadership position with APS on the national scale. He
                       <a href="http://www.apsnet.org/members/apsleadership/comm/Pages/edpc.aspx">
                        is a member
                       </a>
                       (although not an officer) of the APS Committee on Emerging Diseases and Pathogens. And he
                       <a href="http://www.ars.usda.gov/SP2UserFiles/Place/00000000/opmp/Corn%20Late%20wilt%2081112.pdf">
                        chaired and contributed to
                       </a>
                       (pdf) the committee that produced the 2008 APS/NPDRS report on late corn wilt (which, naturally, didn't include anything like what's being claimed here).
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Despite claims upthread, he does not appear to be a field leader. He's ... a retired Purdue University research professor, with a long career investigating nutrient uptake and disease in corn. He's published in a few mid-level journals in his field, including at least one paper in
                       <em>
                        Plant Physiology
                       </em>
                       , which has a top-ten impact factor for plant sciences. And he's had a few nice positions in his professional society, as would be expected for anyone with that length of service to the field. Colonel Huber has enough years of experience in the field to know that, if he had verifiable claims, this is not the way to announce them.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       As a result, I can see no reason to afford this letter any more weight than the likelihood of its claims warrants. Which is to say, absolutely none at all.
                      </p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="cf">
                      <p class="sig">
                       "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                      </p>
                      <p class="cb">
                       by
                       <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                        Serpents Choice
                       </a>
                       on
                       <a href="/comments/949492/40516069#c291">
                        Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 08:39:02 AM PST
                       </a>
                      </p>
                      <p class="cl">
                       [
                       <a href="#c277">
                        Parent
                       </a>
                       ]
                      </p>
                     </div>
                    </div>
                   </li>
                   <ul class="cm i1" id="k40516069">
                    <li id="c301">

                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        Volunteers only on such panels
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40516501#c301?mode=alone;showrate=1#c301">
                         7+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )

                      </h5>

                <li id="c512">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40522714">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Ponzi and Fleischkopf
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40522714#c512?mode=alone;showrate=1#c512">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    were the authors of a fictional paper referenced in a brilliant satire by John Waugh. This letter reads more like the satire. The author discovered the release of energy from tungsten filaments in which electrons were stuffed with zero average applied current and average applied voltage, hence zero energy input. Thus nuclear fission was proved. (The jars with the tungsten filaments were "kindly supplied by General Electric Co"., with another version provided by Phillips Gloueijlaempijenfabruijken N. V.) The paper was prompted by "recent changes in the scientific method".
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    Michael Weissman
UID 197542
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">

               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
                </p>
                <p class="cb">

            <li id="c112">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40510054">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I'd like to protect that integrity, too
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40510054#c112?mode=alone;showrate=1#c112">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                And, since this letter managed to get out in to the public prior to a reviewed paper, it deserves a healthy dollop of skepticism.
               </p>
               <p>
                But it doesn't deserve out-and-out rejection of its basic notions. The letter was directed at a non-scientist, Sec. Vilsack - it can be expected to be "dumbed down" to a level that an expert in the field would consider insulting, but which conveys the basic substance of the finding. It was also written apparently under a deadline - the certification of widespread use of RoundupReady GMO alfalfa. Hence, no prior peer-reviewed paper yet.
               </p>
               <p>
                I find the letter to be credible for what it is, but lacking in the details that we need to properly evaluate it.
               </p>
               <p>
                Science isn't supposed to be about closing ourselves out from what we have not yet discovered, but rather setting out to postulate, evaluate, and potentially disprove. That's all I'm asking, and not what your initial response aimed at.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">

               <p>
                Fuck. I wish scientists had integrity for things other then the integrity of their findings. Like the integrity to acknowledge that introducing shit into the environment (see: DDT) could do some fucking harm.
               </p>
               <p>
                How many people have died from things purported to be safe or benign by scientists? Part of the anti-science problem in this country stems from the harm some science has done. Done usually to make a buck and fuck the consequences.
               </p>
               <p>
                Surely you can understand to need to proceed along with some simple precautionary principles in some areas of science?
               </p>
               <p>
                Now, I'm all for science, but I'm tired of it being conducted by some with little integrity for the long-term consequences their science will have on the planet and the humans and animals inhabiting it.
               </p>
               <p>
                Scientists can do as much harm as they can do healing. Your science is not inviolate.
               </p>

          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509381">
           <li id="c83">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40509567">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               It is a good question...
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40509567#c83?mode=alone;showrate=1#c83">
                2+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:31383">
                 mrkvica
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:146640">
                 WiseFerret
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Why not answer it, in layman's terms, rather than attacking the poster's knowledge?
              </p>
              <p>
               We know that organisms can adopt characteristics of other organisms across species, genus, and even kingdom boundaries. Our own mitochondria are theorized to have come from incorporation of a simple organism.
              </p>
              <p>
               So the question remains - is it possible for a mid-sized virus to pick up a trait of an actual cellular organism? I don't think anyone here can say that's been definitively answered.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:6251">
                Phoenix Rising

           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509567">
            <li id="c88">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40509627">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I was asking the original commenter to
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40509627#c88?mode=alone;showrate=1#c88">
                 10+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                  taylormattd
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:7787">

                 </a>

                 <a href="/user/uid:24632">

                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:27571">

                 </a>

                 <a href="/user/uid:36845">

                 </a>

                 </a>

                 <a href="/user/uid:146640">
                  WiseFerret
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:215586">
                  erush1345
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                  cryonaut
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                clarify their question, because it really doesn't make sense in the context of what we know about viruses. They may take on genes of their hosts, but they CAN NOT express those traits because they are not capable of reproducing without a host.
               </p>
               <p>
                That was why I was asking for clarification.
               </p>
               <p>
                And asking about someone's level of expertise is not an attack. I want to know their level of knowledge so I know how much I would expect them to know, and how to engage them.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                "The more the Democrats pursue the center... the further to the right the "center" moves." -fellow kossack vacantlook
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                 Hopeful Skeptic
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40509627#c88">

               </p>
               <p class="cl">

                <a href="#c83">

                </a>

               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509627">
             <li id="c97">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40509810">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Not all traits are related to reproduction
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40509810#c97?mode=alone;showrate=1#c97">
                  0+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 Regardless, all of this is idle speculation. The letter doesn't tell anyone with any kind of scientific understanding anything in enough detail to make heads or tails of it. But a letter to Vilsack wouldn't have contained those technical details - Vilsack is a lawyer, not a scientist.
                </p>
                <p>
                 I think it's good to know that this letter may be out there. But there's just too much unknown right now to lend it the "write your Congressman" weight that something of this potential impact should be given.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt

                </p>

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509810">
              <li id="c102">
