                <div class="ct">
                 <blockquote>
                  Not all traits are related to reproduction
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  I was trying to explain that there aren't any viral genes that are expressed outside of their hosts, which is when they're reproducing. So they couldn't show fungal traits as they exist on their own (as viruses). See my comment below as well.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I agree with this too.

             <li id="c142">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40510537">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Many fungi can't reproduce without a host
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40510537#c142?mode=alone;showrate=1#c142">
                  2+ / 0-

               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 Although they certainly carry their own genesets. And viruses can reproduce, but not without co-opting the hosts machinery. I don't think the letter says enough for me to conclude it's the mad ravings of a senile old man. I'm willing to listen more.
                </p>
                <p>
                 It's not clear to me that he's saying that it reproduces by itself without using the host to assist it. He could be saying that it multiplies inside the cell and therefore isn't some remnant DNA contaminant.
                </p>
                <p>
                 And I'd like to know what he's claiming is fungal about it.
                </p>
                <p>
                 I'd also like to see the actual data on the cattle deaths verified by other souces. That is not the same as saying this is incorrect, simply that there isn't enough information in the letter to make a decision.

           <li id="c93">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40509735">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               My background is chemistry
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40509735#c93?mode=alone;showrate=1#c93">
                1+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                 Hopeful Skeptic
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               with a great deal of informal researching in order to create plausible aliens and alien issues in writing science fiction.
              </p>
              <p>
               A basic biology course introduced the possibility that virus can insert themselves in genetic code, be neutralized, yet leave the genetic code modified and replicated through subsequent generations. It was apparently an extremely bizarre idea at the time, yet is now proving to be one way of delivering a genetic change into an organism to fix genetic mishaps.
              </p>
              <p>
               For me, it was not a grand leap of logic. It seemed perfectly possible. I used in a story. Thus, I do not think we have discovered everything under the sun. It does not surprise me that life, or near live (virus'), might be found in new configurations, especially when we are introducing new sorts of stressors and raw material for them to react to.
               <br/>
               I cannot immediately think of why there could not be such a tiny organism. What ever characteristics it has, will draw an analogy to larger, more familiar organisms. So as far as I can tell, the actual question of possibility, is if it can be an actual organism so tiny or is it merely a virus with unique properties?
              </p>
              <p>
               My formal level is basic college biology. Informally, I have siblings with masters and pHd's in biologic science who I do ask about interesting things I come across. I've dabbled in genetic through breeding mice and ferrets, now applying it to goats. Quite a bit of my knowledge is self-taught, a bit random, on the topics that happen to interest me.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               I am much too liberal to be a Democrat.
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:146640">
                WiseFerret
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40509735#c93">
                Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 09:10:50 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c70">

           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509735">
            <li id="c99">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40509857">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                thank you for the reply
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40509857#c99?mode=alone;showrate=1#c99">
                 1+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                  kalmoth
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                as I said above, I think that viruses can take on genes of their hosts, but they will not express them until they are inside their host again. So the idea of a virus that looks like a fungus just doesn't make sense.
               </p>
               <p>
                However, there are many microbes and eukaryotes with virus-encoding DNA in their genomes, including humans. We have lots of viral DNA... but we don't look like viruses. ;-)
               </p>
               <p>
                As far as a microbe with fungus-like traits, I suppose that could be possible... for certain traits (and I'd bet that there are some already known.. but don' have time to go look it up at the moment). But that doesn't seem to be what the letter is implying.
               </p>
              </div>

             <li id="c107">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40509956">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Agree on that last
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40509956#c107?mode=alone;showrate=1#c107">
                  1+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>

               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                   Joieau
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 The letter implies that this is either a new class of organism in the mid-virus size range having fungal properties, or some completely out-of-the-box discovery on an actual fungus (which is hard to believe for various reasons, but Nature is creative...).
                </p>
                <p>
                 Given the doctor's previous research into increased fungal pathogen susceptibility when exposing plants to Roundup, this letter does at least seem to follow along lines that he might be expected to explore if he were doing research, on the plant side of the equation.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Also, there was an earlier paper published I believe from Argentina that indicated an increase in spontaneous abortions from Roundup exposure.  That might explain this line of research from the animal side. Good science these days lies in fusing multiple disciplines and their findings into a cohesive understanding; if this letter is really true, the research stands as a testament to this cross-discipline approach.
                </p>
               </div>

                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    That one is easy
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40515432#c281?mode=alone;showrate=1#c281">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>

                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    if round up is breaking down the ability of a plant to produce energy by destroying it's chloroplasts, the fungi living inside it would convert to sexual mode to get out of the host and go elsewhere. Not only will this further deplete the host as the fungi uses more of it's resources to produce spores, but the fungi itself is now in aggressive mode and will be more widespread. Many species of endophytes seem to sometimes help a plant and sometimes hurt it. The Fusarium mentioned in the letter is one such organism.
                   </p>

            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Microfungal infections like nosema
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40510529#c141?mode=alone;showrate=1#c141">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )

           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             affect all sorts of animals, and are implicated in killing bees .. so 'microfungal like organism' sounds like it
             <em>
              could be
             </em>
             an actual microfungal organism, to me.
            </p>
            <p>
             Of course, I took microbiology decades ago, so I could be all wet.
            </p>
            <p>
             What I see as the problem isn't the wording of phrases in the article, it's the lack of metrics backing up the hypothesis, more than anything else. The claims of cause and effect must be proven and the author provides no data.
            </p>

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40510529">
          <li id="c153">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40510649">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Microfungal as compared to Mushrooms
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40510649#c153?mode=alone;showrate=1#c153">
               4+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                taylormattd
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                kalmoth
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                murrayewv
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                Hopeful Skeptic
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              not micro as compared to bacteria which is what he is claiming. Most fungi are larger and more complicated than most bacteria. All of which are thousands of times larger than viruses. He's claiming a fungus the size of a virus.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              we are but temporary visitors on this planet. The microbes own this place &lt;- Me
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:48175">

             </p>

           </div>
          </li>
          <li id="c156">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40510713">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              It's the size that's the killer
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40510713#c156?mode=alone;showrate=1#c156">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              a normal microfungal organism isn't the size of a virus, it's significantly larger.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:6251">
               Phoenix Rising
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40510713#c156">
               Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 10:40:37 PM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c141">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <li id="c245">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40514157">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Nosema
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40514157#c245?mode=alone;showrate=1#c245">
               6+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:1276">
                NorthCountryNY
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                taylormattd
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                mem from somerville
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                whl
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                KroneckerD
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:197542">
                docmidwest
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              <em>
               Nosema
              </em>
              is gigantic compared to the "organism" being described in this letter. Microfungus, for the record, is a term of art. It refers to members of Division Microsporidia, a group of unicellular fungi. Note: unicellular. What's being described here is far smaller than any cell could possibly be.
             </p>
             <p>
              But that's actually not the biggest warning light that this letter is a load of nonsense. Let's talk about
              <em>
               Nosema
              </em>
              for a moment.  Have you ever had a
              <em>
               Nosema
              </em>
              infection? Do bees infected with
              <em>
               Nosema
              </em>
              spread it to the flowers they visit, creating plant die-offs across huge sections of land, a lifeless blight left in their wake?
             </p>
             <p>
              Of course not. There are about eleventy zillion species of
              <em>
               Nosema
              </em>
              . The really ambitious ones can infect a closely related group of insects (like
              <em>
               N. apis
              </em>
              , which affects several types of honey bees). Most are confined to only a single species. Some, to a single population. None leap across phylum and kingdom boundaries.
             </p>
             <p>
              Pathogens that can affect widely unrelated species are rare. Pathogens that can affect as many species, as widely unrelated, as described here are unknown. Are unbelievable. And are very likely physically impossible.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:87455">
               Serpents Choice
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40514157#c245">
               Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:57:20 AM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c141">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40514157">
           <li id="c509">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40522654">

               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Page at Purdue implies the plant pathogenic fungus is making a toxin that harms the animals.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               You shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you mad. 
Aldous Huxley
              </p>
              <p class="cb">

           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40526027">
            <li id="c630">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40526376">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Sigh
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40526376#c630?mode=alone;showrate=1#c630">
                 3+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                  mem from somerville
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                  yuriwho
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                  KroneckerD
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                Technically, that's true for everything. Science allow statements to stand until and unless it can be shown that they no longer fit observed data. That's what, fundamentally, distinguishes science from dogma.
               </p>
               <p>
                However, extraordinary claims that would overturn substantial quantities of current practice require extraordinary evidence, and it's considered okay to ditch the qualifiers and talk like normal people. This is because such claims must be weighed against the sum total of what has come before to determine whether there is a pervasive error or oversight that has been made all along or a single error or oversight in the novel statement.
               </p>
               <p>
                This letter makes
                <em>
                 many
                </em>
                extraordinary claims. It presents
                <em>
                 extraordinarily bad
                </em>
                evidence. It is overwhelmingly likely that the error is his, and not, well, all of biology's.
               </p>
               <p>
                And since his previous coworkers at Purdue have already thrown him under the bus over this, unless he comes forward with some real support for his claims soon, the conclusion that the letter is wrongity-wrong-wrong won't even deserve a "that we know of."
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                 Serpents Choice
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40526376#c630">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:04:16 PM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c620">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </ul>

             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               how many times?
              </p>
              <p>
               There have been several times in the history of computing when we ran into a need to overthrow the established theories of science.
              </p>
              <p>
               Biology never used to accept the existence of viruses, or prions - or of illnesses caused by actual organisms, for that matter.
              </p>
              <p>
               This letter is now out on the internet, and the diarist is only repeating what is out there in the anti-GMO community already. It deserves to be investigated and definitively confirmed or shot down; it's too late IMHO to try dismissing it.
              </p>

             <p>
              I find it ironic, that you used a fake quote to try to make your point.
             </p>
             <blockquote>
              I've said some stupid things and some wrong things, but not that. No one involved in computers would ever say that a certain amount of memory is enough for all time  I keep bumping into that silly quotation attributed to me that says 640K of memory is enough. There's never a citation; the quotation just floats like a rumor, repeated again and again.
              <p>
               * Gates (19 January 1996), "Career Opportunities in Computingand More". Bloomberg Business News
               <br/>
              </p>
             </blockquote>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              Those who make peaceful revolution impossible will make violent revolution inevitable. --John F. Kennedy
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:27571">
               Beelzebud
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40518044#c351">

              </a>

             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </ul>
        <li id="c73">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40509440">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Here is the thing.
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40509440#c73?mode=alone;showrate=1#c73">
             14+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:6472">
              RonV
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:10342">
              Pescadero Bill
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:15850">
              shpilk
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:31383">
              mrkvica
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:40073">
              KayCeSF
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:48175">
              yuriwho
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:70434">
              Catesby
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:77225">
              Turbonerd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:78940">
              zeke7237
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:92246">
              Margfh
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:99900">
              Seneca Doane
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:127703">
              Karl Rover
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:206053">
              lincoln deschain
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:235212">
              Joieau
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            GMO is nice for those who want a technical solution to a cultural problem.
           </p>
           <p>
            Whats the cultural problem?
           </p>
           <p>
            1) Expecting that growing monocultures, even in rotation, will provide for soil fertility
           </p>
           <p>
            2) Plowing those monocultures at least once a year and destroying the soil food web that would sustain healthy plants
           </p>
           <p>
            3) Expecting 1 farmer to provide enough food for 100+ people
           </p>
           <p>
            4) Believing one farmer can responsibly steward hundreds, if not thousands, of acres of land
           </p>
           <p>
            5) Praising migration of people from rural areas to urban areas
           </p>
           <p>
            6) Not demanding that our farmers be "educated" in ecology, biology, and other fundamental sciences that are the basis of their profession
           </p>
           <p>
            7) Believing that technological solutions are always the best ones.
           </p>
           <p>
            If we fix the way we view agriculture, we can do without GMO crops. While I believe research should still be conducted, I don't believe the technologies are a) currently used appropriately and b) necessary.
           </p>
           <p>
            We need more farmers, not less. We need more small farms, not less. We need farmers who are willing to take a biological and ecological perspective of their land and steward it appropriately.
           </p>
           <p>
            GMO's won't solve world hunger. They haven't, they won't, and never will. Only farmers, who are ultimately people, will. We need to farm smarter with what we have before we contaminate entire species of domesticated plants with GMO genes that we haven't researched fully. It is ludicrous, arrogant, and downright silly to be dumping billions into cracking genetic code when those same billions could provide education, grants, and loans to farmers who want to work with nature instead of against it.
           </p>
           <p>
            We shouldn't face a future where we might have to rely upon uncontaminated seed stocks stowed away in doomsday vaults because we decide to engineer our way out of a cultural problem.
            <br/>
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            <a href="http://finchj9b.tumblr.com/" rel="nofollow">
             A Victory Garden
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:146565">
             FinchJ
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40509440#c73">
             Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 08:48:16 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509440">
         <li id="c76">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40509484">

              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I've read so much about GMO's that alarm me, too. I think we are playing with fire, and that means playing with our own lives.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:40073">
              KayCeSF
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40509484#c76">
              Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 08:52:34 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c73">
              Parent
             </a>

            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40509484">
          <li id="c86">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40509589">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              It an alarmingly classic example
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40509589#c86?mode=alone;showrate=1#c86">
               3+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:6472">
                RonV
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:40073">
                KayCeSF
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:235212">
                Joieau
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              of human hastiness. Genetically modifying organisms that we have yet to fully understand in their natural state is a recipe for disaster.
             </p>
             <p>
              Just because we can doesn't mean we should. As a species, we are not mature enough to be creating and dispersing GMOs at the expense of evolutionary tested species.
             </p>
             <p>
              Genetically modifying a species by inserting genes from even related species is, as you said, playing with fire. One can argue that genetic engineering is simply speeding up evolution.
             </p>
             <p>
              But did anyone bother to ask if evolution needs to be sped up? Especially when slowing down is the answer to just about every problem we as humans have.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">

         <li id="c133">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40510406">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Part of the problem with food is not quantity,
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40510406#c133?mode=alone;showrate=1#c133">
              5+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:6472">
               RonV
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:10342">
               Pescadero Bill
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:28799">
               k9disc
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:146565">
               FinchJ
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:184587">
               freesia
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             it's waste, gross economic disparity and distribution, first of all. GMOs are shortcuts to making food more profitable, to eliminate some pesky variables.
            </p>
            <p>
             You are quite correct that GMOs won't solve world hunger, because the problems of waste, gross economic disparity and distribution bottlenecks will still be with us. But GMOs will help enrich some segment of the population. Technology for the sake of technology, and making money off it, for the sake of making money off it should never be confused with actually the larger goals.
            </p>
            <p>
             In this case, feeding the population of a wildly out of control planet, where nations like the USA throw away enough food every year to feed billions is not well served by GMOs .. much better and more efficient use of resources would be finding ways to reduce waste, and improve distribution channels for the existing food we have.
            </p>
            <p>
             Here's one article on food waste
            </p>
            <p>
             <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/18/weekinreview/18martin.html">
              http://www.nytimes.com/...
             </a>
            </p>
           </div>

             <a href="/user/uid:90176">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:99900">

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:122357">
              Kathy S
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:135733">
              lostboyjim
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:159657">
              KroneckerD
             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:160276">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:167760">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:183265">
              Hopeful Skeptic
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:197542">
              docmidwest
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:215586">
              erush1345
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:298633">
              cryonaut
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            While I am no fan of roundup-ready GMOs, this letter has numerous 'tells' that scream hoax or crank. The letter claims the 'control' heifer herd had 0 spontaneous abortions out of 1000 cows (a very nice round number that I can never get in a study). Cows have a background normal abortion rate of about 1-2%. There should be around 10 - 20 abortions in the control.
           </p>
           <p>
            For those who care about stats, you would have about a 0.2% chance of observing 0 abortions if the background rate is 1%.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:1276">
             NorthCountryNY
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40509482#c75">

           </p>

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40510420">
          <li id="c625">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40526269">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              No, it's not "impossible."
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40526269#c625?mode=alone;showrate=1#c625">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Entirely depends on the 1,000 cows chosen to be the comparison population. If 'normal' rates are ~3 or 4 per thousand and you don't see 3 or 4 in your sample, it just means your sample didn't include the 3 or 4 that would have 'normally' aborted.
             </p>
             <p>
              All this means is that the control groups suffered no miscarriages in the period of observation. The test groups suffered a hugely significant rate of ~450 per thousand - nearly half! That means something very much needs a closer look.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              Now, more than ever, we need the Jedi.
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:235212">
               Joieau
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40526269#c625">

            </div>

          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40526269">
           <li id="c646">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40527104">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               A closer look
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40527104#c646?mode=alone;showrate=1#c646">
                1+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                 mem from somerville
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               If you assume that study was even done -- and I have very strong reasons to believe that it was not, at least not as presented -- then you'd start by rerunning the observation with some proper controls.
              </p>
              <p>
               If I feed one set of cows wheat silage, and another set of cows hay, and one set has more miscarriages than the other, I have
               <em>
                not
               </em>
               provided meaningful evidence that glyphosate is causing spontaneous abortions.
               <br/>
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                Serpents Choice
               </a>

         <li id="c143">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40510540">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             That's the most glaring question here
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40510540#c143?mode=alone;showrate=1#c143">
              3+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:3388">
               taylormattd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:65678">
               pico
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:215586">
               erush1345
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             There should not have been 0, though as you note it's not out of the question. It doesn't sound like the initial study was well controlled - someone else notes that the letter indicates an unsureness over the actual application of Roundup to the wheat silage. We can wonder forever if someone adjusted the results for the expected background before handing off the numbers for summary. I also don't like the 450 number, though - it's awfully even...
            </p>
            <p>
             I keep pointing this out on different bits of this diary, but this letter was not meant to be a technical summary - it was being delivered to Sec. Vilsack, who is a lawyer, not a scientist. And if I judge it right, it was sent somewhat in haste.
            </p>
            <p>
             Assuming the letter is real (and I point out elsewhere that the diarist has the connections that make it believable), then what we have is either something very hastily put together based on what looked to be alarming data in order to meet a deadline, or someone gone way off the deep end - which I think requires even more proof than asking the scientific types among us to accept that this letter is a gross expression of what is really being studied by the team.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves. - William Pitt

            I do not take this at face value
           </span>

            Verification needed
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40509600#c87?mode=alone;showrate=1#c87">
             15+ / 0-
            </a>
            )

             </a>

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:110896">

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:111567">
              Roger Fox
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:183265">
              Hopeful Skeptic
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:215586">
              erush1345
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:289230">
              Margd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:298633">
              cryonaut
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Has anyone contacted Dr. Huber about this?
           </p>
           <p>
            Bogus alarm.
           </p>
           <p>
            Where are the photomicrographs?
           </p>
           <p>
            Where are the post-mortems on all the miscarried fetuses to determine the details of causation? How about genetic testing on all the live births to look for defects?
           </p>
           <p>
            Usual miscarriage rates in cattle are up to 30% before 6 weeks and drop to 6% thereafter [wiki search]. So in a cohort of 1,000 you could expect a goodly number - at least 60 m/c's under 'normal' circumstances - not zero.
           </p>
           <p>
            What could motivate someone to make up such a story?
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>

           <li id="c118">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40510142">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               I hope for Don Huber's sake
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40510142#c118?mode=alone;showrate=1#c118">
                2+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:1625">
                 opendna
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:127703">
                 Karl Rover
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               That he is vindicated one way or the other. If he wrote the letter, I hope he and the team he is supposedly working with submit a thorough paper that withstands peer review and he gains the recognition he would deserve for discovering a new class of organism.
              </p>
              <p>
               Or, alternately, I hope this is a hoax and Dr. Huber's name is cleared of it.
              </p>
              <p>
               The diary serves a purpose if some one of us can get to the bottom of its claims and verify (or refudiate) the letter. It also got me to do enough research to learn that, yes, there does appear to be a significant amount of research out there on the impairment of plant defenses against fungal infections in the presence of Roundup. Not that I need an excuse to dislike Monsanto, since they're a perfectly repugnant company by policy alone.
              </p>
             </div>

         <li id="c701">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40535026">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             statement on Perdue website
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40535026#c701?mode=alone;showrate=1#c701">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             <a href="http://www.btny.purdue.edu/weedscience/2011/GlyphosatesImpact11.pdf">
              http://www.btny.purdue.edu/...
             </a>
            </p>
            <p>
             <a href="http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/purdue-scientists-refute-anti-gmo-claims/">
              http://www.foodsafetynews.com/...
             </a>
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">

        <li id="c116">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40510131">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Arpad Pusztai
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40510131#c116?mode=alone;showrate=1#c116">
             1+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:99900">
              Seneca Doane
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Anybody remember the study he did which showed deleterious effects on rats (thinning of the epithelium cells in the intestines and weakened immune systems) from eating GMO potatoes? Cost him his job.
           </p>
           <p>
            Have his experiments been replicated? Did anyone even try? His work was published in The Lancet in 1999.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            Solar is civil defense.  Video of my small scale solar experiments at
            <a href="http://solarray.blogspot.com/2006/03/solar-video.html" rel="nofollow">
             solarray
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:50748">
             gmoke
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40510131#c116">
             Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 09:42:24 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40510131">
         <li id="c202">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40512124">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             It was crap science.
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40512124#c202?mode=alone;showrate=1#c202">
              6+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:3388">
               taylormattd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:7787">
               mem from somerville
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:42401">
               murrayewv
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:48175">
               yuriwho
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:76550">
               dirtfarmer
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:122357">
               Kathy S
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Some excerpts:
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             Dr Pusztai's role, as an expert on toxic plant proteins called lectins, was to undertake a series of feeding experiments using GM potatoes and laboratory rats. His particular interest was a lectin called GNA, found in the bulbs of snowdrops, which acts as a natural pesticide. According to Dr Pusztai's report no other lectin-producing GM plants were used in the experiments, although he does say he performed some "analytical" work with GM potatoes expressing another, more toxic lectin, Con A, from the jackbean plant.
             <p>
              This is a key point because, according to an audit investigation into Dr Pusztai's work (ordered by the Rowett following his statements on TV's World in Action), he had become confused over whether he was talking about GM potatoes expressing GNA or ordinary potatoes which had Con A added to them in concentrations 5,000 times greater than would occur naturally. The audit, conducted by four scientists, two from the Rowett and two from outside, concluded that the only time the rats in the Pusztai experiment showed any signs of stunted growth was when they were fed Con A in these high concentrations.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             In other words, he didn't differentiate between a plant engineered to produce a chemical, and another plant which had that chemical
             <em>
              added
             </em>
             to it at levels thousands of times greater than would occur even in an engineered plant.
            </p>
            <p>
             When his initial report was criticized for making such a stupid error, he did a followup one, which is the one most of his supporters hold up. It isn't much better. Here's part of the review by one of the leading food toxicologists in the UK.
             <br/>
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             The food intakes are not adequately described - this data is essential for interpretation of the data. The dietary design of the first three studies is fundamentally flawed, as the diets did not contain adequate amounts of protein and the intake of nutrients and antinutrients differed between the transgenic and control animals.
             <p>
              An intake of 100g protein/kg diet is regarded as the minimum amount for growing rats, and results in some degree of malnutrition, particularly when under stress such as pregnancy. Most commercial rat diets contain protein at 200g/kg diet to support normal growth. The first three studies use between 55.6 and 72.5g protein/kg. This level of protein was not adequate to sustain normal growth and development in the rats. The transgenic potatoes contained 20 per cent less protein than the parent variety but it appears no attempt was made to ensure that the protein content of the diets was similar. Thus differences between the parent variety and the transgenic animals could be attributed to differences in protein intake.
             </p>
             <p>
              It is unclear why a diet of raw potatoes was used, given that they are renowned for containing high levels of natural toxins. The study generalises conclusions made from the use of raw potatoes to the use cooked potatoes.
             </p>
             <p>
              It is well documented that protein malnutrition in rats leads to decreased growth rate, changes in gut morphology and hepatic atrophy features that were observed in these studies. The report gives the impression that these dietary aspects of the study were considered post hoc. Why were the potatoes not analysed before the diets were formulated? And why was the lower protein content in the transgenic line not compensated for by additional protein?
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             He provided the rats with nutritionally poor food, he fed them raw potatos which are naturally much more toxic (even in non-GM varieties) than they are when cooked--how humans typically eat them--and he didn't control for the different levels of protein between the GM and non-GM varieties.
            </p>
            <p>
             Pure, unadulterated crap. He didn't lose his job because of his results. He lost his job because he was doing a shitty job.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:1463">
              Northwatch
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40512124#c202">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 02:30:56 AM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c116">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>

        <li id="c117">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40510133">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            When I hear
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40510133#c117?mode=alone;showrate=1#c117">
             0+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Someone commenting such things as this man must be suffering from dementia without any evidence what so ever that it is true, I see an effort to discredit someone because they may not agree with some tightly held belief. Think DDT they said similar things about the people who first brought the dangers of using this chemical to light.
           </p>
           <p>
            Don't do it.
           </p>
           <p>
            If in fact something has shown up ignoring it will only make more of a problem. Study prove it true or false. But it is terribly unscientific to jump to some conclusion just because it upsets you to believe there are unintended consiquences to Round up and GMOs. It would not suprise me at all.
           </p>
           <p>
            I tend to believe GMOs are short sighted, there are better ways.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            It is the heart that makes a man rich. He is rich according to what he is not what he has -Henry Ward Beecher
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:263250">
             PSWaterspirit
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40510133#c117">
             Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 09:42:54 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40510133">
         <li id="c177">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40511120">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             No
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40511120#c177?mode=alone;showrate=1#c177">
              9+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:3388">
               taylormattd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:7787">
               mem from somerville
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:17717">
               Paulie200
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:36845">
               kalmoth
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:42998">
               Arcparser
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:48175">
               yuriwho
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:90176">
               whl
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:159657">
               KroneckerD
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:183265">
               Hopeful Skeptic
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I don't think people are casting doubt on this because of "tightly held belief". (presumably on the safety of genetically modified food?)
            </p>
            <p>
             It is because of the nature of the letter and the claims made. I spent an entire semester studying what is science, what is pseudoscience, and what is a crank?
            </p>
            <p>
             He basically claims to have made a discovery that would change much of what we know of biology... It would be one of the most important discoveries in biology. A new organism the size of a virus that is actually some kind of fungus? The size difference between them is immense.
            </p>
            <p>
             He thinks his discovery is extremely important.
            </p>
            <p>
             He offers no evidence and his work is not published in a peer reviewed journal.
            </p>
            <p>
             He doesn't use the proper terminology.
            </p>
            <p>
             What seems more likely- that he has made a groundbreaking discovery and is publishing it online instead of in peer review journals, or that he is wrong?
            </p>
            <p>
             Remember those guys that claimed to have achieved cold fusion and went directly to the media instead of other scientists? Yeah, they were wrong.
            </p>
            <p>
             It is an important subject, but I do not see the kind of evidence needed to back up such a claim.
            </p>
           </div>

          <li id="c286">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40515720">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              I'm not convinced the guy was trying to publish it
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40515720#c286?mode=alone;showrate=1#c286">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>

             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              I believe Jill when she says her friend verified that he wrote it. But he wrote it to Tom V. not the place it was published. We should know who sent it to the publication before making any statements on the man's sanity.
             </p>
             <p>
              Secondly, I'm not certain that this is the final letter that was sent to Tom V. He's said he wrote it, but has he said this is the final form of the letter?
             </p>
             <p>
              Really, we need to know those intervening things before we can broadly condemn a guy that seems to be a decent scientist. And then, I still want clarification on what was meant in the letter. I'm not convinced we should ignore him completely. There isn't enough information to do that. I do agree that much of the letter needs clarification and definition before I'd take the letter at face value either.
             </p>
             <p>
              I'm willing to listen more, I'm not saying I'm convinced either way.

        <li id="c119">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40510159">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            What the hell is it
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40510159#c119?mode=alone;showrate=1#c119">
             5+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:2101">
              northsylvania
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:17717">
              Paulie200
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:25308">
              peraspera
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:36845">
              kalmoth
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:99900">
              Seneca Doane
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            .. a virus? A prion?
           </p>
           <p>
            If it's fungus, haplophasea it
            <em>
             is
            </em>
            possible, but unlikely to be
            <em>
             caused
            </em>
            by some chemical spray. The spray could set up conditions to make it more likely for a particular type of microfungal infection to flourish, but that would require some type of study. It's been 30 years since I took microbiology, so you'll have to excuse my ignorance. It could micro spores, like nosema that attack honeybees, I guess.
           </p>
           <p>
            Interesting, but more work is required to prove cause and effect, a lot more work.
           </p>
           <p>
            "Implicated". "linked with" are hypothesis, not valid conclusions backed by any metrics; but I am NOT saying it's something to be ignored.
           </p>
           <p>
            Definitely is important to look at.
           </p>
          </div>

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40511188">
          <li id="c394">

            I am sorry...
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40510870#c162?mode=alone;showrate=1#c162">
             10+ / 0-

            </strong>

                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:99900">
                  Seneca Doane
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:135160">
                  forgore
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:219522">
                  BlueDragon
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <blockquote>
                <strong>
                 <a href="http://www.dkosopedia.com/wiki/DailyKos_FAQ#Tag_Guidelines">
                  Tag abuse
                 </a>
                 (changing the tags in a diary to express your editorial opinion of the diary) is a bannable offense.
                </strong>
                <p>
                 First, and most importantly, you need to know that tag abuse is a bannable offense. If an administrator sees you've engaged in tag abuse, you will be formally warned. Repeat abuses can result in banning at any time without a follow-up warning. This diary should be taken as a warning in itself - now that we are unequivocally on the record about this, we will be more willing to take action against tag abusers the first time we see it. So do not express your dislike of a diary or diarist in tags. Reserve that for the comments. Tag abuse includes deletion of tags in order to replace them with "troll diary."
                </p>
               </blockquote>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                "Tacos are like that." - flumptytail
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:205862">
                 JayinPortland
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40511618#c193">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 12:48:34 AM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">

                <a href="#c172">

                </a>

               </p>
              </div>
             </div>

            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40511618">
             <li id="c205">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40512229">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Correct, but the only places
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40512229#c205?mode=alone;showrate=1#c205">
                  3+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                   taylormattd
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                   kalmoth
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                   yuriwho
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 where "tag abuse" is defined involve 1. deleting or editing an existing tag against the diarist's wishes, 2. using tags to express dislike of a diary or diarist, and 3. adding the "troll diary" tag.  yuriwho doesn't think "unsubstantiated rumor" is "an expression of dislike" but a statement of fact, arbitrary of like or dislike. I get that, and I think this is a little fuzzier region than what's outlined by the FAQ - albeit still in the spirit of the law. Which is why I'm asking for rather than demanding a change.
                </p>
               </div>

        <li id="c178">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40511164">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            I don't think Roundup was originally designed to
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40511164#c178?mode=alone;showrate=1#c178">
             2+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:48175">
              yuriwho
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:135160">
              forgore
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            be an agricultural herbicide (i.e. more of a commercial/residential kill-all herbicide). It probably wouldve had more rigorous testing if it was originally designed to be used on food (or feed) crops. I think this also needs to be taken into consideration when addressing the concerns listed in this diary. This should justify a little more caution before expanding its use as an agricultural herbicide, especially when it wasn't originally designed to be used on food/feed crops.
            <br/>
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:132430">
             Mike Taylor
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40511164#c178">
             Thu Feb 24, 2011 at 11:38:53 PM PST

           <p class="cl">

          </div>

        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40511164">
         <li id="c223">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40513257">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             When a compound is registered
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40513257#c223?mode=alone;showrate=1#c223">
              4+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:36845">
               kalmoth
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:42401">
               murrayewv
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:90176">
               whl
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:289230">
               Margd
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             for food use crops it undergoes very extensive testing. If there are data base deficiencies these are filled or very stringent safety factors added. Pesticides periodically undergo reregistrations, when any older data are brought up to modern standards through requiring new testing.
            </p>
           </div>

        <li id="c183">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40511316">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            academic issues aside
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40511316#c183?mode=alone;showrate=1#c183">
             4+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:1625">
              opendna
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:25308">
              peraspera
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:38760">
              Noisy Democrat
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:76550">
              dirtfarmer
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Yes, a memo is admittedly not a peer reviewed and replicable piece of research.
            <br/>
            However, I would
            <em>
             really
            </em>
            like to hear if: sudden death syndrome (SDS) in soy, and Goss wilt in corn, is driving down farmers' yields appreciably, and if infertility rates in dairy heifers of over 20%, and spontaneous abortions in cattle as high as 45% are common or even extant. When I type in the phrase as written, it rings every bell on Google. When I put -Roundup, it goes down to seven, all of which do have the word Monsanto. If I type in spontaneous abortions cattle, it turns out that campylobacter is a frequent problem, but that's about it.
            <br/>
            Any farmers here who have a problem with their cattle not attributable to campylobacter? Have your soybeans been up to scratch?
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:2101">
             northsylvania
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40511316#c183">
             Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 12:03:09 AM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40511316">
         <li id="c239">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40513936">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             SDS
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40513936#c239?mode=alone;showrate=1#c239">
              3+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:6472">
               RonV
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:42401">
               murrayewv
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:135160">
               forgore
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             has been adversely affecting soy bean crops around here more than before, and the ag agent doesn't know why.
            </p>
            <p>
             Last year some farmer's plants produced no beans, and others had beans the size on bb's, but that was due to drought. In July, my family's crop was looking like it would be the best ever till the drought hit, but we lucked out and ended up with an average crop. They stopped using round-up ready corn two years ago.
            </p>
            <p>
             Because there are so many factors that can affect crop yield, I believe that more intensive and lengthy studies should be done on GMO beans and corn. The super weeds are unbelievably large and abundant.
            </p>
            <p>
             There has been much speculation in this ag community over what has been causing SDS in the bean crops. I won't jump to any conclusions from this diary, but you can bet I'll be keeping my eyes and ears open for more info on it.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:70499">
              Loonesta
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40513936#c239">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:39:49 AM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c183">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40513936">
          <li id="c294">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40516278">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              early season rainfall
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40516278#c294?mode=alone;showrate=1#c294">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                yuriwho
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Thanks to climate change, there has been an increase in early season rainfall in much of the major soybean producing area in the US, and this favors SDS.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
