               Arcparser
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:110896">
               Devsd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:159657">
               KroneckerD
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             we know vaccines cause autism, right, because cranks write stuff on the internet.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Darwinic pilgrims claim the image fills them with an overwhelming feeling of logic.
             <a href="http://onion.com/gg6dZ7" rel="nofollow">
              --The Onion
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40513393#c228">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:44:31 AM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c187">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40513393">
          <li id="c307">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40516894">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              No, we don't know that
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40516894#c307?mode=alone;showrate=1#c307">
               3+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:1625">
                opendna
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:83832">
                OHdog
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                Roger Fox
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              It is very convenient to argue that because something appears on the internet questioning the safety of science, it must be the work of cranks, but you know that that isn't true. You likely know the prominent counterexamples yourself.
             </p>
             <p>
              I see things in the letter that make me suspicious -- the rate of spontaneous abortions in the comparison group, the weird bit about micro-fungus. They do not lead me to think that this must have no basis at all simply because this letter to Vilsack did not itself meet the standards of publishable work. People sometimes express themselves poorly; the stakes are high enough here that it makes sense to investigate.
             </p>
             <p>
              The scientist doesn't know exactly how things could be going wrong. But,
              <em>
               if
              </em>
              there is some relationship between Roundup Ready and bad effects, saying that we should not worry about it because we can't explain why it would be happening is
              <em>
               anti
              </em>
              -scientific. The model doesn't always come before the data that requires the model.
             </p>
             <p>
              A scientist asks, when the metaphorical chocolate bar melts in his or her lab coat pocket, why the hell something happened. The scientist doesn't have to start with a hypothesis about the potential of microwaves as a heating source.
             </p>
             <p>
              <em>
               Not
              </em>
              going forward and figuring out if what this guy says is going on on the ground in completely bogus -- if the data is cooked, as with the autism case, or if he's missing something significant in his analysis other than the "fact" that this can't be happening -- is lousy science. Great commerce, maybe, but lousy science.
             </p>
             <p>
              By the way, I heard an interview on NPR yesterday with the guy who made the documentary on fracking and water pollution that's up for the Oscar. A called triumphantly said "this can't be a problem, because the fracking takes place under the bedrock a mile down, way below the groundwater, so the toxic chemicals can't be in the drinking water!" (This despite findings that ...
              <em>
               these toxic chemicals are in people's drinking water
              </em>
              ? Faced with this irrefutable scientific fact that fracking takes place below where groundwater is, the filmmaker said "yeah, the hypothesis is that some leaks out of the pipes on the way up."
             </p>
             <p>
              Makes sense, huh? Could be wrong -- could be refutable -- but sensible!
             </p>
             <p>
              Now who was being more scientific -- the person who said "theory proves this can't be true" or the guy who said "here are the groundwater readings, they need to be explained, and here's one hypothesis that might be true, but if it's not this then there must be another explanation, because here's the data about people's water and these chemicals appear where and only where there's fracking"?
             </p>
             <p>
              Boiled down to its essentials, this guy is saying "something weird is going on here and it suggests that scientists don't understand something important about the effects of this substance." A scientist should
              <em>
               listen
              </em>
              to that, eh?
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">

               <p>
                I heard a ten-minute interview, with listener call-ins, on NPR. If you want to go to the website and look for a transcript before you believe my recounting on it, be my guest.
               </p>
               <p>
                I don't know if the letter is true in whole or part. I'm saying that it presents a statistical association that warrants review, regardless of whether this guy's hypothesis is brilliant or crackers. You disagree?
               </p>
               <p>
                I'll grant you "unsubstantiated." "Laughably incorrect" is just calumny. As for "possibly fictional," well, we're all "possibly" all sorts of things, aren't we?

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40518338">
              <li id="c472">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40521645">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  OK, you started off by deriding an interview with
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40521645#c472?mode=alone;showrate=1#c472">
                   0+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  someone who made an Oscar-nominated documentary about fracking, and then took a very reasonable seeming "scientific objection" to his work and immediately pulverized it, as just "something heard on NPR," so I haveto doubt the subtlety of the distinctions you're willing to make here. But, to go on:
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  (1) I'd like to think that you would distinguish between a member of a panel reporting to the SecAg and a crank off the street, but your colleague tomcat says that there's not necessarily much difference, which I find shocking if true.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  If by "data" you mean a series of numbers in a spreadsheet (or even comma-delimited plaintext), then you're right: there was no data there. What there was in the letter were assertions of the type "where variable X exists, variable Y changes in certain ways" (including some numbers, admittedly subject to doubt, about different rates of spontaneoua abortion in cattle.) That is an allusion to and an explanation of relationships within a dataset. So when you say that there is no data there, I don't know what you mean. There are assertions of relationships between measurable variables, which is normally what we see in summaries ofscience n policy discussions.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  You give the sense of trying to squelch thoghtcrime on this issue. I prefer debate that engages th subject rather than saying, in an ever-more certain tone, that there's nothing to see here so move along.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  Unplug the Koch machine! It's
                  <strong>
                   swallowing people's money!
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">

              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40521645">
               <li id="c486">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40522095">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Perhaps you have forgotten
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40522095#c486?mode=alone;showrate=1#c486">
                    6+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:13650">
                     Free Radical
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                     kalmoth
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                     yuriwho
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                     xgz
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                     KroneckerD
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                     cryonaut
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   you began this thread with a snarky and vacuous comment supporting this tripe.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   I merely pointed out that similar tripe provided by anti-vaxxers (or climate deniers, or any other anti-science types) should be summarily dismissed for information of this quality.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   You provided some totally unrelated story that you heard on the radio. I have no idea whether there is quality chemistry and testing underneath that. And it's really not relevant to this discussion.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   But I don't care if you don't like my perspective. Let's hear from the
                   <a href="http://cookingupastory.com/purported-letter-from-dr-don-huber-to-secretary-vilsack-possibly-a-fraud">
                    chair of Huber's department
                   </a>
                   :
                  </p>
                  <blockquote>
                   Peter Goldsbrough, professor and head of the Department of Botany and Plant Pathology at Purdue University where Dr. Huber had taught prior to his retirement 3 years ago, indicated by phone his skepticism over the authenticity of the letter, and most of the information contained within it.
                   <p>
                    Professor Goldsbrough stated that he, and the colleagues in his department, are not aware of any new pathogen that has been identified. The letter states in part:
                   </p>
                   <blockquote>
                    A team of senior plant and animal scientists have recently brought to my attention the discovery of an electron microscopic pathogen that appears to significantly impact the health of plants, animals, and probably human beings .
                   </blockquote>
                   <br/>
                   Goldsbrough explained, not only would it be highly unusual for a single pathogen (within the same species) to pass across multiple species barriers, its claims about the deleterious effects of glyphosate on the production of certain crops, he and his fellow colleagues also found to be suspect. The letter goes on to say:
                   <blockquote>
                     It is well-documented that glyphosate promotes soil pathogens and is already implicated with the increase of more than 40 plant diseases; it dismantles plant defenses by chelating vital nutrients; and it reduces the bioavailability of nutrients in feed, which in turn can cause animal disorders.
                   </blockquote>
                   Professor Goldsbrough stated, There are claims made that the use of Roundup and glyphosate, and the roundup ready system is causing significant declines in yield to some crops, and an increased incidence of diseases in some crops. The pathologists that I work with in this department, have no evidence for those claims. He went on to say, this organism that is claimed is a complete mystery, and many of these other things claimed to be connections between this organism, the use of roundup, the use of roundup ready crops, are completely unsubstantiated, and Im not aware of any evidence for these claims"
                  </blockquote>
                  <p>
                   You can continue to defend this non-substantive letter, and Jill's promotion of it. It's a free country. I'm just sad for you that your loyalty to Jill or your desire for this to have substance is clouding your judgment on this. I find it hard to ally with people who are that gullible.
                  </p>
                 </div>

                   <p class="cl">
                    [
                    <a href="#c486">
                     Parent
                    </a>
                    ]
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522354">
                 <li id="c548">
                  <div class="cx" id="cx40523618">
                   <h5>
                    <a class="de">
                    </a>
                    <span class="cu">
                     It is awful.
                    </span>
                    <span class="crd ntb">
                     (
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40523618#c548?mode=alone;showrate=1#c548">
                      5+ / 0-
                     </a>
                     )
                    </span>
                   </h5>
                   <div class="crs">
                    <dl>
                     <dt>
                      Recommended by:
                     </dt>
                     <dd>
                      <a href="/user/uid:11236">
                       tomcat
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                       kalmoth
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                       yuriwho
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                       xgz
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                       cryonaut
                      </a>
                     </dd>
                    </dl>
                   </div>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     But let's face it--Jill won. This will be embedded in people's minds forever, no matter how much debunking there is now, or there will be coming.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     And when the department comes out and disowns him? Well, you know how that will go--it will be a big conspiracy by the big M...suppressing the troof, as always.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Jill is a master of propaganda, I'll concede. Someday I hope she'll have an awakening. But I'll bet it doesn't happen. And it will be too late. The damage will be done.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     On the other hand--the rest of the world is really ignoring the anti-science cranks on this for the most part now. Japan has approved GMOs, EU is caving. Developing countries are all over this stuff.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     I think this is a last gasp, flailing as they go down.
                    </p>
                   </div>

                     <a href="http://onion.com/gg6dZ7" rel="nofollow">

                     </a>
                    </p>
                    <p class="cb">

                     <a href="/user/uid:7787">

                 <li id="c557">
                  <div class="cx" id="cx40523947">
                   <h5>
                    <a class="de">
                    </a>
                    <span class="cu">
                     Monsanto hasnt sold GE Wheat yet
                    </span>
                    <span class="crd ntb">
                     (
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40523947#c557?mode=alone;showrate=1#c557">
                      1+ / 0-
                     </a>
                     )
                    </span>
                   </h5>
                   <div class="crs">
                    <dl>
                     <dt>
                      Recommended by:
                     </dt>
                     <dd>
                      <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                       xgz
                      </a>
                     </dd>
                    </dl>
                   </div>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     Cant study what dont exist.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/04/us-monsanto-wheat-gmo-idUSTRE6A34K220101104">
                      http://www.reuters.com/...
                     </a>
                    </p>
                   </div>
                   <div class="cf">
                    <p class="sig">
                     FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
                    </p>
                    <p class="cb">
                     by
                     <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                      Roger Fox
                     </a>
                     on
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40523947#c557">
                      Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 03:26:58 PM PST
                     </a>
                    </p>
                    <p class="cl">
                     [
                     <a href="#c499">
                      Parent
                     </a>
                     ]
                    </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </ul>
              </ul>
             </ul>
            </ul>
           </ul>
           <li id="c335">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40517510">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Not a valid comparison
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40517510#c335?mode=alone;showrate=1#c335">
                3+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                 mem from somerville
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                 kalmoth
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                 whl
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Let's look at these two situations.
              </p>
              <p>
               With fracking, people clearly noticed a problem with their groundwater. Laboratory testing reveals contamination, although you admittedly don't generally need lab testing when that lady in Pennsylvania can light her tap water on fire. The industry position, naturally, is that everything's fine, citizen, move along. I know what
               <em>
                I
               </em>
               think the reality is here, but, from a science perspective, you have an observed phenomenon, and a hypothesis, and it's research time.
              </p>
              <p>
               With Huber's claims, you have nothing of the sort. Huber claims to have discovered a totally novel life-form, a virus-scale entity capable of independent reproduction. If any of this was real and verifiable, that's when Huber would have published. Because that's ... well, it's probably biochemically impossible. But if we pretend that such an organization existed, discovering it means that, at a minimum, you just got published in your choice of absolute top-tier journals. Huber made it into
               <em>
                Plant Physiology
               </em>
               once. A publication in
               <em>
                Nature
               </em>
               or
               <em>
                Science
               </em>
               would have been the breakthrough shot of his lifetime. And, frankly, if that discovery held up, you really are talking Nobel Prize. But ... he didn't publish that data. Instead, he seemingly started to look for it in all kinds of random places. Huber's letter proposes that this sooper-sekrit organism is everywhere: from cows to corn, from sows to soybeans, and at "high concentrations." Again, that's the sort of claim that, if you could back it up at all, would make you an overnight celebrity -- not just in your field, but in science as a whole. But he passed on that shot, because instead he did more studies to show that this organism was pathological, and then MORE studies to show that its growth was enhanced by the presence of the Roundup resistant gene in GMO agricultural products.
              </p>
              <p>
               Why? Why would you DO that? Why would you risk getting scooped on a discovery that would literally revolutionize modern biology in order to take the time to explore its connections to herbicide resistance? For that matter, why wasn't he scooped on this discovery? American agribusiness is only one of the most highly studied fields in ... oh,
               <strong>
                ever
               </strong>
               . If this was real, whoever hit the journals with it would have their name listed right after
               <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martinus_Beijerinck">
                Martinus Beijerinck
               </a>
               and
               <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_B._Prusiner">
                Stanley B. Prusiner
               </a>
               .
              </p>
              <p>
               The answer, of course, is that it isn't real. I would put cash money on the table that he's observed artifacts of electron microscopy, a known and serious problem with the process, especially for biological specimens. He never published the world-altering intermediate steps (and isn't publishing this) because he's wrong. Because he's, in the immortal words of Wolfgang Pauli,
               <em>
                not even wrong
               </em>
               .
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                Serpents Choice
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40517510#c335">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:51:38 AM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c307">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40517510">
            <li id="c356">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40518194">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                This was a letter to the Sec. of Agriculture
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40518194#c356?mode=alone;showrate=1#c356">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                saying "hold off on this, something is wrong." It wasn't submitted to
                <em>
                 Nature
                </em>
                . It was presented, prematurely as matter of science, to influence policy. The electron microscope aspect of it isn't my focus. The "is there evidence that Roundup appears to be having effects such as increasing the spontaneous abortion rate etc.?" that is my focus.
               </p>
               <p>
                I honestly don't care about his model. I care about whether there is
                <em>
                 something
                </em>
                -- by whatever previously unknown path -- that is going on here that should affect policy. Even nuts, if he is one, can note something that requires attention.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                Unplug the Koch machine! It's
                <strong>
                 swallowing people's money!
                </strong>
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:99900">
                 Seneca Doane
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40518194#c356">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 10:23:51 AM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c335">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k40518194">
             <li id="c368">
              <div class="cx" id="cx40518546">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Smoke and mirrors
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40518546#c368?mode=alone;showrate=1#c368">
                  11+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:1276">
                   NorthCountryNY
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                   mem from somerville
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:11236">
                   tomcat
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                   kalmoth
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                   yuriwho
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:76550">
                   dirtfarmer
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                   whl
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                   lostboyjim
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                   KroneckerD
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                   Margd
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                   cryonaut
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 You cannot, to use an appropriate metaphor, separate the wheat from the chaff here. There is no wheat, only chaff.
                </p>
                <p>
                 He claims that Roundup is causing an increase in a novel pathogen, resulting in increasing spontaneous abortion of cattle. You say that you're not interested in the mechanism -- the amazingly-unlikely pathogen -- but just the outside parts of that claim. Is Roundup causing an increase in the spontaneous abortion of cattle?
                </p>
                <p>
                 Even that is the wrong question to ask.
                 <em>
                  Is there an increase
                 </em>
                 in the spontaneous abortion of cattle at all? Except for some outbreaks of brucellosis in the past few years, a quick review of published literature provides no evidence that such a trend exists. Agribusiness, as I'm sure you know, is something of a big-money industry. If there was an unusual number of failed pregnancies in domestic cattle herds, that would have been Story One in any of a dozen or more journals and ever farming and ranching publication in the country.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Infertility in dairy cattle? Well, there was a fungus -- a real one, grows on stored corn, called
                 <em>
                  Fusarium graminearum
                 </em>
                 -- linked to in a study in 1968. Some talk about high-protein diets contributing to it in the mid-1990s. Nothing about rising trends in diary cattle infertility.
                </p>
                <p>
                 So, in fact, not only is his connection wrong, but I don't even see evidence of what he's trying to connect
                 <em>
                  to
                 </em>
                 . That's not surprising, though. Any time you run across someone who jumps into this sort of pseudoscience, you have to assume that even the sane-sounding parts of their evidence are suspect, inadequately controlled, quoted out of context, or outright fabricated. Bad science begets bad science. And, again, if any of the research he claims to have done worked the way he said it does, he'd've gotten published ages before he was even able to see the connections he's proposing.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                  Serpents Choice
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/949492/40518546#c368">
                  Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 10:41:00 AM PST
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c356">
                  Parent
                 </a>
                 ]
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </li>
             <ul class="cm i1" id="k40518546">

                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">

                 <div class="ct">

                  </p>
                  <p>
                   It's a sad, vicious cycle of revenge.
                  </p>

                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">

                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by

               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40518660">
                <li id="c377">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40518752">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    onoz!
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40518752#c377?mode=alone;showrate=1#c377">
                     2+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                      mem from somerville
                     </a>
                     ,
                     <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                      lostboyjim
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    <a href="http://img815.imageshack.us/i/680245274c5625x1000.jpg/" target="_blank" title="ImageShack - Image And Video Hosting">
                     <img border="0" src="http://img815.imageshack.us/img815/1783/680245274c5625x1000.jpg"/>
                    </a>
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    (image source:
                    <a href="http://www.worth1000.com/entries/625388/cow-abduction">
                     worth1000.com
                    </a>
                    )
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                     kalmoth
                    </a>
                    on
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40518752#c377">
                     Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 10:50:29 AM PST
                    </a>
                   </p>
                   <p class="cl">
                    [
                    <a href="#c375">
                     Parent
                    </a>
                    ]
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
               </ul>
              </ul>
              <li id="c418">
               <div class="cx" id="cx40519942">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  If you are under the impression
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40519942#c418?mode=alone;showrate=1#c418">
                   0+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  that asking whether there
                  <em>
                   is
                  </em>
                  an actual increase in the incidence of spontaneous abortion in cattle (at least, and especially where there is reason to believe there could be, an effect of use of Roundup, Roundup Ready crops, and their sequelae) is
                  <em>
                   not
                  </em>
                  part of the process of examining whether there is a relationship between another variable and thatvariable, then I am happy to disabuse you of that notion.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I'm saying that one investigates -- with a jaundiced eye towards the possibility of mistakes and misrepresentations on both sides -- all variables and their relationships. There's no evidence of the greater abortions? Great -- that substantially undermines his argument, if true.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Under a cultural scientific regime in which the implausible gets hooted off the stage without a chance to be heard, we lose a lot of useful, interesting, and yes disturbing and challenging information. (Given time, I'll tell a story about Lamarckism.) I'm not saying the guy is right, I'm saying that I want to understand whether part of what he's saying maybe true, regardless of whether some is weird.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  Unplug the Koch machine! It's
                  <strong>
                   swallowing people's money!
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:99900">
                   Seneca Doane
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/949492/40519942#c418">
                   Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 11:52:20 AM PST
                  </a>
                 </p>
                 <p class="cl">
                  [
                  <a href="#c368">
                   Parent
                  </a>
                  ]
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <ul class="cm i1" id="k40519942">
               <li id="c453">
                <div class="cx" id="cx40521076">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Bottom line
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40521076#c453?mode=alone;showrate=1#c453">
                    8+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                     mem from somerville
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                     yuriwho
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                     lostboyjim
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                     KroneckerD
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:183265">
                     Hopeful Skeptic
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:197542">
                     docmidwest
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                     Margd
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                     cryonaut
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   What in this letter is there to even consider being true? The more I read over it, the more I hope that it's a hoax, rather than the sort of sad pseudoscientific state of affairs that claims some researchers near the end of their careers.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   In order to even consider a connection between two things, you have to have at least one thing. It's bad science to just wander around, willy-nilly, testing things to see if they go together. Sometimes you can munge the data to support that, but it's never a sound conclusion. What is even here to start with? Let's count the number of studies (and papers) that should already exist for this to be possible.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   It starts out trying to connect glyphosate-resistant GMOs with this bizarre, unproven mystery fungus (BUMF, from here out). There are two missing steps here. #1: Showing this fungus is real. #2: Showing that glyphosate-resistant plants host more of the fungus than non-GMO variants under indentical conditions. In reality, there'd be more papers than that, because you could publish every time you detected it in a grossly differing environment. But, moving on...
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   The paper then sort of conflates glyphosate-resistant crops with glyphosate itself. You can't have it both ways. Roundup-ready means it won't die if you spray it with Roundup, not that it contains Roundup. So missing study #3: Compare glyphosate-resistant plants with no herbicide application to untreated, but glyphosate-resistant controls.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Then it claims BUMF is more prevalent in crops affected by Goss's Wilt or by SDS. That's missing studies #4 and #5.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Then it claims BUMF
                   <em>
                    also
                   </em>
                   places animals at higher risk of spontaneous abortion, thus explaining the increasing spontaneous abortion rate. Whew, this one's a mess. Study #6 should have determined if there IS an increase in spontaneous abortions in animals, because you can't cause something that isn't real. Study #7 would have actually done population comparisons.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   If anything in this letter wasn't ... well, bullshit, then study #8 would have repeated study #7, because that 0/1000 abortion rate in the control meant that no one is ever going to take your control seriously. It might also be nice to know where that wheat silage "which likely had been under weed management using glyphosate" came from, since glyphosate-resistant wheat wasn't made commercially available (Greenpeace threw a little party when Monsanto shelved it in 2004).
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   You'd need at least one additional study per target species to show that the BUMF was actually pathogenic and not just coincidentally present. Ironically, the letter claims that one of these is being done, but ...
                  </p>
                  <blockquote>
                   Preliminary results from ongoing research have also been able to reproduce abortions in a clinical setting.
                  </blockquote>
                  <p>
                   Animal studies typically require approval by an oversight board. No research center in the country would green-light a study to test whether the presence of a substance (here, the BUMF) would induce abortions in cattle without there being a prior publication trail detailing the existence of that substance and suggesting a relationship. None. Zero. This study, one of the few that the letter purports to reference,
                   <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Almost_surely">
                    almost surely
                   </a>
                   does not exist.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   The whole thing is wrong. It's either made up or delusional or both. Nothing of merit can come through it.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                    Serpents Choice
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40521076#c453">
                    Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 12:52:38 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c418">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>

                 l, it tells you to be careful what kind of water you use to mix the round up with, because if you use river water, the round up will bind with the silt in the water and make the whole batch of round up useless.

          <li id="c302">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40516539">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Rather than take you on directly here, matt
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40516539#c302?mode=alone;showrate=1#c302">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:205862">
                JayinPortland
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              let me ask you: how do you know what I know about the GMO issue?
             </p>
             <p>
              Would you like to discuss the new head of the AAAS, who was advisor to both Condi Rice and Hillary on science issues and who is unscientifically (in my opinion as a trained scientist) rigid and extreme on these issues?
             </p>
             <p>
              Would you like to discuss the question of the likely etiology of a problem with GMO products from an evolutionary perspective, dealing with the pace of change and the ability of creatures from insects to worms to smaller creatures to adapt to new substances in their diets? Would you like to discuss the extent to which the effects of GMO products are even testable
              <em>
               in theory
              </em>
              ?
             </p>
             <p>
              Please do elaborate on how little I know about how profit can pervert science.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">

              <strong>

          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40516539">
           <li id="c305">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40516874">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Not the problem with this letter and diary
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40516874#c305?mode=alone;showrate=1#c305">
                7+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                 taylormattd
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                 mem from somerville
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                 kalmoth
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                 lostboyjim
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                 KroneckerD
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:197542">
                 docmidwest
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                 Margd
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               This diary, and the letter it features, are not about responsible objections to GMO crops, or even objections to Monsanto's business practices.
              </p>
              <p>
               This diary is about a letter than presents a patently implausible claim, presented in a manner that virtually guarantees it is pseudoscientific hokem. Daily Kos is intended to be a reality-based community. This letter does not -- and demonstrably
               <em>
                cannot
               </em>
               -- represent reality.
              </p>
              <p>
               It should not matter whether you support or oppose GMO, whether you support or oppose Monsanto. This is bad reporting about worse science, and we, as a liberal community that purports to value reality and reasons, should want none of it.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
              </p>

            <li id="c311">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40517012">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Let me ask you one thing:
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40517012#c311?mode=alone;showrate=1#c311">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                Do you rule out the possibility, based on the above, that there is an apparently association, possibly causal, between these activities and certain other things (like spontaneous abortions, even if he misreported aspects of them) on the ground?
               </p>
               <p>
                If you accept that this is worth investigating, then everything else is beside the point. I don't know enough microbiology to know whether his theory is plausible or not. If he's right about the
                <em>
                 association
                </em>
                , even if he's a crank about his explanation of it, then this absolutely does deserve to see the light of day.
               </p>

                 Absolutely not

               <div class="ct">
                <blockquote>
                 If he's right about the association, even if he's a crank about his explanation of it, then this absolutely does deserve to see the light of day.
                </blockquote>
                <p>
                 I absolutely, and without reservation, discount any statement based on his letter other than to say that its claims are,
                 <em>
                  at best
                 </em>
                 , completely wrong. The microbiology is wrong. The chemistry is wrong. Hell, the imaging process he claims to use doesn't even work in a way that makes any sense to be used in this manner at all. There's no there there; there is nothing of substance in that letter to bring into the light of day.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Trends in actual plant disease, like SDS, are clearly worthy of study. Unsurprisingly, they're already being studied, by people doing real science that makes sense. If there
                 <em>
                  were
                 </em>
                 upward trends in the spontaneous abortion rate of cattle, which I see no evidence of in the literature (and which the cattle industry would absofreakinglutely report on if it were true),
                 <em>
                  that
                 </em>
                 would be researched by people doing real science that makes sense.
                 <br/>
                </p>

                     This "panel" a small group of people that volunteer to do an assessment. There is no prestige or credence given to an individual member of the group. No member of the panel or any other credible scientist is going along with him.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     It is the diarist who took a weird off-the-wall letter and presented it to the Kos community as something of scientific relevance. And I am astounded at how people have fallen for this hoax.

                   <li id="c449">

                     <h5>
                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       Professional Societies
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/949492/40520959#c449?mode=alone;showrate=1#c449">
                        2+ / 0-
                       </a>
                       )
                      </span>
                     </h5>
                     <div class="crs">
                      <dl>
                       <dt>
                        Recommended by:
                       </dt>
                       <dd>
                        <a href="/user/uid:135733">
                         lostboyjim
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="/user/uid:289230">
                         Margd
                        </a>
                       </dd>
                      </dl>
                     </div>
                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       I am not sure what you mean by a "learned society", but professional societies like APS have tons of committees and volunteer work to do, and pretty much any member who wants to help can find a place. Simply being a member of APS or a volunteer on one of their committees doesn't give them prestige or credence.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       APS has thousands of members, and they can't be expected to control the ramblings and conspiracy theories of each of their members.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Don Huber does not have an elected position or any other prestigious place in APS. He's just a retired member who was never very prominent or well-known. Now his own colleagues at Purdue are disavowing his statements.
                      </p>

              <p>
               I literally have no idea what you are trying to say.
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               Would you like to discuss the new head of the AAAS, who was advisor to both Condi Rice and Hillary on science issues and who is unscientifically (in my opinion as a trained scientist) rigid and extreme on these issues?
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               Is this paragraph trying to leave kossacks with the impression that you are the new head of the AAAS? Or are you trying to say you know the person who is the new head of the AAAS, and wish to arrange for them to speak to me? If you do know the person who is the new head of the AAAS, you have spoken with this person about Huber's letter, and this person thinks the letter is perfectly fine?

            <li id="c719">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40537466">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                You may want to hire a translator, then:
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40537466#c719?mode=alone;showrate=1#c719">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                Here, I'll give you this one for free.
               </p>
               <p>
                You said originally:
               </p>
               <blockquote>
                I know Jill is your friend (1+ / 0-)
                <br/>
                but you have no idea what you are talking about here.
               </blockquote>
               <p>
                You imply that I'm just recommending this because Jill is a friend -- strike one -- but also that I have no idea what I'm talking about when it comes to GMO. That's strike two.
               </p>
               <p>
                I reply that I'm willing "to discuss the new head of the AAAS," who is "rigid and extreme
                <strong>
                 on these issues
                </strong>
                ". (Emphasis added because apparently it didn't click for you that "these issues" means the safety of GMO products.)
               </p>
               <p>
                You reply with three question, which I'll lovingly address in turn:
               </p>
               <p>
                (1)
                <em>
                 Is the paragraph trying to imply that I'm the new head of the AAAS?
                </em>
               </p>
               <p>
                No. Had it been, it would have said "with me, the new head of the AAAS," or some such. You inserted that word "with" in your head. It's not there. Check.
               </p>
               <p>
                (2)
                <em>
                 Do I know the person who is the new head of the AAAS are want to arrange for you to speak with them?
                </em>
               </p>
               <p>
                No. Again, that would be discussing "this issue
                <strong>
                 with
                </strong>
                " Nina Federoff, President-Elect of AAAS, rather than discussing Dr. Federoff and her attitudes, which a plain reading of the sentence would show was the actual offer.
               </p>
               <p>
                (3)
                <em>
                 Have I spoken with Dr. Federoff about the letter and found that she thought it was fine?
                </em>
               </p>
               <p>
                No and no. I heard a lengthy radio interview with her that touched on GMO products where she demonstrated the rigidity and extremism that I offered to discuss. I have absolutely no doubt that she would dismiss this letter out of hand. I also have little doubt that she'd do so even if made a stronger case.
               </p>
               <p>
                I'd say more here, but first: do you understand what I did and didn't say?
               </p>

           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40513786#c234?mode=alone;showrate=1#c234">
             19+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:3388">
              taylormattd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:11236">
              tomcat
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:27328">
              Iberian
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:27571">
              Beelzebud
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:36845">
              kalmoth
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:42998">
              Arcparser
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:56544">
              GreyHawk
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:56799">
              skralyx
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:76550">
              dirtfarmer
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90176">
              whl
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:110896">
              Devsd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:111567">
              Roger Fox
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:122357">
              Kathy S
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:159657">
              KroneckerD
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:175912">
              cdkipp
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:183265">
              Hopeful Skeptic
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:289230">
              Margd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:298633">
              cryonaut
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Let's ignore the bit about Roundup Ready crops. Let's just look at the base claims of the letter.
           </p>
           <p>
            This letter purports to have discovered not just a new organism, but an entirely new kind of organism -- the size of a not-very-large virus but with behavior like a fungus. It goes on to claim that this weird mini-fungus is pathogenic to ... well, everything, including both diverse species of plants
            <em>
             and
            </em>
            hugely unrelated groups of animals. It goes on to sow panic; this disease is of epidemic proportions already. It's everywhere! It's infecting everything! Run for your lives!!
           </p>
           <p>
            Pardon my bluntness here. Are you fucking kidding me?
           </p>
           <p>
            This is biologically impossible. The only pathogens that size are viruses, which tend to be at least a bit specific about what they can and cannot infect. That's how they work; they hijack a cell's factory, so they can only infect cells with similar sets of machinery. Virus behavior aside, have you ever gotten sick from a plant disease? Anyone you know ever caught chestnut blight, or cedar-apple rust, or sudden oak death, or Dutch elm disease, or ash yellows, or pine blight?
            <strong>
             No.
            </strong>
            The differences between corn and a pig are so monumental as to be impossible to overcome for a pathogen. And, of course, this mystical magical pathogen is simultaneously everywhere, infecting everything, but only this one wackjob has had the foresight to see it?
           </p>
           <p>
            This is crap. This is a conspiracy theory. It would not make this letter any less believable if its author went on to state that this "micro-fungus" also killed JFK.
           </p>
           <p>
            Always --
            <strong>
             always
            </strong>
            -- be suspicious of science by press release when there's no journal publication at its back. Back in DK3, I'd promised that at some point, I'd get a series going here helping lay readers know how to read and evaluation scientific claims. Clearly, I need to hurry that up, because for a "reality-based" community to have fallen for this dreck and given it 257 Recommends at the time of this writing ... is
            <em>
             pathetic
            </em>
            .
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:87455">
             Serpents Choice
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40513786#c234">
             Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:25:04 AM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40513786">
         <li id="c252">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40514290">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I'm with you
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40514290#c252?mode=alone;showrate=1#c252">
              4+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:3388">
               taylormattd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:7787">
               mem from somerville
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:90176">
               whl
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:289230">
               Margd
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I find it very odd that the mere addition of a resistance-marker gene, or the presence of phosphonates (RoundUp), would cause the hyper-proliferation of some hitherto-unencountered form of life. Not impossible, but very, very odd.  I work with biological systems quite a bit, and you just don't see effects this crazy from such innocuous changes. I can't understand why a modestly different phosphate source, or a stretch of DNA that permits the breakdown of that compound into harmless products, would cause some sort of Sorcerer's Apprentice phenomenon. As if this lifeform just couldn't proliferate without phosphonates or a particular stretch of DNA that under most circumstances doesn't even do anything. I just don't get it. I'm not a fan of Monsanto, either, but this looks really strange. I can't wait to see the peer-reviewed article(s), but I get the feeling that may never happen.....
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:56799">
              skralyx

         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40514290">
          <li id="c256">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40514386">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              And the connection to Roundup
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40514386#c256?mode=alone;showrate=1#c256">
               7+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:3388">
                taylormattd
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                mem from somerville
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:56799">
                skralyx
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:88255">
                xgz
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:90176">
                whl
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                Roger Fox
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:122357">
                Kathy S
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              ...is so far down the list of things wrong with this letter that I haven't even addressed it. In order for there to be a credible method by which the presence of glyphosate or a glyphosate-resistance gene could encourage the growth of this claimed organism, there would have to be a credible method that such a pathogen could exist at all.
             </p>
             <p>
              Which, I should note, there isn't. Claiming that Roundup exposure increases the chance of infection by virus-sized fungi that are pathogenic across multiple kingdoms, while producing totally unrelated symptoms in those various hosts has exactly as much scientific merit as an open letter expressing concern that Roundup is killing the Tooth Fairy.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."

           <li id="c419">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40519984">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Yeah, that multiple symptom thing is a red flag
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40519984#c419?mode=alone;showrate=1#c419">
                1+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                 Roger Fox
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Whenever you see something claimed to cause so many unrelated symptoms, people should immediately be skeptical of that claim.
              </p>
              <p>
               As an example, note the panic over silicone breast implants and the subsequent lawsuits which blamed them for everything under the sun, which was later demonstrated to be complete and total bullshit.
              </p>
             </div>

         <li id="c289">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40515803">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Science Matters
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40515803#c289?mode=alone;showrate=1#c289">

             </a>

            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">

            </p>

           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Michael Weissman
UID 197542
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:197542">
              docmidwest
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40515803#c289">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 08:24:25 AM PST
             </a>
            </p>

           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <li id="c332">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40517456">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Now hold on a moment.
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40517456#c332?mode=alone;showrate=1#c332">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <blockquote>
             This letter purports to have discovered not just a new organism, but an entirely new kind of organism -- the size of a not-very-large virus but with behavior like a fungus. It goes on to claim that this weird mini-fungus is pathogenic to ... well, everything, including both diverse species of plants and hugely unrelated groups of animals...
             <p>
              Pardon my bluntness here. Are you fucking kidding me?
             </p>
             <p>
              This is biologically impossible. The only pathogens that size are viruses, which tend to be at least a bit specific about what they can and cannot infect. That's how they work; they hijack a cell's factory, so they can only infect cells with similar sets of machinery.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             What about mammalian and fungal prions?
            </p>
            <p>
             I have no idea what "fungus-like properties" means, but I'd expect that it's a metaphor to other crop blights being used to describe something which isn't yet understood. If you found a prion which worked on carbohydrates and lived on soy, how would you describe it?
            </p>
            <p>
             I'm not a scientist, and I'm not going to buy into the claims until they're published (and fought over), but a lot of the "impossible!" comments go way too far without evidence.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             <em>
              Groups:
              <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/user/Toolbox" rel="nofollow">
               Toolbox
              </a>
              and
              <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/user/Trolls" rel="nofollow">
               Trolls
              </a>
              ... to preserve the best &amp; the worst of DailyKos.
             </em>
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:1625">
              opendna
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40517456#c332">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:48:50 AM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c234">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40517456">
          <li id="c349">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40518000">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Prions
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40518000#c349?mode=alone;showrate=1#c349">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                mem from somerville
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Other than the fact that they are both prions, mammalian and fungal prions have very little to do with each other. They are certainly not cross-pathogenic.
             </p>
             <p>
              I don't know what "fungus-like properties" means, either, but he claims his novel pathogen is capable of independent reproduction. And for the size range he's claiming, that's just not on.
             </p>
             <p>
              As for the lack of evidence, that's really the problem here. I understand that it is daunting to evaluate scientific claims without the background, but what he's saying here would require a massive rewrite of biology and biochemistry to work. And he brought nothing to the table except a press-release letter that, frankly, reads like a forum screed.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:87455">
               Serpents Choice
              </a>

           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40521157">
            <li id="c461">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40521249">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Reproduction
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40521249#c461?mode=alone;showrate=1#c461">
                 2+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:1625">
                  opendna
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                  kalmoth
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                What prions do isn't considered reproduction. I mean, I see how from a lay perspective, you can think of it that way. But it's very different. Unless a prion encounters the folded-the-other-way version of itself, you'll never get more prions.
               </p>
               <p>
                Cellular life, on the other hand, reproduces, by making copies of itself. And viruses are like that kid in school who always tried to cheat off the paper next to him. They can't reproduce on their own, but they hijack cells and make the cell's construction team build new viruses instead of what it's supposed to be doing.
               </p>
               <p>
                One of the top 3 or 4 most implausible claims in this letter is that something the size of a virus can reproduce the way that a cell does.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                 Serpents Choice
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40521249#c461">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:02:43 PM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c458">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
