        <li id="c276">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40515072">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Scientific Threat
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40515072#c276?mode=alone;showrate=1#c276">
             6+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:42998">
              Arcparser
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:76550">
              dirtfarmer
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90176">
              whl
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:110896">
              Devsd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:135733">
              lostboyjim
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Bogus information contained in the "letter" to the USDA. 50 years of work in the field of pathogens and 40 years working with biological toxicity. Meaning, he's been out of military servitude for 10 years. Any scientist would not say things as, "it has been brought to my attention". That's like saying, "God has brought to my attention". " By Who", "What, "Where", "How", and "Why"? The USDA received that "What" in the letter only. How can it be taken seriously? Everyone knows that the "RR" is a political device used by 'organic' folks to scare people without any science backing them up. So, is this letter the science backing up the organic folks? The fact about 45% of heifers whose mom's feed, or whose dad's feed (its unclear in the letter) on RR having aborted heifers is simply untrue unless it is limited solely to those 1,000 mother's-to-be referred to in the letter. Then, for all the other mother's to be who feed on RR, they are left untouched by the pathogen, or malady.  At least, no other farming operation has reported such unimaginable, fantastic (fantasy) figures. The allegations in the letter are horrifically alarming. It is sad that a person in the business for 50 years is unable to write a letter that can (if he really has the facts) and should be taken seriously by his contemporaries. If what he says in the letter is true, he has done a grave disserivce to mankind because there is no possible way he would write such a letter (with his purported knowledge and experience) without any source information included.
           </p>
          </div>

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            It should matter to people that no evidence is presented. For 15 years we've been eating genetically engineered soy and corn, designed to be resistant to glyphosate. Numerous studies have been done on the herbicide, and every time it has been found to be safe.
           </p>
           <p>
            Now because the internet says there is some new undiscovered life form, people are leaping to persecution. How would anyone know this virus size critter is related to glyphosate? How would they know the life cycle of something that can only be detected under an electron microscope?
           </p>
           <p>
            There is science and then there is politics. Science deals in facts. Politics deals in agendas.
           </p>
           <p>
            Shame on people, who pretend to be defending science, to further their own agenda.
           </p>
           <p>
            This is what I call the anti-left, and it is just as dangerous as the anti-science right.
           </p>

        <li id="c319">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40517241">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Well, I'm a farmer and I grow wheat.
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40517241#c319?mode=alone;showrate=1#c319">
             17+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:4128">
              decembersue
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:27571">
              Beelzebud
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:36845">
              kalmoth
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:48175">
              yuriwho
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:65678">
              pico
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:88255">
              xgz
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90176">
              whl
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:110896">
              Devsd
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:111567">
              Roger Fox
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:127703">
              Karl Rover
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:131391">
              ekyprogressive
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:135733">
              lostboyjim
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:175912">
              cdkipp
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:178286">
              kerflooey
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:183265">
              Hopeful Skeptic
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:298633">
              cryonaut
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            At present there is
            <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/04/us-monsanto-wheat-gmo-idUSTRE6A34K220101104">
             no roundup ready wheat
            </a>
            . So where did this "wheatlege" for the study come from?
           </p>
           <p>
            Why not do the study with roundup ready corn or corn silage? Huge numbers of cattle are fed this stuff. Wouldn't the pathogen be expressed there as well?
           </p>
           <p>
            If the mystery pathogen causes spontaneous abortions at a rate of up to 45%, then US cattle numbers would be decimated by now. Carnivores would be jonesin' for a burger and militant vegans would be dancing in the streets.
           </p>
           <p>
            There
            <strong>
             are
            </strong>
            serious questions about the safety of roundup ready crops. But this letter sounds like a "throw some shit against the wall and hope some of it sticks" version of science. It's difficult to believe it was written by a competent scientist.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:76550">
             dirtfarmer
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40517241#c319">
             Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:37:37 AM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>

        <li id="c322">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40517300">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Damn! That's about the most terrifying
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40517300#c322?mode=alone;showrate=1#c322">
             0+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            report I've ever read. Something like that could have the capacity to wipe out the entire human species, plus many other species of plants and animals.
           </p>
           <p>
            There are several fungus species that cause lethal infections in humans, but they are all limited in range. This one sounds like something that we may be ingesting right now in food from big grocery stores.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            It is a calling...to do things about injustice.... It helps to have a goal. I've always tried to have one.--Ted Kennedy, True Compass
           </p>
           <p class="cb">

           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             It is a calling...to do things about injustice.... It helps to have a goal. I've always tried to have one.--Ted Kennedy, True Compass
            </p>
            <p class="cb">

         </li>
        </ul>
        <li id="c326">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40517344">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            A few thoughts
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40517344#c326?mode=alone;showrate=1#c326">
             8+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:36845">
              kalmoth
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:76550">
              dirtfarmer
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:83832">
              OHdog
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:111567">
              Roger Fox
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:131391">
              ekyprogressive
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:135733">
              lostboyjim
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:289230">
              Margd
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            more about effective communication of science than this particular issue which has already been beaten to death in the comments.
           </p>
           <p>
            I'm a biologist but not a microbiologist. As I read that letter several things jumped out at me - language, methodology, experimental results that made me suspicious. Pretty much all of these I've seen raised in the comments although I haven't seen anyone asking why there's nothing about this organism's DNA. In this day and age that seems a little weird. Do a bit of sequencing and see what it matches. That could give you a smoking gun.
           </p>
           <p>
            I think one thing that nonscientists don't realize is that part of the culture of science is to be critical.  Scientists tear other scientists' work apart all the time, on topics that would baffle most people here as to why anyone would care.
           </p>
           <p>
            Scientists also tend (although certainly not always) to defer to experts in fields outside of their expertise. If I stumbled across something that I thought was completely new in the field of Microbiology I would certainly consult with microbiologists to make sure what I said made sense. Unfortunately this can come across as the argument from authority. I think the conversations here would benefit a lot from a bit of perspective from both sides. If, as a nonscientist, you aren't convinced that the claim of virus-sized fungi is ridiculous you might ask for more background info rather than simply accusing the other party of being close-minded. And scientists should realize that they are communicating with people who don't have their background and that, in a forum like this, they bear more responsibility for providing background into. This does lead to longer comments but maybe more light and less heat.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            "We are normal and we want our freedom" - Bonzos
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:125051">
             matching mole
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40517344#c326">
             Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 09:42:43 AM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40517344">
         <li id="c336">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40517529">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I asked for sequence data
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40517529#c336?mode=alone;showrate=1#c336">
              9+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:36845">

              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:131391">
               ekyprogressive
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:135733">
               lostboyjim
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:289230">
               Margd
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             here:
             <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/comments/949492/40513227#c222">
              http://www.dailykos.com/...
             </a>
            </p>
            <p>
             However, it won't matter. This group wants to believe this unsubstantiated crap. Yet they call for data from the scientists that they won't believe anyway.
            </p>
            <p>
             How can you counter data-free stuff that people really really really want to be true? Nothing matters.
            </p>

             Indeedy, science's great strength
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40520710#c440?mode=alone;showrate=1#c440">
              2+ / 0-
             </a>

              <a href="/user/uid:125051">

              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <blockquote>
             I think one thing that nonscientists don't realize is that part of the culture of science is to be critical.  Scientists tear other scientists' work apart all the time, on topics that would baffle most people here as to why anyone would care.
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             As I'm fond of pointing out, science gives out rather well known awards and acclaim for the act of proving that someone else was
             <em>
              wrong
             </em>
             .
             <br/>
            </p>

        <li id="c389">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40519197">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Sub-topic: Should we HR?
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40519197#c389?mode=alone;showrate=1#c389">
             9+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:27571">
              Beelzebud
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:36845">
              kalmoth
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:48175">
              yuriwho
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:88255">
              xgz
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:111567">
              Roger Fox
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:159657">
              KroneckerD
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:183265">
              Hopeful Skeptic
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:289230">
              Margd
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            After reading all the comments here, I think it appropriate to ask,
            <em>
             "Should we ask the poster to take this diary down, or should we HR this as a conspiracy theory?"
             <br/>
            </em>
           </p>
           <p>
            If RR crops were causing a 45% abortion rate in cattle, the news would be everywhere. It would be obvious in the nations meat supply.
           </p>
           <p>
            Enough biologists have weighed in saying this is an OBVIOUS hoax. Yet here we are on the front page, with hundreds of recs. This is bad for KOS, it's bad for science, it's bad for people who really do oppose Monsanto but have to defend them against this type of fakery. Should we HR?
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            <i>
             Minority rights should never be subject to majority vote.
            </i>
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:135733">
             lostboyjim
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40519197#c389">

            </a>
           </p>

               </p>
               <p>
                The letter cited in the diary has some issues. all covered in the comments. I'll summarize:
               </p>
               <p>
                !) Electron Microscope organism, is an organism of the electron microscope.
               </p>
               <p>
                2)The Letter mentions GE Wheat, which apparently does not exist. This comment makes the case that GE corn and soy are well known and it makes far better science to do studies in soy and corn, as well as provides a link to backup the claim there is no GE wheat..
               </p>
               <p>
                <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/..">
                 http://www.dailykos.com/...
                </a>
                .
               </p>
               <p>
                3)The Letter says that in the study no cows fed hay had miscarriages. Highly unlikely in a sample of 1000 cows.
               </p>
               <p>
                In Summary, If Dr Huber (retired) is of sound mind, I doubt he wrote this letter, the quality of the writing is not that of a PHd. If DR Huber is not of sound mind, this letter has no credibility. And since many might see a diary with 200 recs as an actionable item, they would send the letter to their representatives in DC.
               </p>
               <p>
                I might add that I graduated from Rutgers, in Golf Turf Management, I dont think you need an electron microscope to see fungus or its spores. Which is another thing that raised a red flag for me
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                 Roger Fox
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/949492/40520806#c444">
                 Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 12:38:03 PM PST
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c424">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </ul>

        <li id="c403">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40519385">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Two points to clarify...
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40519385#c403?mode=alone;showrate=1#c403">
             8+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:42998">
              Arcparser
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:57829">
              blue jersey mom
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:76550">
              dirtfarmer
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:135733">
              lostboyjim
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:142468">
              Anne Elk
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:160276">
              TFinSF
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:183265">
              Hopeful Skeptic
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            1. It is entirely possible for an eminent scientist to totally lose his|her shit on some specific issue (Linus Pauling and vitamin C come to mind), and (at least in my opinion) it is unfair to start lobbing
            <em>
             diagnoses
            </em>
            at this scientist. Making wild guesses comes with the job, and it's the function of peer review to shoot the wrong wild guesses (which would be most of them) down. Something getting published in PNAS does not necessarily guarantee it's true (refer to: L. Pauling), however, if it's untrue, it WILL get shot down.
           </p>
           <p>
            3. I don't find a justifiable reason for Kossacks to lose their shit and start screaming at each other in this thread. The preemptive insult against
            <strong>
             mem from somerville
            </strong>
            was particularly nasty.
           </p>
          </div>

           <p class="sig">
           </p>

         <li id="c468">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40521576">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Well, let's be open here.
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40521576#c468?mode=alone;showrate=1#c468">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             You mean the 'preemptive insult' by me.
            </p>
            <p>
             And, admittedly, it was written before I'd even read the boxquoted letter. I got as far as 'GMO' and 'bad news' and knew, mem would be popping up in opposition, no matter how likely or unlikely the rest of the diary was, and, sure enough, I was correct.
            </p>
            <p>
             The letter has some odd wordings, some interesting claims, and I'd love to see the data and the methodologies that would lead to such unusual claims. I do
             <strong>
              not
             </strong>
             accept the claims made out of hand, and am actually dubious about them, but in the spirit of actual scientific inquiry, will hold off on making any rash judgments until such time as data actually shows up, and/or other scientists pop up with information to show that the purported study was either made up out of whole cloth or flawed in its methods.
            </p>
            <p>
             Rest assured though, I neither 'lost my shit' not 'screamed at' anyone.
            </p>
           </div>

                Help Aji!
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                Ezekial 23 20
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40521707#c476">

               </a>
              </p>

             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <li id="c481">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40521976">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               We're talking about the initial comment, right?
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40521976#c481?mode=alone;showrate=1#c481">
                0+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Well, it was certainly cynical and sarcastic, but it was written 'honestly'.
              </p>
              <p>
               Every diary I've read on DK in which GM has been brought up in any sort of negative light, mem has, like clockwork, popped up in opposition extremely quickly, and, when I would suggest that perhaps we needed longer longitudinal studies to proclaim GM totally safe, I get met with claims that 'I don't understand science'.
              </p>
              <p>
               Now admittedly, if the claims were 'I'm lazy at doing statistical analyses upon things said in diaries' she might have a better point. In the comments under this particular diary, somebody did bother to note that the claims presented were statistically very far fetched.
              </p>
              <p>
               But, in general, I find mem's attitudes toward 'science' (not just this particular letter, which I admit looks very odd) very perplexing, and very prone to accepting the status quo. If somebody thinks they've discovered some new wrinkle that's been overlooked, my attitude is 'if you've got the funding, go for it. Study the hell out of it, and if you've actually found something, great!' I don't really care if it flies in the face of 'accepted science'. Pretty much everything ever in science 'flew in the face of' accepted science that predated it.
              </p>
              <p>
               If the person is wrong, if it's a hoax or some artifact of bad methodology or corrupted samples, more studies will quickly reveal such. To me that's what science is about. Actually bothering to find out if some wild claim or other could actually possibly be true and is reproducible, or whether someone intentionally or unintentionally screwed up, and has egg on their face.
              </p>
              <p>
               Can you state the reasons something is unlikely, even highly unlikely? Sure. But mem's attitude always strikes me as being like Frist's - diagnosing with no real data.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
                Help Aji!
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                Ezekial 23 20
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40521976#c481">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:35:51 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c473">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k40521976">
            <li id="c503">
             <div class="cx" id="cx40522490">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Show me the evidence of your claims.
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/949492/40522490#c503?mode=alone;showrate=1#c503">
                 10+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                  kalmoth
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                  murrayewv
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:42998">
                  Arcparser
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                  yuriwho
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:57829">
                  blue jersey mom
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:76550">
                  dirtfarmer
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                  Serpents Choice
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                  KroneckerD
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:169461">
                  Dr Teeth
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:298633">
                  cryonaut
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                I love science. I've been a biologist my whole adult life. There's nothing I want than more quality data.
               </p>
               <p>
                But every time I show the data that people claim doesn't exist on this topic, it's dismissed. I can show you
                <a href="http://gmopundit.blogspot.com/2007/06/150-published-safety-assessments-on-gm.html">
                 hundreds of papers
                </a>
                . I can show the National Academy reports (
                <a href="http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?isbn=0309092094">
                 1
                </a>
                ) (
                <a href="http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12804&amp;page=R1">
                 2
                </a>
                ).
               </p>
               <p>
                But running off on claims that have the credibility of an anti-vaxxer shouting "vaccines caused autism because more kids have autism" is not constructive and should not be promoted. Or "it's snowing at my house there's no global warming" is not a valid basis for policy either.
               </p>
               <p>
                I would love to see the data on this. But this is not data. This is rumor, speculation, possibly fiction, and completely unsubstantiated.
               </p>
               <p>
                I ask for evidence in these diaries. I offer evidence I have. You are coloring your opinion based on your perspective on this topic.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">

                  </p>

                  </p>

                  </p>

                  <p>
                   for the data, in the same spirit that I posted my fist comment.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   You asked for it, didn't actually get it, of course, since no one has it, and two sentences later went onto calling it crap.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   So I apologize for having missed that particular comment, although I doubt the honesty of your having 'asked for it' given the rest of the comment in which you did so.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   But honestly, I think you and I are wasting our time talking to each other.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   If you honestly do love data, then we probably agree that the real proof lies in the data and the science, and we disagree on whether or not it should even be glanced at, or shown to exist or not exist before 'crap' is declared. And I know we disagree on the need for far longer longitudinal studies of the effects of chemical and genetic tinkering with the food supply.

                <li id="c566">

                  <h5>

                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:11236">
                      tomcat
                     </a>

                     <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                      kalmoth
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    because I'm not afraid of it. Data is data.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    But crankery submitted to the feds is about the furthest thing from data there is. And it should be trounced as crankery. It should not be treated as some giant revelation of the troof.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    And if you are surprised that I battle crap science, junk science, and pseudoscience every time it's posted here and I know of it, and for some reason you think I'm not entitled to do so--tell me exactly why I'm not supposed to.
                   </p>

                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    Darwinic pilgrims claim the image fills them with an overwhelming feeling of logic.
                    <a href="http://onion.com/gg6dZ7" rel="nofollow">

                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                     mem from somerville
                    </a>
                    on
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40524251#c566">
                     Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 03:47:05 PM PST
                    </a>
                   </p>
                   <p class="cl">
                    [
                    <a href="#c559">
                     Parent
                    </a>
                    ]
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524251">
                 <li id="c592">
                  <div class="cx" id="cx40524961">
                   <h5>
                    <a class="de">
                    </a>
                    <span class="cu">
                     Sigh, no,
                    </span>
                    <span class="crd ntb">
                     (
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40524961#c592?mode=alone;showrate=1#c592">
                      0+ / 0-
                     </a>
                     )
                    </span>
                   </h5>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     really, I don't know why it is, but you rub on me like nails on a chalkboard at times. I think it's what I see as your absolutism.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     I demand data, I demand proof, I demand repeatability before I'll believe. And I'm dubious of anything anyone writes something scientific in absolutist terms. 'This is the 100% safe distance', 'We can say with certainty that there absolutely is no...', etc. For rhetorical purposes sure. Absolutism is great for rhetoric, for making demagogical arguments.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     But in science, I like an overkill of proof, especially when the consequences of a mistake could be dangerous. So I want so many studies that we don't ever
                     <strong>
                      have
                     </strong>
                     to recall products. I don't want to wind up in the position where we're banning the use of a chemical after releasing it in the environment for decades.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Time and again, humanity has done that. PBDE, Lindane, PFOS, Chloredecone, DDT, Parathion, the list keeps growing. We do studies, we decide something is safe, we start using it, and then as the decades wear on, the problems show up. And how much simpler is the study of a simple chemical, even an organic one, than the systemic interactions of new protein expressions as a result of GM?
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     I may be completely wrong in how I see you, but the way you come across to me is that you're all gung ho about GM, and have no reservations about releasing it into the wild, as long as the studies that have been done look good. While I don't think we've ever had sufficient time or funding by people who don't stand to make a profit off the GM in question to have thoroughly studied every possible angle.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     I'm paranoid, really. But history shows I should be.
                    </p>
                   </div>
                   <div class="cf">
                    <p class="sig">
                     <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
                      Help Aji!
                     </a>
                    </p>
                    <p class="cb">
                     by
                     <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                      Ezekial 23 20
                     </a>
                     on
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40524961#c592">
                      Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:32:11 PM PST
                     </a>
                    </p>
                    <p class="cl">
                     [
                     <a href="#c566">
                      Parent
                     </a>
                     ]
                    </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </li>
                 <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524961">
                  <li id="c600">
                   <div class="cx" id="cx40525184">
                    <h5>
                     <a class="de">
                     </a>
                     <span class="cu">
                      The problem
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">
                      (
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40525184#c600?mode=alone;showrate=1#c600">
                       4+ / 0-
                      </a>
                      )
                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="crs">
                     <dl>
                      <dt>
                       Recommended by:
                      </dt>
                      <dd>
                       <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                        mem from somerville
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/user/uid:36845">
                        kalmoth
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                        murrayewv
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/user/uid:159657">
                        KroneckerD
                       </a>
                      </dd>
                     </dl>
                    </div>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      ...with taking an approach to scientific innovation that we should study it until there is zero [justifiable] chance that we've missed something is that doing so would be outrageously expensive and delay implementation of new things by decades -- after all, we can't know a 30-year cancer risk without 30-year studies. And that raises two questions.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      1. Who pays? That's especially a big question if the funding cannot come from anyone with a financial interest in its outcome. Now, I'm ALL FOR ... oh, let's say halving the defense budget and dumping that all into science. But then I wake up and remember that's never ever going to happen.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      2. When is the marginal risk low enough to stop testing? Each successive test has a smaller and smaller impact on the chances that we missed Something Bad. But we could keep testing forever; there's always some novel combination of factors ("Does exposure increase the 30-year risk of ... say, ovarian cancer in Ashkenazi Jews with a prior history of autoimmune disease?"). But most of those studies would tell us nothing, and we'd be forever waiting before we actually used new science. So, put another way, how much testing is too much testing?
                     </p>
                    </div>
                    <div class="cf">
                     <p class="sig">
                      "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                     </p>
                     <p class="cb">
                      by
                      <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                       Serpents Choice
                      </a>
                      on
                      <a href="/comments/949492/40525184#c600">
                       Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:46:38 PM PST
                      </a>
                     </p>
                     <p class="cl">
                      [
                      <a href="#c592">
                       Parent
                      </a>
                      ]
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525184">
                   <li id="c611">
                    <div class="cx" id="cx40525531">
                     <h5>
                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       I'd say the balance depends on
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/949492/40525531#c611?mode=alone;showrate=1#c611">
                        0+ / 0-
                       </a>
                       )
                      </span>
                     </h5>
                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       the spread of risk.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       If risk is limited to 'Ashkenazi Jews with a prior history of autoimmune disease' that's a pretty small risk pool.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       If the risk extends to 'the entire food supply chain of the entire country and much of the rest of the world', well, that's a pretty big potential risk pool, and could probably stand to have a lot more testing done than for the Jews with autoimmune disorders...
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       And who should pay? Certainly the people who stand to profit from it.
                      </p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="cf">
                      <p class="sig">
                       <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
                        Help Aji!
                       </a>
                      </p>
                      <p class="cb">
                       by
                       <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                        Ezekial 23 20
                       </a>
                       on
                       <a href="/comments/949492/40525531#c611">
                        Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:08:53 PM PST
                       </a>
                      </p>
                      <p class="cl">
                       [
                       <a href="#c600">
                        Parent
                       </a>
                       ]
                      </p>
                     </div>
                    </div>
                   </li>
                   <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525531">
                    <li id="c615">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx40525696">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        On funding
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40525696#c615?mode=alone;showrate=1#c615">
                         1+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="crs">
                       <dl>
                        <dt>
                         Recommended by:
                        </dt>
                        <dd>
                         <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                          murrayewv
                         </a>
                        </dd>
                       </dl>
                      </div>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        Earlier, you said:
                       </p>
                       <blockquote>
                        While I don't think we've ever had sufficient time or funding by people who don't stand to make a profit off the GM in question to have thoroughly studied every possible angle.
                       </blockquote>
                       <p>
                        But then you said:
                       </p>
                       <blockquote>
                        And who should pay? Certainly the people who stand to profit from it.
                       </blockquote>
                       <p>
                        This is one of the things that always bugs me about agribusiness debates, although it comes up in other contexts, too. Everyone wants Monsanto to pay for all the hard research, but no one wants the researchers to
                        <em>
                         get paid
                        </em>
                        by Monsanto.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        As for the risk thing, I'm curious: where do you think we are now compared to an acceptable level of risk for commercial use of GMO crops? How about for direct human consumption of them? And would your answers to either of those be different if we used genetic engineering to improve yield or quality (double-size corn cobs, lets say) instead of for herbicide resistance?
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                       </p>
                       <p class="cb">
                        by
                        <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                         Serpents Choice
                        </a>
                        on
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40525696#c615">
                         Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:18:55 PM PST
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">
                        [
                        <a href="#c611">
                         Parent
                        </a>
                        ]
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <li id="c621">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx40526032">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        Do it the same way I'd like to see political
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40526032#c621?mode=alone;showrate=1#c621">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        funding. The scientists don't get paychecks directly from from Monsanto. The gov't tells Monsanto what running the tests will cost, if Monsanto green lights it, they give the cash to the gov't, who pays for the testing.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Where do we stand? In a tiny pool of light surrounded by darkness. I'd like to see a solid 30 years of longitudinal intergenerational animal consumption testing before we would even consider transgenic GMO entering the food chain outside of a lab. And maybe still 15-20 on cisgenic stuff.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        And a few law changes, such that farmers would be able to sue Monsanto if their crops were contaminated with 'patented' genes, instead of the reverse, with Monsanto suing farmers if contamination occurs, and any product that contains GM ingredients be labeled as containing such.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
                         Help Aji!
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cb">
                        by
                        <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                         Ezekial 23 20
                        </a>
                        on
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40526032#c621">
                         Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:40:50 PM PST
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">
                        [
                        <a href="#c615">
                         Parent
                        </a>
                        ]
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <li id="c623">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx40526162">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        And btw, key would really be
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40526162#c623?mode=alone;showrate=1#c623">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        knowing whether or not you were getting GM. TBH, if you personally want to eat GM food with 0 years of testing, more power to you. Go right ahead.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        But I shouldn't be forced to be a guinea pig for Monsanto GM corn without having volunteered for it.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        If you can guarantee that all GM feed, and all animals that consume it and are then broken down for food are properly labeled as such, I would say devise whatever testing regime for effects you want.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
                         Help Aji!
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cb">
                        by
                        <a href="/user/uid:210303">
                         Ezekial 23 20
                        </a>
                        on
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40526162#c623">
                         Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 05:49:43 PM PST
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">
                        [
                        <a href="#c615">
                         Parent
                        </a>
                        ]
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <li id="c639">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx40526826">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        I'm really more curious
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40526826#c639?mode=alone;showrate=1#c639">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        ...about what it would take for you, personally, to be comfortable with it.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        I hate that Monsanto is the visible representative for genetic engineering. I hate that they abuse our outdated legal framework to bully farmers, including quite a few innocent victims who wanted no part of what they do. I cite them often on my list of "bad corporations".
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        But my problems are with the company, not the science. Transgenic organisms aren't new. The first GMO crop tests were in the 1980s (around 1987, but that may be off a year or so). The industry is about to have its 25th anniversary.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Ironically, even though GMO corn isn't approved as food grade product, and "all fish" accelerated growth salmonids aren't even
                        <em>
                         remotely
                        </em>
                        close to approval, at least one GMO product is already approved -- and in very, very widespread use -- for humans. Insulin. Almost all insulin is now produced by transgenic organisms. Mostly, that's from a transgenic line of
                        <em>
                         E. coli
                        </em>
                        , but there's also an insulin-generating yeast. A transgenic safflower that yields extractable insulin has also been created; in the near future, it will be possible to grow insulin on a farm (In 2009, PI/II trials were completed, analysis prior to approval for PIII is ongoing) instead of in a $100 million laboratory.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        And that's good! Now, we can all probably agree that it would be best if we lived in a world where there wasn't epidemic diabetes. But we're don't, and there is. Trangenic generation of insulin has been responsible for a substantial improvement in availability, especially outside the Western World. And, interestingly enough, it's made diabetics safer. Pigs are the "famous" original source for insulin, but prior to transgenic
                        <em>
                         E. coli
                        </em>
                        , a lot was extracted from cattle, and turns out to have been at a non-zero risk of prion contamination (although, no known cases of prionic disease through this vector; zero chance now).
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        And I really don't understand why cisgenic engineering is problematic, since that's not adding anything new to the species's gene profile. It really
                        <em>
                         is
                        </em>
                        just super-high-speed artificial selection.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                       </p>
                       <p class="cb">
                        by
                        <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                         Serpents Choice
                        </a>
                        on
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40526826#c639">
                         Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 06:34:38 PM PST
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">
                        [
                        <a href="#c623">
                         Parent
                        </a>
                        ]
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <li id="c694">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx40532810">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        It's a systems thing for me
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40532810#c694?mode=alone;showrate=1#c694">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        (Cisgenic) - moving even genes around in the same critter can have unintended and subtle consequences.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Go a bit more macro - look at what happens when you introduce a species to a new environment. The asian carp, the cane toad, the little asian bug that wiped out most American chestnuts - all devastating to the balance of the ecosystems they entered, even though they were 'perfectly natural' in their original locations.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        So even 'super-high-speed artificial selection' can be dangerous. And if the standards of care are sufficiently tight, there simply wouldn't be any lawsuits for Monsanto to file. No one would have Monsanto genes showing up in their fields if there truly was no chance of genes going where they shouldn't.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        I'm glad we're producing insulin, but I hope it's done in controlled environments.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        My problem with the paucity of study we do before releasing new tech to corporate use is that we keep finding out, time and again, that we've not done enough, and we end up having to recall, ban, and treat the resulting damage done. We've always reactive, rather than proactive. In so many fields, time and effort taken upfront costs less than remediating the damage caused by not taking enough care in the beginning. It's inefficient and sloppy, and all done in the name of profit.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        So seriously up gov't science funding and perform far more comprehensive studies now, and avoid the next round of thalidomide babies or mesothelioma sufferers or extinction of native species.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">
                         Help Aji!
                        </a>
                       </p>

                        <a href="/user/uid:210303">

                        <a href="/comments/949492/40532810#c694">
                         Sat Feb 26, 2011 at 07:08:25 AM PST
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">

                        <a href="#c639">

                      </div>

                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">

                        So what?
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40536786#c711?mode=alone;showrate=1#c711">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>

                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        Serpents Choice and I were having a more general discussion about GM at this point, not about this specific letter. Which, btw, I have repeatedly noted in my comments I find dubious at best.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        So what exactly is the point of your non sequitur about the scientists who have a long term dispute with Huber at this point?
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2010/11/15/920412/-Community-Care:-Click-only-if-you-want-to-help-Aji" rel="nofollow">

                    <li id="c727">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx40548042">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        Dubious, yes
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/949492/40548042#c727?mode=alone;showrate=1#c727">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        The debate is interesting, on the Purdue website they say that the issue with Mn uptake is not worth applying extra Mn to GE crops, but a weakened plant, due to micronutrient deficiencies, will be more stressed, and possibly more susceptible to Fusarium. The Purdue guys seem accept the issue of Fusarium. Micro nutrient issues in biology are fairly well understood, and the effects can actually be visible, for example Iron deficiency in turfgrass shows up as a a yellowing of the plant. Foliar application of say... ferrous sulfate...can make the same plant appear much darker green within 24 hrs.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        It looks like the letter may exist and Dr Huber did write it, (my apologies to those involved). But the Letter as we know it, (IMHO) is piss poor, yes dubious at best.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.

            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Yeast is a Micro fungus, and you dont need an elec
             </span>

              (

            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:111567">

          </li>
          <li id="c656">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40527378">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              There was a presentation at the
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40527378#c656?mode=alone;showrate=1#c656">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:175912">
                cdkipp
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Lunar Planetary Institute back in '99, mainly related to the Mars Global Surveyor results , on "nanobacteria" that had recently been observed, although controversially, on Earth - which would make the Mars meteorite results less outlandish. They were about this size.
             </p>
             <p>
              (I was there presenting for our team on the Mars crustal magnetic anomalies, mostly the long alternating polarity ones in the southern hemisphere)
             </p>
             <p>
              I haven't followed the field since, but the idea of organisms visible only to the electron microscope has been kicked around in scientific conferences for at least a decade. Not being a microbiologist, thoug, I can't speak to its validity.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              Non enim propter gloriam, diuicias aut honores pugnamus set propter libertatem solummodo quam Nemo bonus nisi simul cum vita amittit.
-Declaration of Arbroath
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:130411">
               Robobagpiper
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40527378#c656">
               Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 07:15:16 PM PST
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c471">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k40527378">
           <li id="c659">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40527566">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Nanobacteria
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40527566#c659?mode=alone;showrate=1#c659">
                3+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:17717">
                 Paulie200
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                 yuriwho
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:175912">
                 cdkipp
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Technically still an open topic, future doesn't look good for them as a theory.
              </p>
              <p>
               There's been some lab demonstration of very much not alive "'calcifying nanoparticles" that look and behave exactly like putative nanobacteria. And the smoking gun study in favor of them being alive, the 1998
               <i>
                Nanobacterium sanguineum
               </i>
               study out of Finland, failed catastrophically on review; their detected DNA was sequenced and matched
               <em>
                Phyllobacterium mysinacearum
               </em>
               , which will be familiar to any PCR fans around here as a very common contaminant.
              </p>
              <p>
               The guy who made the Martian nanofossil claim is having none of it, however. I suspect he's also wrong, but I'd still give him a long-odds chance at finding something like a nanobacterium in the paleomartian environment.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                Serpents Choice
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/949492/40527566#c659">
                Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 07:28:20 PM PST
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c656">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </ul>

        <li id="c437">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40520582">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Lateral Genetic Transfer is common in nature
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40520582#c437?mode=alone;showrate=1#c437">
             5+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:48175">
              yuriwho
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:76550">
              dirtfarmer
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:169461">
              Dr Teeth
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:225593">
              OldDragon
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:289230">
              Margd
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            We live on a planet where 80% of the biomass is microbial and only a tiny fraction have been identified. Monoculture is a very questionable strategy. The
            <strong>
             application
            </strong>
            of GMO in general and to monoculture specifically should be questioned. Supply chain agribusiness should be questioned. THey are all iffy strategies IMO. We should be looking at distributed hydroponic agriculture on demand - as a much more efficiant use of resources such as water, fertilizer and pesticide. Not a hysteric reaction to all GE.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:283196">
             Visionary Excellence
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40520582#c437">
             Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 12:25:55 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40520582">
         <li id="c452">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40521051">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Great Comment
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40521051#c452?mode=alone;showrate=1#c452">
              4+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:36845">
               kalmoth
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:76550">
               dirtfarmer
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:135733">
               lostboyjim
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:289230">
               Margd
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I have no problem with questioning the strategy used by Monsanto, and you shouldn't need a scare tactic to do it. Genetic engineering is being used as a scape goat.
            </p>
            <p>
             If something gets used as a scape goat too often, it becomes the subject of public contempt. Tell a soldier with spray on skin that repairs burn damage in weeks rather than months how evil genetic engineering is.
            </p>
            <p>
             The same thing was done with stem cell research. It was used as a scape goat in an abortion debate, and hence was branded as controversial.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:169461">
              Dr Teeth
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40521051#c452">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 12:51:44 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">

             <a href="#c437">

        <li id="c475">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40521689">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            fascinating thread.
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40521689#c475?mode=alone;showrate=1#c475">
             0+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            seems like it struck a nerve here. sort of along the lines of the I/P debates. the information in the letter intrigues. just enough info to seem credible, but also enough to question the letter. i keep looking at the word "wheatlege". what does it mean? i don't know, but when you google the word it comes up with web pages that all reference the original letter. i wonder if that was on purpose?
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:162692">
             eb23
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40521689#c475">
             Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:22:17 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40521689">
         <li id="c488">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40522131">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             My presumption
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40522131#c488?mode=alone;showrate=1#c488">
              7+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:7787">
               mem from somerville
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:17717">
               Paulie200
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:36845">
               kalmoth
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:76550">
               dirtfarmer
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:111567">
               Roger Fox
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:135733">
               lostboyjim
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:169461">
               Dr Teeth
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             ...is that "wheatlege" is a typo for "wheatlage", which is sort of a portmanteau shorthand for "wheat silage".
            </p>
            <p>
             That's actually very high on the list of red flags about the validity of the document. Not the misspelling or weird word choice -- well, actually, those too -- but that glyphosate-resistant wheat was never made commercially available by Monsanto. It was actually pulled from development in 2004. On the other hand, glyphosate-resistant corn is freaking everywhere.
            </p>
            <p>
             If you wanted a GMO product to feed to cattle as a test, the logical choice would be glyphosate-resistant corn silage, not a material that largely doesn't exist. And that you spelled wrong.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:87455">
              Serpents Choice
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40522131#c488">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 01:43:26 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c475">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40522131">
