           <li id="c545">
            <div class="cx" id="cx40523480">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               GMO stance
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/949492/40523480#c545?mode=alone;showrate=1#c545">
                6+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:1276">
                 NorthCountryNY
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                 mem from somerville
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                 yuriwho
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:76550">
                 dirtfarmer
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                 Roger Fox
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:162692">
                 eb23
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               I oppose the dissemination of pseudoscience and its use to support political positions, regardless of whether or not I support those positions.
              </p>
              <p>
               Hence, my comments objecting to this diary and the letter it is based on.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
              </p>

              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                I googled around and found some interviews with him. I'm no expert on whether he's right or wrong on any of the substance of his criticisms, but his speaking style sounds like a scientist. The letter sounds phony from start to finish. For him to have written it would have required a very drastic personality change in a few months. This is something that should have been apparent to anyone with a nose for writing style, even if they knew nothing at all about science.
               </p>

               <li id="c590">

                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   Scientist Letter
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40524933#c590?mode=alone;showrate=1#c590">
                    0+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   Letter to USDA Secretary Vilsack Possibly a Fraud
                  </p>
                 </div>
                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                    Roger Fox
                   </a>
                   on
                   <a href="/comments/949492/40524933#c590">
                    Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:30:55 PM PST
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p class="cl">
                   [
                   <a href="#c588">
                    Parent
                   </a>
                   ]
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524933">
                <li id="c664">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx40527964">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Read the article
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40527964#c664?mode=alone;showrate=1#c664">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    and refresh it before you read so you get the current update.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">
                    we are but temporary visitors on this planet. The microbes own this place &lt;- Me
                   </p>
                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:48175">
                     yuriwho
                    </a>
                    on
                    <a href="/comments/949492/40527964#c664">
                     Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 07:56:44 PM PST
                    </a>
                   </p>
                   <p class="cl">
                    [
                    <a href="#c590">
                     Parent
                    </a>
                    ]
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <ul class="cm i1" id="k40527964">
                 <li id="c669">
                  <div class="cx" id="cx40528481">
                   <h5>
                    <a class="de">
                    </a>
                    <span class="cu">
                     Just means
                    </span>
                    <span class="crd ntb">
                     (
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40528481#c669?mode=alone;showrate=1#c669">
                      4+ / 0-
                     </a>
                     )
                    </span>
                   </h5>
                   <div class="crs">
                    <dl>
                     <dt>
                      Recommended by:
                     </dt>
                     <dd>
                      <a href="/user/uid:7787">
                       mem from somerville
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:42401">
                       murrayewv
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:111567">
                       Roger Fox
                      </a>
                      ,
                      <a href="/user/uid:175912">
                       cdkipp
                      </a>
                     </dd>
                    </dl>
                   </div>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     That instead of this being a hoax, Huber is sadly just another scientist whose wheels came off at the end of their career.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     I read the
                     <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/24/us-monsanto-roundup-idUSTRE71N4XN20110224">
                      reuters article
                     </a>
                     again more carefully, and I think see where the problem arose. It has a quote supporting Huber and his research, which is something that I hadn't seen anywhere else. But now I understand.
                    </p>
                    <blockquote>
                     "While the evidence is considered preliminary, the potential damage to humans and animals is severe," said Jeffrey Smith, executive director of the Institute for Responsible Technology.
                    </blockquote>
                    <p>
                     IRT -- which I am
                     <em>
                      not
                     </em>
                     linking to; you want woo, you can Google it yourself -- is a dedicated anti-GMO organization. The organization, including Jeffrey Smith, its head, has a renowned ... looseness of standards for evidence that allows them to oppose the biotech industry. I would consider them a firm part of the anti-science left.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     In particular, they cite the Showa Denko L-tryptophan supplement-induced eosinophiliamyalgia syndrome epidemic as evidence that GMOs are harmful; in reality, that Chinese company had shockingly bad factory controls. The bacteria they were using to produce L-tryptophan were cultured in open vats on an unsecured factory floor, and they admitted to having reduced the amount of carbon employed in a necessary filtration step to cut costs.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Also, they're still champions of Irina Ermakova's study on the effects of soybeans from glyphosate-resistant plants on rats. Her claims were that pups born to rats fed GMO soy had a fivefold mortality rate. Others pointed out that her control had a 10% mortality rate, and so it was clear that, at a minimum, her testing conditions were bad for rats. Also, there was considerable evidence that her study was incorrectly controlled; she did not establish the origins of her test material, and there is reason to doubt that her test soy was entirely as she advertised it. In what some might consider a trend, Ermakova didn't publish her findings in a peer-reviewed journal (and to my knowledge, has not to date). A follow-up study was performed in Japan anyway (citation below, for the hardcore) which refuted ... well, everything she claimed, actually, finding no difference between feeding rats GMO soy and non-GMO soy under identical conditions, for a year.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     This is another sad case of a scientist drawn away from reality-based research by peddlers of anti-science woo.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     That citation: Sakamoto, Y; Tada, Y; Fukumori, N; Tayama, K; Ando, H; Takahashi, H; Kubo, Y; Nagasawa, A; Yano, N; Yuzawa, K; Ogata, A; Kamimura, H (2007) A 52-week feeding study of genetically modified soybeans in F344 rats Journal of the Food Hygeine Society of Japan, 48 (3): 41-50 JUN 2007
                    </p>
                   </div>
                   <div class="cf">
                    <p class="sig">
                     "We are not entitled to our opinions; we are entitled to our informed opinions. Without research, without background, without understanding, it's nothing."
                    </p>
                    <p class="cb">
                     by
                     <a href="/user/uid:87455">
                      Serpents Choice
                     </a>
                     on
                     <a href="/comments/949492/40528481#c669">

                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       My evidence that he does, or has
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/949492/40529215#c688?mode=alone;showrate=1#c688">
                        1+ / 0-
                       </a>

                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       Is that, in the Reuters article, Smith knew what Huber was talking about. Since exactly zotto referenced in that article seems to be published anywhere, the only way that someone could know what Huber's on about is if they were privy to it, if not involved with it.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       It's circumstantial, admittedly. But Huber's never been a supporter of GMO technology, and the arguments being made in that letter are straight out of the IRT playbook. And if IRT wasn't involved, how the hell did Smith wind up as the only person conveniently available for Reuters to quote?
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       No, since hoax sadly was ruled out when Reuters also got a government official to confirm the communication, temptation by the Dark Side seemed the most likely explanation, anyway.
                      </p>

             Micro fungus's are larger than Virus's and you dont need a electron microscope to view them , total ho@@@@it this diary is. Yeast is a micro fungus, right?
            </p>

             Cant do a study on GE Wheat if Mansanto hasnt sold it yet.

         <li id="c704">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40535303">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Perdue response on website
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40535303#c704?mode=alone;showrate=1#c704">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             <a href="http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/purdue-scientists-refute-anti-gmo-claims/">
              http://www.foodsafetynews.com/...
             </a>
            </p>
            <p>
             <a href="http://www.btny.purdue.edu/weedscience/2011/GlyphosatesImpact11.pdf">
              http://www.btny.purdue.edu/...
             </a>
            </p>
            <p>
             Most of the issues with GEcrops seem to be nutrient uptake problems, Fe, Mn, Colbalt, and then a weakened plant may be more susceptible to Fusarium. I did find one study with rats that cited Liver problems, pre diabetic.
            </p>
            <p>
             <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2793308/">
              http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/...
             </a>
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:111567">
              Roger Fox
             </a>

            Oh my, I just realized what this has to be
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">

            <a href="/comments/949492/40524478#c575?mode=alone;showrate=1#c575">

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Didn't anyone see it? Previously unknown microscopic organisms that are apparently being found in all living things that exhibit strange powers to affect the organism in so many different ways?
           </p>

            There's only one thing it can be.
           </p>
           <p>
            <em>
             Midichlorians
            </em>
            .

           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40524796#c587?mode=alone;showrate=1#c587">
             0+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            and no, I haven't checked to see if it's been posted before because I have limited time to spend here these days. I read all of the comments earlier, and it appears to me that many of them are a bit off. Too defensive of an industry that has profited from polluting for too long.
           </p>
           <p>
            Here is the link to another version of Jill's opinion (
            <a href="http://www.truth-out.org/usda-approved-monsanto-alfalfa-despite-warnings-new-pathogen-discovered-genetically-engineered-crops">
             USDA Approved Monsanto Alfalfa Despite Warnings of New Pathogen
            </a>
            www.truth-out.org/
            <br/>
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            "It doesn't take many words to speak the truth" - Chief Joseph, Nez Perce
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:201617">
             Tyto Alba
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/949492/40524796#c587">
             Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:22:11 PM PST
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40524796">
         <li id="c595">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40525039">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             They aren't defensive of an industry
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40525039#c595?mode=alone;showrate=1#c595">
              7+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:11236">
               tomcat
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:17717">
               Paulie200
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:36845">
               kalmoth
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:42998">
               Arcparser
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:111567">
               Roger Fox
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:289230">
               Margd
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:298633">
               cryonaut
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             They're defensive of
             <em>
              reality
             </em>
             . They're defensive of the scientific process. They're defensive of what is good work. They're defensive against crap pseudoscientific bullshit.
            </p>
            <p>
             Because if the level of that letter is what people are willing to accept, well, as a geologist let me tell you about the new mineral I discovered last week: harder than diamond, looks just like red emerald, is a room temperature superconductor, and is made entirely out of pure solid helium. Why, I have a chunk waiting in my office right now, and I'd love to share it with the world but you see there are these shadowy figures I think represent Big Oil lurking around outside my office.
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <em>
              "It doesn't take many words to speak the truth" - Chief Joseph, Nez Perce
             </em>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             "It can often take many words to correct the nonsense which takes but few to spread." - Me
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:1463">
              Northwatch
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40525039#c595">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 04:38:02 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">

             <a href="#c587">

           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40525039">
          <li id="c599">
           <div class="cx" id="cx40525168">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Thanks for some science minded people
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/949492/40525168#c599?mode=alone;showrate=1#c599">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Note, there is no GE Round up ready Wheat, so I dont know what was being studied, additionally round up chemically binds to soil particles. Especially clay, which has more surface area because of its small size.
             </p>
             <p>
              In fact the round up label warns about this, to use drinking water IIRC. If you use river water the round up binds to the silt and and the round up is wasted.
             </p>
             <p>
              <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/04/us-monsanto-wheat-gmo-idUSTRE6A34K220101104">
               http://www.reuters.com/...
              </a>
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              FDR 9-23-33, "If we cannot do this one way, we will do it another way. But do it we will.
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:111567">
               Roger Fox
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/949492/40525168#c599">

              </a>
             </p>

              </a>

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             No Phd of sound mind wrote that. come on. Jill hasn't addressed any concerns all day. Its been 9 hours. Maybe she knows its fake. One cant help but notice the comments, unless one is blind.
            </p>
            <p>
             GE Wheat is not available, so what did they do to claim it was round up? Spray round on the old wheat stalks just before they fed them to cows?
            </p>
            <p>
             You got to remember that no farmer in their right mind is going to spray round up on regular wheat, because it will all die.
            </p>
            <p>
             No GE Wheat was used in the study. But yet it was round up in the wheat that caused 450 cows to miscarry.
            </p>
            <p>
             If you clear a field with round up before planting, the round up chemically binds to the soil and is unavailable to the Wheat plant, planted later.
            </p>
            <p>
             And misspelling Wheatlege, twice....... Puh lease.
            </p>
            <p>
             If this were true it would reason to get a Nobel Prize, not a posting on a blog here:
            </p>

              http://farmandranchfreedom.org/...

        <li id="c648">
         <div class="cx" id="cx40527201">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            The letter makes a number of leaps,
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/949492/40527201#c648?mode=alone;showrate=1#c648">
             6+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:7787">
              mem from somerville
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:17717">
              Paulie200
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:36845">
              kalmoth
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:88255">
              xgz
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:159657">
              KroneckerD
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:289230">
              Margd
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            each of which is incredibly improbable and taken together virtually impossible.
           </p>
           <p>
            The difference in size between a virus and fungi is huge in relative terms. Remember viruses are not really living. They can only reproduce by hijacking a living cell.
           </p>
           <p>
            There simply is no living organism that small.
           </p>
           <p>
            Also, evolution occurs through mutations. Life forms are not spontaneously created. Monsanto may create genetic modifications, but they do not create new life or new organisms.
           </p>
           <p>
            The claim that Roundup serves as a reservoir for this organism seems absurd and the idea that it infects both plants and animals, causing 45% abortion in cows and hurting plants, strains credulity more than anything on the SyFy network.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>

         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k40527742">
         <li id="c667">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40528396">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             "Lab" cattle?
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40528396#c667?mode=alone;showrate=1#c667">
              5+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:36845">
               kalmoth
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:42401">
               murrayewv
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:111567">
               Roger Fox
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:159657">
               KroneckerD
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:175912">
               cdkipp
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Did you see ANY claim that the cattle were involved in an actual STUDY? I didn't. (Not to pick on just you and your worthy comment, because a lot of people seem to be assuming that.)
            </p>
            <p>
             Huber, or the person claiming to be Huber, never mentioned a study. THAT is the problem. And it's NOT how scientists communicate, even to non-scientists. Even when scientists say "I got a hunch", and they do all the time informally, it is couched in much more qualified and defined terms.
            </p>
            <p>
             I can guarantee you that too many of the actual science people who post here went out and wasted googles of electrons, and time, on the web trying to find ANY study that this MIGHT have been referring to. (Other than Huber's, if it IS him, ramblings.)
            </p>
            <p>
             My hunch is that Huber, or the person claiming to be Huber, is likely talking about an anecdote with the 450/1000 cattle aborting, if it has any real basis in fact at all.
            </p>
            <p>
             For hundreds of years before Roundup and GMO, instances of bad silage sickening and killing animals were not uncommon. (Google this 'aflatoxin silage') You don't have to invent a new microorganism, directed at something you consider "evil" to make events like those described happen.
            </p>
            <p>
             When I see some science I'll change my mind. But from what I've read so far, Huber might as well be blaming witches for sickening cattle.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:17717">
              Paulie200
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/949492/40528396#c667">
              Fri Feb 25, 2011 at 08:32:27 PM PST
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c663">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <ul class="cm i1" id="k40528396">

         <li id="c726">
          <div class="cx" id="cx40544710">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I can find no evidence they state it is a fraud
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/949492/40544710#c726?mode=alone;showrate=1#c726">

             </a>

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I see them rebutting the claims of this letter without ever mentioning Dr. Huber, I see the Chairman of the department suggesting it might be a fraud, but nowhere do I see a statement that this was not written by Dr. Huber.
            </p>
            <p>
             I think Purdue is in damage control mode and they know they have a loose cannon in Dr. Huber. I'm willing to bet that at the next faculty meeting of the Pant Path department, they vote to remove his emeritus status.....unless he agrees in writing to stop speaking with the media or political officials, or posting anything to the internet on the topic of roundup.
            </p>
            <p>
             They going to do what they can to silence him, if he objects they will sever all ties to remain credible as an academic institution.
            </p>

  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   $(document).ready( App.initOnReady );
	
        kos.story_id = 949492;
        kos.sid = '2011/2/24/213451/902';
		//kos.LAST_SEEN = '0';
		kos.LAST_SEEN = DailyKos.CommentCount.getReadCommentCount(kos.story_id);
		kos.pub_status = 'published';
		kos.version = 0;
		kos.trcount = 0;
		kos.trremain = 0;
		kos.serial = 739;
		kos.updated = '2015-04-11 16:16:33';
		kos.hidingchoice = false;
		kos.can_comment = 0;

		jQuery(function() {
			jQuery('li.from-mobile .cx').each(function() {
				var counts				= jQuery(this).find('.crd.ntb').clone(true),
						dropTriangle 	= jQuery(this).find('.de').clone(true);

				jQuery(this).find('h5').hide();
				jQuery(this).find('.ct').prepend(dropTriangle);
				jQuery(this).find('.ct').prepend(counts);
				jQuery(this).find('.ct::first-line').css('background', 'red')	});
		});
	
		$('#popup-story_setTags').dialog({
			autoOpen: false,
			width: 600,
			position: 'center',
			close: App.onAjaxPopupClose,
			buttons: {
				"OK" : App.onAjaxPopupSubmit,
				"Cancel" : App.onAjaxPopupCancel
			}
		});
	
		$('#popup-story_hotlist').dialog({
			autoOpen: false,
			width: 500,
			position: 'center',
			close: App.onAjaxPopupClose,
			buttons: {
				"Save" : App.onAjaxPopupSubmit,
				"Cancel" : App.onAjaxPopupCancel
			}
		});
	
		$('#popup-story_unHotlist').dialog({
			autoOpen: false,
			width: 400,
			position: 'center',
			close: App.onAjaxPopupClose,
			buttons: {
				"OK" : App.onAjaxPopupSubmit,
				"Cancel" : App.onAjaxPopupCancel
			}
		});
	
		$('#popup-story_removeRating').dialog({
			autoOpen: false,
			width: 400,
			position: 'center',

    e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript');

       "js/chartbeat.js");

  <script src="/j/metrics.js" type="text/javascript">
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   DailyKos.Metrics.metricsOn = (0 === 1);
	  DailyKos.Metrics.sampleSize = 20;
		DailyKos.Metrics.setUserProperties({
			requestFormat: 'full site',
			subscriber: false,
			mobile: $.browser.mobile,
			loggedIn: false,
			staff: false
		});
		DailyKos.Metrics.init();
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/story/)) {
			  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Story', {  url: "http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/02/25/949492/-A-Scientific-Bombshell-Dropped-This-Week", 
			                                            blog: "Sustainable Food and Agriculture",
			                                            author: $('.author').children('a').first().html(),
			                                            title: $('#titleHref').html()
			                                          });
			} else if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/comment/)) {
			  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Comment');
			}
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   if($.cookie('meter_user') !== 'false') {
		if ($('#ePostButton').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('#ePostButton').click(function() { 
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Posted Comment', { 
		      repliedTo: $(this).parents('#eP').prevAll('.cb').children('a').first().html() 
		    });
		  });
		}
		
		if (!!document.location.pathname.match('activate') &amp;&amp; $('h1:contains("Welcome to Daily Kos!")').length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Signed Up');
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname === '/') {
		  if (document.location.hostname.match(/^www|^dailykos/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Front Page');
		  } else {
		    var subdomain = document.location.hostname.split('.')[0];
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Vertical', { name: subdomain });
		  }
		}
		
		if ($('.ratinate').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.ratinate').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Recommended Comment') });
		}
		
		if ($('.do-addRating.type-story').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.do-addRating.type-story').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Recommended Story') });
		}
		
		if ($("form[action$='publishHow']").length &gt; 0) {
		  $(document).ready(function() {
			  $('.type-story.do-publishHow').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Published Story') });
			 });
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/user/) &amp;&amp; $('li.here').length &gt; 0) {
		  if ($('.pageMenu:first li.here').children('a').html().match(/Stream/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Stream', { name: $('.name').children('a').html() });
		  } else if ($('.pageMenu:first li.here').children('a').html().match(/Profile/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Profile', { name: $('.name').children('a').html() });
		  } else if ($('.pageMenu:last li.here').children('a').html().match(/My Recent Replies/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Replies');
		  }
		} 
		
		if ($('#search-tabbed').length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Searched');
		}
		
		if ($('#group-tables').length &gt; 0) {
			DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Groups List');
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/groups/) &amp;&amp; $("#group_info").length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Group', { name: $('.name').children('a').text() });
		}
		
		if ($('.do-hotlist.type-user, .do-unHotlist.type-user').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.do-hotlist.type-user, .do-unHotlist.type-user').click(function() {
		    var nickName;
		    nickName = ($(this).prev('a').html() || $('.name a').html())
		    if ($(this).hasClass('do-hotlist')) {
		      DailyKos.Metrics.track('Followed User', { nickname: nickName }) 
		    } else if ($(this).hasClass('do-unHotlist')) {
		      DailyKos.Metrics.track('Unfollowed User', { nickname: nickName }) 
		    }    
		  });
		}
	}
  </script>
  <!-- end mixpanel -->
